name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements concerning the preparation of the European Council meeting (19 and 20 October)

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, in two weeks’ time, the 28 Heads of State or Government will be meeting in Brussels. President Tusk has put four items on the agenda: migration, digital Europe, defence and external relations. Let me take them one by one. The first item on the agenda is migration. Recent developments are encouraging. Illegal flows along the central Mediterranean route have gone down significantly. The determined action of the EU as a whole, together with the resolute bilateral efforts from Member States, is yielding results. Leaders will want to consolidate these trends and root them in a long-term vision. This is why we need to scale up our work with international partners. This is also why a strong partnership with countries of origin and transit is indispensable. Tackling the root causes is the only way to handle this challenge of irregular immigration in the long term. Concerning the future Common European Asylum System, the European Council is expected to welcome progress already achieved and to call for further convergence to reach an agreement which strikes the right balance between responsibility and solidarity and ensures resilience to future crises. Second on the agenda, leaders will come back to the digital vision for Europe, following the successful Digital Summit in Tallinn last Friday. Behind the concept of a digital Europe lies more than the digital single market. The leaders will of course also want to take stock of the progress made on the concrete legislative proposals under the digital single market but there is much more. The question today is quite simply whether Europe is gearing up to meet the challenges and opportunities of the digital revolution. This is a key challenge for the future of Europe. It has an impact on all aspects of our lives, be it our citizens, our businesses or our governments. Leaders already touched upon this issue last June. Digital was also the focus of the summit last Friday in Tallinn in which you, President Tajani, also participated. In October, the European Council will provide further guidance to ensure that Europe is well equipped for this transformational change.  Let me now turn to the third item on the agenda, defence. Leaders established a comprehensive work programme in December 2016. They moved the discussion further in June 2017 with additional guidance focused on Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO), but also on EU battlegroups and the industrial dimension of EU defence. More has been achieved in the last year than in a decade. Leaders are keeping a close eye on progress to maintain this momentum. In October, they will review efforts to launch an inclusive and ambitious Permanent Structured Cooperation. Discussions are moving in the right direction. Leaders will want to push for a rapid agreement on that basis.  The last item on the agenda of the European Council is external relations. Leaders will discuss recent developments on the international stage. One of the topics for this debate will be relations with Turkey. It is a little too early to pin down the other topics which will require leaders’ attention. I will therefore leave this open.  To conclude, I would also like to mention that leaders will meet as 27 in October as well. You discussed the latest state of play of the Brexit negotiations yesterday. You adopted a resolution and, as you know, a fifth round of negotiations is scheduled for next week. The European Council, under Article 50, will be the occasion for the 27 leaders to review the state of the negotiations.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: , vice-président de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, Monsieur le Président en exercice du Conseil, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, il y a trois semaines, s’adressant à cette assemblée, le président Juncker a appelé, dans son discours sur l’état de l’Union, à savoir tirer profit d’une conjoncture qui, pour l’instant, nous est plutôt favorable.  Il est vrai qu’aujourd’hui, l’Europe bénéficie d’une reprise économique qui commence à se faire sentir dans tous nos États membres et d’un regain de confiance. De nouvelles opportunités s’ouvrent, et la balle est dans notre camp. Saisissons-la au bond car en réalité, il nous reste encore beaucoup à faire pour passer d’une amélioration économique passagère à une amélioration durable, qui sera réellement ressentie dans toutes nos régions par tous nos citoyens, y compris par les jeunes à la recherche d’un emploi.  Il nous reste encore beaucoup à faire pour passer d’un regain de confiance à une véritable adhésion à un projet d’avenir commun. Le prochain Conseil européen, d’ici dix jours, doit être l’occasion de faire quelques pas de plus dans cette direction, dans le même esprit d’urgence et d’énergie qui ressort des discours récents de Jean-Claude Juncker, d’Emmanuel Macron et d’Antonio Costa. Nous devons maintenir fermement notre cap en répondant concrètement aux attentes et aux préoccupations de nos concitoyens, et en ne cédant rien sur nos valeurs, y compris le respect de l’état de droit. Le moment est venu de nous fixer des objectifs ambitieux mais réalisables d’ici 2025 pour une Union à vingt-sept plus unie, plus forte et plus démocratique. Honourable Members, the Europe we are working for each day is a Europe which protects its citizens, which empowers and defends them. The Digital Agenda which was at the heart of the discussions at the summit in Tallinn, and which will also be on the agenda for the European Council, is one example of where we really need to show concrete results. Since the start of the mandate, this Commission has presented some 40 initiatives, 24 of which are legislative proposals. We have proposed action ranging from making sure high quality internet is available in public spaces for thousands of local communities, to measures to combat threats to cybersecurity and to ensure that personal data is as well protected online as it is offline. We have launched a discussion about how best to ensure that services provided through online platforms are effectively taxed.  It is now time to find agreement on the 18 legislative proposals which are pending here in this House and in the Council. I hope that we can see tiny progress in particular on the telecoms package, the revision of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, and on our recent proposals on cybercrime.  The Commission would also like to see timely progress on the other new proposals made together with the State of the Union speech. Trade in particular is an area where urgent action is needed to take advantage of the momentum. The European Council will also pay particular attention to migration. Last week, the Commission presented our views on how to ensure and consolidate the ongoing work on the European Agenda on Migration. We have identified where and what further efforts are needed in coming months. Particular attention must be given to stepping up returns and to resettlement, whilst the reform of the Common European Asylum System in Dublin now needs to be completed as soon as possible. We must also continue our work with priority third countries and the Commission would like to see a concerted effort from leaders when it comes to the issue of financing, where we need to live up to our collective promises and we are living up to them today.  Finally, the European Council will also review progress on defence. The Commission is closely following the developments on Permanent Structured Cooperation. The Commission wants to incentivise greater cooperation in defence in line with the Treaty and stands ready to support it with the instruments at its disposal. For this, we need to ensure an early agreement on the proposed European defence industrial development programme. Honourable Members, together we have more or less 18 months to finish the job and deliver on the 10 priorities on the basis of which this House approved the college in 2014. If we fail, this will be a collective failure. To the outside world it makes no difference whether we failed because the Commission made the wrong proposals, or Parliament or Council took too long. When we succeed, it will be our collective success. When we fail, it will also be our collective failure. I set out in the road map for a more united, stronger and more democratic Union. Europe now has an opportunity to look further ahead. The road map sets out a path to March 2019 when our Union will sadly become a union of 27. It is in Sibiu, Romania, on the banks of the Cibin river in Transylvania, that we should reassert this Union and our confidence in our future together, a Union based on our values, a Union of equals, a Union able to deliver for its citizens on the things that matter the most.  We saw in Tallinn that there is now a real appetite amongst European leaders to move forward together, but we cannot wait until March 2019 to start the work and we cannot be bogged down in process, treaty changes or institutional wrangles in the meantime. That is why in the letter of intent, Jean-Claude Juncker and I laid out a concrete set of actions which are all achievable under the current treaties to prepare the Europe of 2025. I can assure you that we will continue to work alongside you every step of the way, starting with a social summit in Gothenburg where I hope we can  proclaim the European Pillar of Social Rights. And then in December, with the euro area summit underpinned by concrete proposals to deliver a strong economic and monetary union and ensure the lasting stability and success of our European single currency.  This summit will be inclusive with the participation of those EU members whose intention is to introduce the euro before 2025. I know Jean-Claude is looking forward to organising the summit together with President Tusk. The Commission will then present its full package of proposals on the EMU on 6 December. For Dutch and Flemish people, I would say on St Nicholas day.  I trust that the Commission can count on the full support of this House as we implement the road map together. Let’s use the next 18 months to deliver positive changes in the lives of Europeans and to set the course for a more united, stronger and more democratic Union for the future. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Mr Councilor, my dear colleagues! People expect practical action from us, and I would like to thank both the Council representative and Frans Timmermans for this basic direction that we are now dealing with the issues that concern the people. I also think it's important what Frans Timmermans did, namely to talk about the successes first. We can only convince people of our project and take them with us if we talk about successes. The growth in the euro area is strong and solid, we have reduced unemployment to pre-crisis levels, the debt in the euro area, in the European Union - compared with the Americans, with the Japanese, with other major currency areas - is low. We have also made significant progress on the second major task, namely solving the migration issue. Compared to 2015, when we had the large migration flows, the numbers at the external border were reduced by over 80%. Europe delivers, Europe moves forward, and we can tackle the big tasks together. And yesterday, too, we achieved a great success: our colleague Salvatore Cicu and all those responsible in the other political groups found new investment protection and new WTO regulations - in partnership with all parties. We want world trade, but we Europeans also want to be able to defend ourselves when unfair world trade is practiced. Big steps for this continent! I believe that we are entitled to talk about Europe delivering. The Council is about the tasks that now lie ahead of us. The main topic is certainly the great open wound on the continent, and that is still the question of migration. Despite successes, there is still no legislative solution as to how we can permanently solve the migration issue. It is clear to the EPP Group that Europe must help. We need people who flee the civil war, offer shelter. On the other hand, we need control and a strong state that puts a stop to the gangs of smugglers and organized crime. That is why we have to work on further developing border protection. Why don't we further strengthen Frontex - for example by building up additional capacities for direct intervention at certain borders of the Schengen area? Second, we need cooperation with the United Nations. Last week's Commission proposal to offer a 50 000 resettlement quota is the right way to go. Controlled and structured by the United Nations, bringing people in need to Europe in order to offer them better care based on humanitarian criteria, as well as security checks - that is the right way to go. The third thing we have to make clear is that the asylum issue is not an issue. Asylum is a fundamental right of the European Union, which we have fought for through many bloody experiences that we have had. That is why the right of asylum should not be an issue in any way. Real help is needed there. And last but not least: Solidarity with Africa, fighting the causes of displacement. Europe will only be able to live in peace in the long term if Africa also has a reasonable future. The second big issue is the digital agenda. I would like to thank you for the many proposals that the Commission has put on the table. The urgency is obvious. Europe can only move forward if we act together to achieve economies of scale. We have to strike a balance between taking advantage of opportunities and simultaneously implementing our values. I would like to make it clear to the EPP Group that we as Europeans already have the task of giving this digital single market a framework that is shaped by our values. For example, the copyright that we are currently debating is a value that we recognize to have. We need to protect intellectual property. That must also be enforced in the digital world, principles must be enforced, because this is the only way we will defend our way of life. The next big issue will be security policy and foreign policy. I would like to single out two more points on foreign policy. On the one hand, on behalf of my group, I would like to show that I fully support Federica Mogherini and our external colleagues that we consider the agreements with Iran to be existential. It would be a catastrophic development if we now open a second nuclear conflict in this world in addition to the North Korea conflict. What Europe has achieved there with the Iran Agreement is an example of the fact that we are not resolving these conflicts through war, but through diplomatic means with agreements. We hope that Europe speaks a clear language. Last but not least, I would like to make a political note: we are experiencing our ongoing struggle against populism and extremism on this continent. We had positive experiences like in France, we also had negative experiences like now in Germany, for example, where populists and extremists are moving back into parliament in strength. In other words, the debate, the fight against these simplifiers, remains on our table. I would just like to say one thing, and that, dear Gianni Pittella, in the direction of social democracy, because in the German experience on election evening a week ago we saw that German social democrats refused to talk about forming a government from the start . Martin Schulz decided to immediately join the opposition. I personally believe that it is right that we as Democrats talk to each other first. Going into the opposition may be the result of conversation, but it is not the starting point for going into the opposition. I'm bringing this up here because that's what we're in the The Netherlands have seen it because we have seen it in Spain, too, that social democracy is increasingly evading responsibility.I hope that doesn't catch on.(Applause from the EPP Group)

name: Gianni Pittella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleague Weber, I do not think it is appropriate to discuss the German elections while the next European Council is being discussed. But if you really want an answer on this point, I welcomed Mr Schulz's decision to take note of the conclusion of the grand coalition in Germany, as we did here in the European Parliament a few months earlier. This does not mean that we cannot collaborate: it is one thing to have a strong, true dialectic between right and left, moderate conservatives and progressives, and one thing is to do the big coalitions. Yesterday we demonstrated, on the issue of recognizing China as a market economy, that Parliament, while maintaining this strong dialectic, can work together and we have achieved a great result, defending European industries and European workers. I want to thank the comrades and colleagues of the Socialist Group who played a crucial role, starting with my colleague Moscow, my colleague Maurel and President Bernd Lange. I have heard comforting words from Frans Timmermans, First Vice-President, which are in line with the report made by President Juncker and I want to say to the European Commission: the Socialists are ready, they have always been ready! When it comes to action and doing, we are ready; when it comes to having courage, we are ready! We are not ready and we are against, when you put your head in the sand. We must challenge the Council, together, in a constructive way, but in a clear way. On immigration we await convincing answers. The fact that flows have been reduced by 80% cannot reassure us about the elimination of the root causes of migratory flows; indeed, we must use this phase to address the root causes that push thousands and thousands of people to come to Europe and we must not trade the causes with the effects and wrong therapy. The therapy cannot be to force Europe and Africa into a fortress. Therapy cannot be to build new walls! I say this to the Council and I say it to the Commission: the idea of ​​creating new borders, of strengthening the internal borders of European states, of extending the time at these borders is the wrong weapon to tackle a serious problem which is that of terrorism. It is legitimate for Member States to equip themselves with effective tools in the fight against terrorism, but do not delude yourself that you are curing a serious problem with aspirin! Aspirin can cause stomach ulcers: internal borders can abolish a great European achievement which is the free movement of people within the European Union. And be careful not to transform the hotspots, which are a tool for the emergency management of flows, into a tool for the ordinary management of migratory flows. It is not fair, it is not useful, it is not effective to do these things. In recent days we have appealed to President Tusk to finally recognize the Council of Bulgaria in Romania and, in due time also for Croatia, the right to be part of the Schengen area but also to finally reform the Dublin regulation: the Parliament he is doing his job - as always - and the Council must begin his! Here we cannot say: "Europe does not work". No! The Commission has made a proposal and Parliament is working on it. It is the Council that did not open the file! This is the truth. We want to say it clearly and loudly: when the Council opens it, I will say: "Good Council, you are doing well, you are doing well" and we must clearly say that the rule that states that it is the first country of arrival to take on all the burdens and of all responsibilities is contrary to the spirit of unity and solidarity that must exist in the European Union. Finally, Africa. Colleague Weber also spoke about it: he tells me pleasure, because this idea is spreading that Africa is our priority.Two years ago the Trust Fund was launched in Valletta;well, great foresight of Vice President Mogherini and the European Commission.But the Member States that fed that fund were very few: here too I say this to the representative of the Council: take it upon himself!Africa is not a slogan: Africa is an issue that requires answers.The 44 billion euro investment plan is doing well: but those investments must be conveyed and aimed at interventions that really create development and create jobs, because this serves to give African girls and boys a future and also to reduce migration flows.I am increasingly convinced that the solution of our global and local challenges is coming from Africa.I would like to conclude with a beautiful phrase by Fatou Diome."We must stop with the hypocrisy: we will be rich together or we will all drown together".

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is highly probable that the Council will start with everyone congratulating Chancellor Merkel on her electoral victory. Indeed, Ms Merkel should be congratulated. Firstly, because she won for the fourth time, which is remarkable; secondly, because she won after having made the worst political decision of her life: opening the European borders without bothering to consult anyone. So much for solidarity, by the way.  Yet, while Ms Merkel’s victory was a success, it should also be viewed in equal measure as a wake-up call for Europe. After all, the two main parties scored the worst results for years, something that only months ago happened in the French elections too. For many years, Germany epitomised what political science calls ‘consensual politics’. We had a sample of it a while ago in what Mr Weber said, to put it crudely, a sort of united front in which everyone tends to speak with one voice. But if in a country like this – and Germany is just such an example, because of its remarkable political culture – we see some cracks in the hitherto monolithic structure, perhaps we are witnessing the beginning of some kind of pluralism underway in the western part of the European Union.  As for me – and on this point I believe I differ from most of you – I believe it is a good thing and long overdue, considering the stifling atmosphere of European politics, the absence of any serious debate, and the routine bullying of anyone who dares to voice a different opinion. The Council will take up for the nth time the problem of immigration – perhaps the most misrepresented, mystified, lied about, contaminated to the core by political correctness, problem of recent decades. The good thing is that the infamous mandatory relocation scheme is now history. It is dead. It is dead and gone. It is an ex—relocation scheme. But from the very beginning this was a bad idea. This was a stillborn idea, and whatever progress we have achieved in controlling immigration – and we have made some progress – this scheme had nothing to do with it whatsoever. Will this idea disappear? I am not sure. Experience has taught us that in the European Union bad ideas die hard. There has been a lot of talk about the new European asylum policy, and it is a good thing that we should be working on it and making it better and better. President Macron mentioned it in his speech too, but President Macron’s speech was not really the exposition of a strategy as a lot of us expected it to be. It was more – I apologise for the comparison – like a pep talk, but beautifully delivered as always. So whatever shape this asylum policy – and everything that surrounds it that is related to immigration – will take, it should not repeat the errors of the past. The asylum policy on immigration is not a matter for a majority to decide. There has to be a consensus of all Member States. Otherwise, we will be back in the situation where the big guys do what they want, they can get away with anything and they order the others are not so strong to obey. That has to be over. Demographic policy is too subtle and too complex a problem to be imposed by the European political and ideological bulldozers. Of course, anything is possible so it can be predicted that remarks like mine will be ignored and the EU will sink more deeply into the sea of troubles, because we are already quite deep in the sea of troubles. There should be some hard thinking rather than going in the same direction with the same remedy – whatever happens, more of the same. That is not a solution. I have serious doubts if the coming Council will start rethinking, but I really hope they do. I do hope against hope.  (Applause from the ECR Group)

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I hope for two things for this European Council. The first has been already echoed by other colleagues, namely that there can be a breakthrough in the migration package. In fact, if there is one role the European Council can play, it is on that because they have to give political direction. So a conclusion by the European Council, where they push forward the package as it has been introduced by the Commission is what we need now, because we can continue to complain about Dublin, which is not a European system of asylum, we can continue to complain about the lack of legal migration ways in Europe, and we can continue to complain about the bad management of our outside borders, but the proposals are there. We need a European Council which in fact now steers the Ministers of the Interior responsible in that direction. So that is my first wish.  My second wish for this European Council is to further take up the work on the reform of the European Union. My fear is that – you know how it is – there are elections in France, elections in the Netherlands, elections in Germany and then it is like– I cannot say a pudding, because that is a British word I think – a soufflé, that is maybe a French word, and then suddenly we go back to business as usual. Business as usual for the last 18 months before the European elections. That cannot be the case. I think that President Juncker made an enormous effort on this reform of the European Union with his State of the Union speech, I think that President Macron made an enormous effort with his important intervention on the future of the European Union, and we hope to see other leaders express themselves on this. I do not even see big differences. The whole discussion about the difference between the Macron speech and the Juncker speech is that one is saying we are going to do it in one circle and the other is saying that we are going to do it in two circles. But on the content, we agree and not only do they agree, but also this House because let me recall that, at the beginning of this year, we adopted three important reports on the future of the European Union which were completely in line with President Juncker’s State of the Union speech and which were completely in line with the proposals of the French President. (Applause from ALDE and Vert Groups)  So it is the moment – and that is my message to the Council – to pick this up and not to lose the momentum because it is true what Manfred Weber said. It is not the end of nationalism. It is not the end of populism. It will be the end of nationalism and populism if we are capable of reforming the European Union, changing the European Union and breaking the deadlock that exists. In that sense, I think there are doubts – the Liberals in Germany, will there be an obstacle, yes or no? – but I can tell you one thing. I know the FDP. It is a genuine pro-European party still anchored in the legacy of Hans—Dietrich Genscher, in favour of a European defence union, in favour of European transnationalism, and in favour of European capacities in investigation and intelligence. If there is a difference in the point of view on the eurozone, we know that there are rules to be applied in the eurozone and we want a new governance of the eurozone. Well, the one is not in contradiction with the other. You need both of them. You need a new governance to have a sustainable eurozone and to apply these rules.  So my last wish – and this is not for the Council President but more for us – is what is the role we are going to play in this? It is this House that has to take the lead on this reform and this debate on the European Union. So my plea to you – and I know that you are in favour – and also to the plenary is let’s organise here, every session, this debate on the future of the European Union. Secondly, let’s ask, through our Committee on Constitutional Affairs, to have regular meetings with the national parliaments because we are not going to reform the European Union without the help of these national democracies and these national parliaments. Finally, let’s put the three institutions together – the Commission, the Council, the Parliament – in such an endeavour.   (Applause from the ALDE Group)

name: Dennis de Jong
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, after the Second World War, Europe was the driving force behind the many treaties that were concluded to protect human rights. The Geneva Convention on the Protection of Refugees was one of these. Now the European Council is to talk about stemming illegal flows on all migration routes. That same Geneva Convention states very clearly that illegal entry can never be held against refugees, so this type of language undermines respect for the elementary rights of refugees. I call upon the Council to rephrase the wording, putting the emphasis again on Europe’s tradition of caring about people, and to make sure that the refugees are protected. In the field of human rights, ambition is lacking more generally. The Commission is making no progress whatsoever with the ratification by the EU of the European Convention on Human Rights, nor with the European Social Charter. When, First Vice-President Timmermans, can we expect to see a breakthrough here? In a few weeks’ time, in Geneva, the UN will again discuss a convention on business and human rights. The Commission and the Member States are not driving forces there, indeed they are reluctant to participate, whereas we all know about inhuman practices, in closing factories, or in mines, and in Africa and developing countries generally. If we want dignity and stability, we need to invest in respect for human rights, including by our companies, instead of in arms and defence. We all saw the tragic pictures of the attack in Las Vegas. It is cynical that, after such an attack, arms sales in the USA go up – for so-called self-defence. This is a vicious circle: the more arms people buy, or a state buys, the more attacks. Let us learn from this. Instead of speaking about more defence, let us stick to the European tradition of promoting human rights, including through radical disarmament treaties. We should not fall into the Trump vicious circle. Let us be different, let us be ourselves and let us invest in human rights and not in arms. (Applause from the left)

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: , on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, last summer, on a hill in the south of Burgundy, I met about twenty young Hungarians who told me of their dismay in the face of a society, a Europe, moreover. in addition polarized, cut in two by lines of fracture, apparently impassable, which divide even within families. I think they were right because, little by little, our Union seems to be won over by this cancer of the mind, which would like to reduce our societies to an opposition between “them” and “us”, like a landscape without nuances, frozen, in black and white, the realm of real and virtual walls which, when they are not concrete or barbed wire, are erected by words or actions. In such a world, we are constantly called to choose our side. There are plenty of examples. Remember the euro crisis, which separated Europe between creditor states, by definition virtuous in everything, and debtor countries, necessarily guilty of everything. On the issue of posted workers, there would be the ugly profiteering Member States, and the nice Member States victims of social dumping. After the terrorist attacks, I remember a French prime minister asserting that to explain was already a little excuse, or even here, that refusing the general surveillance of our society would be tantamount to being an accomplice of the killers. Finally, any call for Europe to take its responsibilities to do more and better in welcoming migrants is immediately denounced as an unbearable call or a threat to our identity. Dear colleagues, what happened last Sunday in Barcelona is the result of this binary logic, according to which you have to choose sides. Faced with the obvious dissatisfaction of a majority of citizens of Catalonia with the status of their region, the government in Madrid has chosen denial. Over the years, this stubborn refusal to engage in dialogue has led to unilateral actions, certainly, but peaceful, of which nothing, absolutely nothing, can justify the violent repression which we have witnessed. And make no mistake, because you will ask me what is the connection with the Council? Make no mistake about it! What is playing out in Catalonia at the moment is not only a Spanish affair, it affects the European Union in its foundations, because what is the European Union, if not a conscious and resolute decision to resolve our conflicts and differences through dialogue, negotiation and compromise rather than violence. Isn't our motto "Unity in Diversity", a diversity that we choose to see as an asset, rather than a handicap? It is all of this that is at stake today in the Spanish constitutional and political crisis. That’s why, Mr. Juncker or Mr. Timmermans, that’s why, Mr. Tusk, you cannot remain spectators. Who can understand the silence and inaction of the Commission? Who could understand, Mr Maasikas, that the European Council meets next week ignoring a crisis which, far more than Brexit, can undermine the very spirit of European integration? If this is an internal matter, Mr Timmermans, it is an internal matter within the European Union. If anything needs to be done to help reconnect the thread of dialogue between Spain and Catalonia, it is up to the European Union to do so. And there is urgency. Let us not wait for further unilateral steps to take place, which would make a negotiated solution even more difficult. Dear colleagues, it is the very credibility of the European Union and its project that is at stake here.

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mister President! An exciting debate - it is particularly exciting who is talking about what here. Mr Weber has started to talk about the German Bundestag and the formation of a government. Mr Weber, we are very much looking forward to you doing politics together with the Greens and then voting in Bavaria next year. We are eagerly awaiting how you intend to enforce a hard line on the matter of migration. We look at this with great pleasure and interest. The Council talks about the digital, about defense, about external relations and then in about 45 seconds also about migration on the sidelines. That sets you apart from Mr Timmermans, who has not talked about migration for so long. You talked about the upswing that can be seen everywhere, about the values ​​we want to preserve, about the digital agenda, about cybersecurity, broadband expansion, trade. But you hardly touch the all-important issue on which the future of the European Union will be decided. But that's how it is. We are two years after the outbreak of the dramatic refugee crisis and there are still two unanswered questions. First, how do we prevent millions more from entering Europe? Second, how do we bring back those who came here illegally? We have to state that the Balkan route is still not sealed. Those who are committed to it are attacked as hard as possible. This is Mr Orbán, he is being attacked and not defended. At the same time we support Macedonia - not a member of the EU, not a member of the Schengen area. There we build fences, there we support fence construction. But if Mr Orbán does that, he will be criticized. We make deals with warlords all over the world - e.g. on the Bosporus. B. with Mr. Erdoğan. This is completely the wrong way. We still don't have the Australian solution. We have to like France suspend the European Convention on Human Rights so that we can rescue the refugees in the Mediterranean, but then drag them back and not across to Europe. Instead, we also make deals with Libyan warlords - it's all wrong. Mr Juncker said that 36% of illegals are deported, pushed back - an astonishing number! In Germany it is around 5%. How Mr. Juncker gets 36% - I don't know. Refugees - this is being completely forgotten - only have temporary protection, a temporary right to stay, and if there is an opportunity to return in the states from which they come or to set up protection zones there so that they can return, then we must support that . That is what we should focus on. And of course I'm talking about Afghanistan and Syria. But, Mr Timmermans and the Council, keep talking about broadband expansion. Then we shall see how this Union develops. If you touch the right topics at some point, we may move forward. Not like that!

name: Nicolas Bay
text: , on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European summit which will take place soon will be an opportunity to deal with several major subjects which concern the nations of the European Union. I will start with the question of immigration. Mr Timmermans explains to us that he now wants to further strengthen Frontex. But Frontex is an illusion! A few weeks ago, I was in Warsaw where I visited the site of this agency. It was explained to us very well that, in the end, most of the work of the coast guards and border guards consisted of boarding the boats of illegal migrants to secure their approach in Italian territorial waters, before letting them settle in. the European continent. The European Union has never had the slightest will to prevent or curb illegal immigration. It has never implemented effective means to ensure the return to their country of origin of illegal immigrants. Moreover, today, when we talk about the issue of asylum, we are told that the rules must be harmonized, and this harmonization will obviously go in the direction of ever more flexible criteria, which make asylum today become a full fledged sector of illegal immigration. This allows millions of people to arrive on the European continent with no prospect of ever being deported. Moreover, what is very revealing in our debates is that we never mention the technical means that the European Union or the European nations could implement to organize the return of these migrants to their country of origin. 'origin. As far as defense is concerned, the permanent structured cooperation that you want to strengthen corresponds to a desire now displayed to suppress the sovereignty of nations. We know that there are considerable disparities between the different Member States, that some have ambitions and military forces, and others, much less. It is linked both to the history and to the unique capabilities of each nation. It is obvious that defense interests are totally different, sometimes divergent, and even contradictory. You have to accept it. And if we force harmonization or enhanced cooperation with a view to a hypothetical European defense, we will end up in the field of defense, as in all other fields, in the collective impotence of our nations. Digital is obviously a very important subject, but let's start by talking again about industrial issues. The European Union has no industrial strategy. We can clearly see with the Alstom-Siemens affair that we are subject both to American interests - Mr. Macron was in the front line to dismantle Alstom from part of its activities - and mainly today, to German interests, which are defended to the detriment of those of other nations. In economic matters, Mr Timmermans, you tell us that the recovery is there, which is false. The truth is, you only consider growth points and growth prospects. But growth is what you think of economics. It will perhaps be there, and undoubtedly in more limited proportions than you say it, but it relates to the financial economy, which does not necessarily correspond to an increase in employment, nor to a improvement in purchasing power. That is, the distortion will always be greater between your purely financial conception of the economy and the real economy, which itself continues to suffer. As for your desire for fiscal or social harmonization, this will again lead to a race to the bottom. When you look at the wage differences that exist between Eastern and Western Europe, this harmonization would obviously be disastrous. To conclude, I would like to respond to Mr Weber. Mr Weber, you present yourself as a great democrat, but suffer democracy, accept the verdict of the ballot box and respect the six million Germans who voted for our AfD allies.Respect the 90 members of this party in the Bundestag, who have said and still say clearly that they are tired of the crazy policy that you supported and that Mrs Merkel pursued, which consisted in organizing the migratory invasionfrom Europe.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, some of the speeches I have heard, whether they come from the Council, the Commission or other speakers, bring back old memories to me because I have been a Member of this institution for almost 28 years. I have heard for 28 years that when it comes to migration, we have to tackle the causes, but the problem is that we have never tackled the causes and that we will continue to not tackle it. What would it mean to "tackle the root causes" in the current situation? This would, for example, be dealing with the abominable regime in Eritrea, which forces the particularly male population of that country to come to Europe to escape military service for life. But for that, of course, we would have to enter into a relationship with the African Union. Tackling the causes would mean not giving up a large part of the Libyan coast to traffickers, but that would obviously require concerted action. It is not only, as the previous speaker excellently pointed out, sending boats to pick up potential migrants, after receiving a phone call from the traffickers indicating that the boat is two or three miles from the coast. , as a French admiral responsible for the European armed force on the spot told me personally. And to conclude, I still have a lot to say, Mr President, you have let the other speakers go over their speaking time. A word on foreign relations ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: - Mr President, dear Presidents, dear colleagues! It is good that the European Council will be talking about the future of the European Union in two weeks' time and that we do not only have to deal with current crises. We have to look ahead and say specifically what the European Union has to do. I say yes to a strong, efficient Europe where we need common solutions - in the fight against terrorism, in defense, in asylum and migration and in international trade. Yes, we need a common European asylum law, an effective border protection. We have to introduce biometrically secured identification documents and return refugees who have no right of residence, and we have to get involved in Africa too. I think it's very good that one of the priorities at the European Council is migration and asylum. I would like to remind colleagues on the right-hand side, who want to show us that we have not delivered anything, achieved nothing, once again, very clearly, with the figures. I don't even know why we're discussing when no one is listening. Both Vice-President Timmermans and the representative of the Council made it clear: 80% fewer refugees, less immigration than a year ago, two years ago. If that's not a success, then I have to ask myself the question: Where do we actually live? We fought the smugglers, we fought the people smugglers on site, dear colleagues. And if we talk to the African states, that is the right solution. That is not all easy and good, but - sorry - we are tackling this problem consistently together in Europe. I defend myself against these populists who claim that everything is crap, that nothing has been done. We can look to a certain extent with pride at what we do here in this house decided together.We are not at the end of the road yet, but we are on the right track.And I hope that the Council Summit will take decisive steps again in a fortnight.Yes, we solve our problems here in Europe together!That makes us strong, and that also gives me hope for the future in this common Europe.(The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- First a note: 80% success or 80% fewer migrants are very nice, but we assume a number of a million, so that leaves 200,000. That is probably a record year.Assuming there were ten million migrants, you would be 98% successful.So I wouldn't argue too much with the percentages.My question is: are you in favor of the European Union setting up camps and refugee centers outside the Union where asylum applications are processed?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I would like to point out that there are 30 seconds for such questions and 30 seconds for the answer.So that we stay on schedule, I'll keep to that strictly without further knocking.Mr Sulík, it is of course not possible for you to spend 24 of these 30 seconds making a statement.These blue cards are for questions, not statements.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Europe is based on common principles of the rule of law, and in contrast to others, I am of the opinion that anyone who can claim the right to asylum can also make use of it and is also welcome here in Europe.Regarding your specific question: We have to resolve the issue of refugees and migration at the external borders, and if we - as shown - manage to set up transit centers here in African states, then I believe that is the right way to go.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the time to wait is over. This is the time to deliver. Mr Verhofstadt is no longer here, but I would like to pick up the issue he raised. We do have a road map for the European Union, and we could force this road map through cooperation between the three institutions. Recently, three speeches of three leaders – Juncker, Macron and Antonio Costa – have showed important overlaps from different political sensitivities. This means something, but let me be clear about the real meaning of delivery. If we want to deliver on the migration crisis once and for all, we need to prepare a much stronger partnership for African development, and we need to create a real European asylum agency. If you want to deliver better social equality in Europe in this digital age, we need to have a strong pillar to ensure that everybody in employment can count on a decent labour contract and access to social protection. If you want to close these divergences which we still have in Europe, you need to have a community budget and a Eurozone budget working for convergence. And finally, if you come with the argument that we don’t have the money for this, I’m sorry. The money is there if you add taxation properly on big corporations which are operating in the single market and benefiting from it, particularly in the digital economy. So we have the solutions; we need to start delivering, and the next European council should be a step for this.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
text: - Mr President! I would like the Council to take advantage of this relatively good economic situation in the European Union and less politicization after the big elections, but in order not to be mistaken, it is often necessary to admit mistakes that have been made. On migration. In order for you to be able to develop a new migration policy, you must, of course, acknowledge the mistakes that have been made, and if we look at the European Commission's press release, it is said that 23,000 asylum seekers have found a home in the European Union as a result of resettlement. It is not true! In my country, Latvia, everyone who came to Latvia in this resettlement scheme is away from Latvia, and this has happened in many countries. Consequently, it must be acknowledged that it does not work in that way. I wish Mr Maasika and the Estonian Presidency the continuation of the fifth freedom: the introduction of data flow while it is still possible. And finally, I was very surprised by what Mr Timmermans read that Europe protects its citizens. It sounds a little unbelievable on the streets of Barcelona today.

name: Sophia in ’t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the biggest threat to Europe at the moment is not migration or terrorism. The biggest threat to the European Union is paralysis, stagnation and a lack of courage. There are plenty of good ideas on the table, but there is little progress. The biggest test will be to see if the European Union is willing and able to uphold its own values, which we have laid down in the Treaties, when they are under pressure. Some grand visions for the future have been laid out by Mr Juncker, Mr Macron and others, and some react by saying these are too romantic: if you have vision you need to see an eye doctor, it is unrealistic, it is a fantasy. I actually think it is totally unrealistic to imagine we can tackle the challenges of the 21st century with a model that was perfect for the 19th century but is totally unsuitable for the world of today. I think that is a fantasy and that is unrealistic. (Applause) Finally, on migration, I hear what the Council is saying but Parliament has been doing its homework on the asylum package. We are waiting for ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, on October 1 the desire of Catalonia to decide its future in freedom and without locks was clearly and forcefully shown.The Government's response was overwhelming: police violence and violation of fundamental rights in the European Union, with the sole purpose that Catalans could not vote, demonstrating a very worrying authoritarian drift.The Government and its allies have consistently refused to offer a democratic and peaceful solution to the people of Catalonia.This is no longer just a question of "independence yes or no", but of "democracy and civil liberties yes or no".Europe has to take sides, defending the legitimate decisions of the people of Catalonia, opening a dialogue between equals, without repression and without locks, to build a free, democratic and supportive coexistence.If the European institutions do not take sides for dialogue, they will become part of the problem.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, sitting in the next European Council there will be a Member State President who has become a real problem and a source of shame for Europe. I am talking about Mr Rajoy, who is violating fundamental rights and European values in Catalonia. Last Sunday, he went as far as to order the Spanish police to repress, with dreadful violence, peaceful crowds who just wanted to vote. More than 800 citizens, voters, were injured by the Spanish police as a result of this irresponsible action. Mr Timmermans, you are doing a great job when trying to defend fundamental rights in the European Union. Will you ask Mr Rajoy on what grounds did he violate the European Charter of Fundamental Rights? Will you help us to get mediation to resolve the situation in a democratic and peaceful way? When are you going to trigger Article 7?  If the European institutions keep saying that it is all about the law and nothing but the law, that it is an internal matter, you will deserve the world record for turning Catalan pro-European citizens into eurosceptics. Against all the difficulties and despite all the state repression, we voted, and we voted to be free. So, as we say in Catalan: visca Catalunya lliure!  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: blue card question.- To Mr. Solé, I would ask: your mouth fills with freedom, with democracy ... Do you think that giving a coup in a country, going against the Constitution of this country, going against the laws ofthis country is freedom?Is that democracy, on the part of the secessionists, that you are supporting in Catalonia, Mr. Solé?

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" response.- Coups are given by the military, not the voters, not the votes, not the ballot box.We defend fundamental freedoms, the freedoms of the citizens of Catalonia, who are also citizens of the European Union.Voting is not giving any coup.Voting is democracy.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: - In the wake of Sunday's violence in Catalonia, it would be not only stupid but also blasphemous to talk about the issues scheduled for the regular Council meeting. It’s as if we’re pretending nothing happened. I believe that both we in the European Parliament and the Council should speak first on the issue of democracy, starting with how we understand it. Photos from Catalonia have shown the world a different, hitherto unusual, picture of democracy. Twisted faces, people injured by rubber bullets, women being pulled behind hair. For wanting to exercise one of its fundamental freedoms, the instrument of democracy is a referendum. The actions in Catalonia are in clear violation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the Public Declaration of Human Rights, the European Convention on Human Rights and many other norms of international law. I will still dare to ask how it differs from 1956. In Hungary, since 1968. In Czechoslovakia, since 1988. In Lithuania and since 1989. In Georgia, when the police and army raised peoples seeking democracy, freedom and independence with bananas, spades and tanks. In view of the situation regarding the actions of the Spanish Government ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Let us not forget that we are in the midst of the main and key debate, debating the upcoming Council meeting. The topic that should move Europe the most is not on the agenda: the referendum in Catalonia. I do not want to judge the constitutional side here because it would be far too complex and there is no time for it. But when 900 people in the heart of Europe are prevented with rubber truncheons and rubber bullets from making a declaration of intent, then I say: Then there will be a fire on the roof and urgent action must be taken. The fact that the European Parliament, which is always the first to condemn something, always speaks up on something, does not want to raise its voice here and postpone a debate about it into the afternoon hours, that is not okay! What is on the Council's agenda, however, is the issue of Turkey. Erdoğan in particular, who is now saying that he no longer wants to join the European Union, is still not reason enough for you to finally break off this debate. We wasted over five billion getting them to Turkey in the face of a catastrophic human rights and democracy situation. Finish this game with Turkey and finish accession negotiations.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I would like to point out that I will not allow blue cards if I have denied the floor of the respective speaker because the speaking time has been exceeded.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: - Mr President, rivalries and compromises between states and monopolies, escalation of anti-popular aggression and European Union intervention, everywhere with victims and refugees for their profits, mark every Summit. Popular discontent is growing in the Greece of the memoranda; but also in France of the "reformer" Macron, reminding that the European Union is changing, but only for the worse; in the elections of rich Germany, where the KKE is confirmed: capitalist development is built with popular sacrifices in Catalonia with barbaric repression where nationalisms on both sides are sparked by a clash of sections of capital. The European Union's concern for the cohesion of states is à la carte. She challenges it elsewhere by inciting dangerous border changes (see Balkans, Middle East). But popular discontent, expressed either by nationalisms or by far-right groups such as the AfD in Germany, is trapped in the interests of other sections of capital, equally unpopular. To be effective: it must aim at the heart of the "beast": the power of capital and its overthrow.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! The agenda of the nearest Council is varied. It's hard to say in a minute or two, but it's easy to see that the Council will deal with both the greatest challenge of today, which is migration, and the greatest opportunity, which is the digital single market globally. Migration is very divisive, gives rise to tensions and controversies. On the other hand, the single digital market is indisputable, uncontroversial. Of course, all simplifications are confusing, because although the digital revolution is inevitable, the different levels of advancement of the member states can create or deepen a multi-speed Union in an economic sense. On the other hand, migration, of course, divides and creates tensions, but if we are talking about relocation systems - it is a sad thing for me, from the Solidarity generation, from the country of millions of refugees and emigrants, when I see the behavior of some governments in this matter. On the other hand, if we look at the agenda of the nearest Council, we do not see any great controversies or disputes here, these are common issues, those elements that will be discussed at the nearest Council: stopping illegal immigration routes, additional tools for helping countries most at risk, cooperation with international organizations, cooperation with the countries of origin of immigrants or refugees and transit countries, and finally the reform of the asylum system. These are the common goals of Europe and, in addition, in the area where the greatest fears arise, in which today we most need security in Europe, and it turns out that the tools of individual countries are insufficient. A European response must be sought, and this is where the dispute between European factions and European populism and xenophobia will be resolved. So good wishes for this part of the agenda of the nearest Council are to be wished.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Schengen is the largest free travel area in the world and it is one of the major achievements of the European Union. It is an achievement that should be preserved, notably by including all Member States that wish to be integrated, if they already fulfil the criteria. Unity is the most important element of the future of our Union. The Union today faces common cross-border challenges and threats, and it is of the utmost importance further to enhance police and judicial cooperation and to protect the external border of the Union more effectively. Therefore, I welcome the Commission communication last week, drawing conclusions from the implementation of the ‘Back to Schengen’ road map and proposing new steps for strengthening the Schengen area. If we want to strengthen the Schengen area and to enhance security cooperation and mutual trust between Member States, then it is more important than ever to open the Schengen area to Bulgaria and Romania immediately, as the Commission had proposed, and to Croatia once it has met all the criteria. I call on the Council to act immediately on this proposal. Moreover, real progress in the fight against terrorism can be achieved only by working together towards effective security and defence cooperation and a Union in which both the external and internal dimensions are important. Therefore, I call for the immediate implementation of a consistent package for permanent structured cooperation (PESCO).

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: - Mister President! Certainly a clear shot across the EU's bow. My hope that Strasbourg will use the UK referendum as an opportunity to question what went wrong has not been fulfilled. Instead, they want to use the supposed opportunity to install a central European state. That is why I am particularly surprised at the reluctance of my German colleagues in the Bundestag election campaign. If you are so convinced of the correctness of a European unemployment insurance, dear comrades from the SPD, why have you not dealt aggressively with it in the last few weeks? And if you are convinced of the lack of alternatives to European finance ministers, European taxes and European centralism, dear comrades from the CDU and CSU, dear Mr Weber, why did you not make this an issue in the federal election campaign? I am afraid because you realize that you cannot win elections in Germany with these points. That is why it is unfair what you are doing here in Strasbourg, namely to support a transfer union without informing the German voters about your plans and the consequences.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, the European Union is a necessary reality among nations that, after centuries of fratricidal wars, understood that the path was peace, union in democracy. And there is no democracy without law, and the law, the Constitution, is the pillar that guarantees our rights, our freedom, that all opinions have their place in dialogue and not in confrontation. Violating the Constitution is violating democracy, the values ​​of the European Union and Article 4 of the Union Treaty, which determines respect for the constitutional order and territorial integrity. In Catalonia, a parliamentary majority, but a minority in votes, has violated the Statute of Autonomy and the Spanish Constitution, in sectarian irresponsibility to try to achieve its objectives, fracturing Catalan society in two. Hans Kensel, the benchmark of constitutionalism, defined as a coup the subversion of the constitutional order outside the legally established channels. This is what happened in Catalonia, and Catalonia is not only on Sunday: fundamentally it is before and after October 1. It is not only an attack against democracy in Spain, it is also against the European Union: it is a Pandora's box.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, in the Spanish State the regime of 78 is sinking. All three of his legs break. On Sunday it was demonstrated that the State of Autonomies does not respond to the aspirations of millions of Catalans. Yesterday we saw a more stale and dangerous monarchy than ever, and the economic system only generates unemployment and poverty. The Popular Party wants to resuscitate the regime with "Arriba España", "Viva la Guardia Civil", taking the Bourbon out for a walk and with blows. And for this, as for almost everything, it has the invaluable collaboration of the Socialist Party and a European Union designed so that nothing changes and that, even today, has not condemned the extreme violence of the Spanish security forces. Sunday in Catalonia. There is no solution with Mariano Rajoy in Moncloa, and that is why we say: "Rajoy, resign." But let's go further: there is no solution with this regime. That Catalonia is the beginning of the end of the monarchy and that it opens the doors to a new territorial model, but, above all, that Catalonia is what the Catalans want it to be. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question.- Mrs. Albiol, when you talk about the '78 regime, are you talking about this?Are you talking about the 1978 Constitution?From the Constitution that we Spaniards vote mostly, especially in Catalonia, and for which we gave ourselves as a political form a parliamentary monarchy, whose head of state is the king?Are you talking about this regime?Are you talking about the democratic transition after 40 years of Franco?Please explain to me what you are talking about when you refer to this regime.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response.- Yes, I am talking about the 78 regime, the heir to Franco regime, a monarchy that we have not voted for.No one has chosen that man.We have not been able to vote and, furthermore, the Government of Spain has always refused a referendum on monarchy or republic.The Constitution has already been shown to expire.Let's go to a constitutional process and let's go to a federal republic.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, gentlemen of the Council, Mr Timmermans, you cannot fail to see what is happening in Catalonia. Yesterday, many people returned to the streets peacefully to denounce the violence and to ask to be heard. You must listen to them. I have to tell you: you must condemn the acts of violence that occurred. The police action had a court order, but the operation of the Ministry of the Interior violated fundamental rights recognized in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and you have to say something, you must. Look, they have to be very aware of the current situation. If you do not intervene - which is what you should do - if there is no dialogue, we are going to a very, very worrying situation. At this time, we can go to a unilateral declaration of independence - which is surely a mistake, but which will lead to more repression by the State - or we can open avenues for dialogue. Mr Timmermans, I ask you on behalf of many Catalans who are worried today at home to open up avenues for negotiation and dialogue. It is urgent, because this, Mr Timmermans, is also a European issue. Please intervene, facilitate dialogue and respond to what the Catalans are asking for these days.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE).
text: - Mister President!The rules of procedure provide that the speakers have to comment on the item on the agenda.There will be a debate this afternoon on what is being raised by many here.But the Council's agenda does not include this issue, which many are talking about here.So maybe it wouldn't be bad if we made sure that we focus on the agenda.That is just a suggestion for the colleagues who will be speaking soon.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Graf Lambsdorff!I discussed the matter with President Tajani.You are of course right on the one hand, and on the other hand everyone can claim that this topic will of course also shape the upcoming summit, and that is why our colleagues will refer to it.I will therefore not intervene.Your colleagues should still hear your suggestion.But I will be very careful to ensure that interim questions are also interim questions and not interim statements, and otherwise I will be very careful to ensure that speaking time is respected and, moreover, treat everyone equally.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: - Mr President! The point for the forthcoming Council meeting that must be at the center is, of course, the events in Catalonia and the late action of the Commission. We all saw the pictures on TV and in newspapers where Spanish military police with indiscriminate brutality beat and kicked people, both young and old, until the blood flowed. This is happening in an EU country and where democracy is expected to be the guiding light. It is nothing but a pure shame, what has happened, and the Commission's fear and cowardice in criticizing Spain for this brutal violence is embarrassing to see. Of course, respect for the Spanish Constitution must be respected, but the Commission must strongly condemn the total lack of respect for people and the brutal violence used. I just heard Mr Weber say that dissenters must be fought. You then chose to use the word extremists about the people who do not share your views. Most federalists in this House use the same message. If I were to use the same rhetoric of the people who do not share my views, I would stand here and call all of you extremists. You have completely misunderstood what democracy is all about. Democracy means that you must be able to listen to the arguments even from those with whom you do not share opinions.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have once again heard general words about terrorism and immigration which are completely inconclusive. Instead, this forthcoming Council, which takes place a few hours after the events in Catalonia, excludes this topic from discussions. The leader of the liberal group said that every month a reflection on Europe and on the future of Europe must be made. The debate of these moments is a debate on the future of Europe because it sees, on the one hand - that is, all of us who were fascists, undemocrats, etc. - all aligned in favor of the Catalan people, or at least of their legitimate desire to be able to vote and, on the other hand, the exponents of the super socialist and popular party that governs this Europe of bureaucrats, banks and multinationals, which instead supports a police action. A police that would do well to continue dealing with terrorism, perhaps even illegal immigrants, instead of beating up - as I have seen myself - quiet people, without party flags, who have been in the rain for hours in order to exercise their right to vote. Then it is clear which side ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, there is so much talk in this House about European values, so now it is time to act. Mr Timmermans, may I ask you please to make a statement – and the European Council should also make a similar statement soon – that mass police violence against unarmed people does not pass the human rights law tests of necessity and proportionality. It violates European values and norms and, under no circumstances, can it be tolerated by the European Union. You must make such a statement, regardless of who you think is right. Whether the Catalonian people are right or the Spanish government is right, no justification can be made for this brutal violence. Please make such a statement if you want the European Union and its values to be taken seriously.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to express, of course, our solidarity with the families of the victims of the vile attack on Marseilles and the terrible slaughter in Las Vegas. More than ever, the fight against terrorism and the eradication of Daesh must be the subject of a European strategy. At the next European Council, heads of state and government will assess the progress of the Brexit negotiations. There is nothing tangible about the British position today, we reiterated this in our resolution yesterday. Such a negotiation is obviously not easy, especially since we have on one side the Europeans, led by our negotiator, Michel Barnier, who adopts a sequenced and serious approach, and on the other, no clear commitment and Ms. May's cipher. Great British statements and reversals mask the scale of the difficulties the UK exit is causing. The British message started out: "We will do better alone than with you". Now Mrs May proposes to copy European methods, for example, in trade agreements. What a tribute to Europe! Both tactically and technically, we remain steadfast about the need for a divorce before stabilizing a relationship in the future. To move Europe forward, you have to have a method and not be in the mantra. Recently, the French president has shown that he wants a European policy that can be decreed, by recycling ideas on which we are working or even proposals already implemented: fight against social dumping and unfair competition with the revision the Posting of Workers Directive; security with mechanisms to strengthen border controls that we have voted for; protection of our industry with the agreement reached yesterday - we talked about it earlier - on the new anti-dumping methodology. This is one more step for a Europe which acts and, above all, which protects its interests.Finally, we are now being presented with transnational electoral lists as a remedy for the lack of support for the European project, but it will have the opposite effect.To account for our action to Europeans, we need an everyday Europe that is not that of elected representatives above ground, but that of representatives who know the reality of the territories.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Mister President! When the heads of state and government are discussing migration and displacement again this time, it is reminiscent of a regular déjà vu: resolutions loudly trumpeted to do everything better now, big plans and expectations. The progress is admittedly little. On the positive side, perhaps: to finally seriously consider resettlement. I find it alarming that we obviously haven't learned anything. The UN announced yesterday that it would cut food rations in Kenyan refugee camps by 30%. Incredible! Nobody will notice until it's too late again. I would like to remind you of what Mrs Merkel said at one of these summits at the height of the refugee crisis on September 25, 2015: we have all failed to see that the international programs are not adequately financed, that people in refugee camps are starving, that food rations are being cut . This time we could see it!

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: - I had prepared a lot about the many digital challenges facing Europe, but today I cannot help but strongly condemn the European Union's long silence on the violence we all witnessed on Sunday.Violence can never be the solution to political conflict, never.I therefore call for a dialogue between Madrid and Barcelona with international mediation.Commissioner Timmermans, you have human rights in your portfolio.Surely you cannot but condemn a Member State that uses violence and shoots at its own citizens?

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE).
text: - Mister President! I became a member here in this House in 2004 when the Balts and the Poles, the Czechs and the Slovaks, the Hungarians became members of the European Union. For me it is still a miracle that we live united with one another on a free continent in unity and freedom and peace, whereby unity clearly does not mean unity on every topic. Whether it's migration or market economy, energy policy or expansion, there are sometimes very different approaches between East and West, between North and South. One thing is important to me: that we do not deny respect to one another in all debates that we have here, that we also listen to other opinions - no matter what the issues. I am pleased that the European Union has now received a new impetus from the speeches by Jean-Claude Juncker, but especially by Emmanuel Macron, and I will continue to work for the European Union - soon from the German Parliament. This is my last speech after 13 years. Thank you very much for your cooperation. I will never forget that as a young German MP I was able to work here with a man like Bronisław Geremek. It was a very moving experience. I thank all my colleagues very much and say goodbye. Thank you very much! (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Graf Lambsdorff!All the best for your work in a new position in the new parliament!

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the international parliamentary delegation in which I participated considers that the referendum was a demonstration of the determination of the Catalan people regarding the right to vote and the democratic process, and urges the European Union to take into account the result . But the Commission says it is an internal matter. No longer. It is already a European issue, and we are seeing it clearly here. Don't hide behind the law. The stubborn defense of the Constitution has led one member state to violence. Here is a fundamental political problem that is not new and must be faced. The Spanish Government is not going to do it. Don't make the same mistake and take action. Voting is a democratic exercise, and there are peoples within their geopolitical map that we want to be free, simply because we feel that way. We do not ask that you understand it, but we do ask that you respect it. To the Catalan people and its politicians, thank you for your lesson in dignity and courage. You have the support and solidarity of the Basque people, and we will soon follow the same path. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question.- Mr Juaristi, it is surprising that you give any meaning of democracy to anyone, when your party has not yet fully condemned the political violence that they commanded in the Basque Country.You speak of the Basque people, on behalf of those who are like you and those who are not.You cannot claim to represent the entire Basque people.You are against the law.The law is the foundation of this Parliament, the rule of law.And the order of the factors alters the product.(The President cut off the speaker)

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response.- I want to address the Commission, Mr Timmermans, to see that this is a truly European problem.Please take action.Take action.Do not think that it is an internal matter of the Spanish State.This needs a solution, it needs a political solution and it needs European involvement.Please take action.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: In the future, I will take the liberty of interrupting the questioner if it is not a question.And if the person who is asked does not answer, then I will allow myself to interrupt the answer.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: - Herr Präsident, Herr Vizepräsident der Kommission Timmermans, Vertreter des Rates! Das Thema Migration ist ein ganz wichtiges. Ich weekend is gut, dass is das nächste Bad wieder auf der Tagesordnung des Rates steht. Was wir aber brauchen, sind endlich legale Zugänge in die Europäische Union, zum Beispiel über Botschaftsasyl und Solidarität innerhalb der Mitgliedstaaten. Was ich aber auch ansprechen möchte: Es ist völlig inakzeptabel, dass auf dieser Tagesordnung des nächsten Rates das brutale Vorgehen der spanischen Polizei in Katalonien am letzten Wochenende einfach nicht einmal vorgesehen ist. And I will switch to Spanish now. After the Spanish Government has refused to speak and the brutal actions of the police last Sunday, I ask you that the Commission offer Catalonia and the Government of Madrid a mediation, to start a dialogue, to return to the table to talk. In particular, I ask the members of the EPP Group, the European People's Party, no longer to say that this is an internal matter for Spain: within the European Union there are no internal affairs; within the European Union that does not work. We are all European. There must be dialogue and a practical solution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the number one point on the agenda of this Council is emigration: in the face of the enormous efforts of Italy and Greece, a decision on redistribution is not yet applied, which has also been confirmed by the Court of justice of the Union.
