The common asylum system is still very far from what it should be, that is, a real compulsory, preventive and permanent redistribution mechanism, to ensure that solidarity is not just a chat. The shameful conditions of the Libyan camps are bad for our democracy: we strongly believe that there is monitoring, an intervention by the United Nations and the European Union to recognize what unfortunately is on the ground, namely kidnappings, rape, slavery , rapes, including on pregnant women, and torture. All of this is unacceptable. We also expect that, when we talk about Turkey, we finally acknowledge that the path chosen by Erdogan is very far from what the rule of law should be and from the fundamental principles of the Union and that the negotiations of adhesion, which increasingly resemble a farce in which the protagonists no longer even believe.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: - As regards the measures to control illegal migration flows, I would like to remind the heads of government that the deployment of, for example, Belgian naval ships should no longer serve to facilitate illegal migration, but rather should be aimed at preventing and preventing people from entering a start a dangerous crossing. The starting point must be that asylum seekers are received in their own region. Reception in your own region leads to more efficient use of available resources and therefore makes it easier to return to your own country. More pressure should be put on third countries that do not cooperate in curbing illegal migration. Development aid and partnerships must be linked to the willingness of these countries to take back rejected asylum seekers and illegal immigrants. Today, people in Flanders survive who have worked all their lives with a gross pension of 1100 or even sometimes barely 900 euros, while an average of 1300 euros per month must be made available for the reception of an asylum seeker. Chairman, the money is gone. Time for an immigration stop.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, today my heart is in Spain. That is why I have written my speech, so as not to get excited. In a few hours or days, a region of Spain, which has never been independent, will unilaterally, illegally and forcibly declare its independence. I don't know if you are fully aware of that. The images of Sunday hurt us all, yes. However, I beg you not to stop there, when there are 48 hours until the second largest country in Europe, my country, can be broken in half. Spain is not Yugoslavia. We are a stable and mature democracy, as stable and as mature as any of those represented here, and we do not need tutelage and we do not need mediators with insurgent politicians. Are we going to dialogue? Yes, under the mantle of the Constitution. Can our Constitution be changed? Yes, but not by force. Deciding whether Spain breaks down or remains united corresponds to all Spaniards and only to Spaniards. As the King said last night, we are not going to leave the Catalans alone. We are not going to leave alone those who, out of fear of stigma, remain silent and did not participate in the false referendum. And neither to those who, in good faith, came to vote on Sunday, whom I cannot and do not want to ignore. All Catalans are Spanish and all Catalans are my compatriots. But make no mistake: the problem of national-populism is not unique to Spain. It is a plague that spreads across Europe. If today you let Spain break through Catalonia, a row of dominoes will follow you across the continent. Instead of a Europe of 27 we will have a 'non-Europe' of mini-states. Nationalism is historically the cause of Europe's pain. As Europeanists, do not agree with the national-populists. Yesterday marked the 30th anniversary of German reunification. Now it is Spain that is fighting to remain united. It is now Spain who has to dialogue with Spain, no one else. I finish: do not point us, support us as we once supported Germany, the Baltic republics or Eastern Europe.Europe is made to unite not to break.(Applause)

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I was going to talk about another topic, but the way in which the Spanish / Catalan issue was approached here obliges me - by an imperative of conscience - to say the following: it is infamous to establish any comparison between democratic Spain and a way any dictatorship. Spain has made an exemplary path, an exemplary democratic transition. It went from Francoism to a democratic regime, a regime that, in fact, enshrines autonomies practically unparalleled in the European framework. I am not Spanish. I am Portuguese, but at the moment I feel obliged, in the name of defending European values, to make this clear statement here: Spain is a great democratic country and must and must be treated in this Parliament as such. The Catalan issue exists naturally and I hope that, with consensus and dialogue, it can be resolved and we are all aware of what is going on. Now that does not authorize anyone to question the great democracy that is Spanish democracy.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: - Mr. President! They can be set up, but in the frame my blue card does not go to a single statute where you can react to a direct reaction to the woman. And the discussion follows that you should be there. Mr President, please allow me to make a few remarks on the latest European proposals from French President Emmanuel Macron. I am a little surprised by these proposals, because I thought he was elected to solve France's problems. Firstly, I consider his proposals to be socialist, because they are based on, firstly, higher taxes, secondly, more redistribution, thirdly, new offices. Furthermore, it is largely a matter of debt socialization, namely that Germany share France's debts. On the contrary, I would like to express my appreciation for President Macron's proposal that the European Union finally set up refugee, migrant camps outside the European Union. However, I consider the most important question with which mandate President Macron ... (interrupted after one minute)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Sulík, you no longer have the floor.And your verbose explanations that it wasn't a statement before are nice, and it's especially nice that you do that in German, but it's just not applicable.If you want to make debates more lively, then you can do that, there are many possibilities, but not by systematically pushing some of the limits of the rules and beyond.And if you think that what you said about my decision was a statement and that it will be deducted from your speaking time, then you are wrong.On the agenda.Please, Mr. Sulík.That would have been the right way.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: - Mister President!(The speaker speaks without a microphone.)… Please which one?I get a minute or two speaking time a month.This is the first.Now and then a blue card.I reacted very specifically to Ms. Niebler's speech - for discussion.I have not made any statements of my own and have not abused any rules here.And maybe the speaking time could be a little longer.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr. Sulík!Firstly, I recommend that you try to give your group more speaking time.The same rules apply to everyone here.And secondly, try to get the representatives of your group in the AFCO committee to think about changes to the rules of procedure and how to make debates more lively.But the rule that only Mr Sulík is helped does not exist, and there will not be.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, the migration crisis, the threat of global terrorism, the problems that hinder the unity of the digital transport or energy markets are real, pressing problems, which have their logical place in the next European Council. And I am going to ask you, in line with the letter that the president of my country - the Lehendakari Iñigo Urkullu - sent yesterday to the president of the Commission Jean-Claude Juncker, to include the problem in Catalonia on the agenda, because the stability of a Member State is at stake and, consequently, that of the Union itself. We are Europeanists, we believe in the values ​​of the founding fathers and we are very concerned that silence, blockade or violence are not solutions to tackle a problem that can only be tackled through politics. We talk about fundamental rights. After the Second World War, the rulers of the powers that faced each other on the battlefield were able to found this project that unites us in our diversity. That first agreement, which gave rise to the CECA, was not built by exchanging reproaches and wielding the limits of the law, but by listening, understanding the other and building with him. Please encourage this way of doing to be applied to the solution of this problem.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Spain is not willing to dialogue, we saw you again yesterday with the King's message. That is why I ask the European Union with a high view, to ensure respect for the fundamental rights of the European Union and human rights, which have been violated in Catalonia. And this is not said by me, it is said by the international team of experts in electoral research. I read verbatim: “We are witnessing events that no election observer should ever witness, and we hope we will never witness scenes of this nature again. We see numerous and repeated violations of civil and human rights. Furthermore, it is clear since it was a carefully planned, military-style, orchestrated core operation. We are astonished that armed and masked officers entered the polling stations with the purpose of preventing a peaceful democratic process. That, he also says, calls for the process to be respected. Consenting more repression on the Catalan people and its institutions will only provoke more disaffection.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the promise of the European Union is the unconditional validity of fundamental rights, including freedom of speech. It is the Commission and the Council’s responsibility to uphold these values when they are threatened inside the EU, and this is not an internal matter. This week, the front pages show images of charges of Spanish police in Catalan schools. Another serious form of repression took place in the weeks leading up to this weekend. Spanish police raided the registrar of the Internet domain ‘.cat’. Its CTO, Pep Masoliver, was held for more than 60 hours and is now facing criminal prosecution. More than 140 domains were blocked and a number of domains were seized, including websites run by civil society organisations. These measures are counterproductive; they undermine freedom of speech and they set a dangerous precedent for a Europe that wants to be a champion of digital rights. The European institutions should immediately offer intermediation to help de-escalate the situation, and I call upon both sides of the conflict to accept such an offer and refrain from further steps that would escalate the situation. It should be on the top of every agenda, including the European Council meeting.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me a small premise: a debate has entered in a violent and instrumental way which should be held this afternoon. I find it scandalous that there is that part of the extreme left that exploits, in an ideological way, a real suffering, a drama. We must be facilitators of dialogue. Shame on you! You are an ideological and undemocratic side. We must foster dialogue in favor of a whole people, the Spanish one. We all want to offer solidarity to this great people, who will surely find their way and the way out in dialogue, harmony, peace, democracy, respect for human rights and respect for the rule of law. Shame! And now let's go back to the Council. So, we must work for a stronger, more democratic Europe, as you said, dear Vice-President, we agree, we are all here, we have this task. There are many signs, including positive ones: we must strengthen them and work on them. There is no doubt that the first condition is safety. And it is precisely for this reason that we have always been, as a political party, in favor of a common European defense. Only if Europe has its own foreign policy, its own common policy, will not only be able to better defend its citizens, but will finally be able to play a geopolitical role as awaits us, sitting among the great of the earth, and not like today, which we are a little - many times, not always - following, falling back, in tow or reacting. No: we are a great history, a great civilization! With our values ​​we must take our rightful place in the world. We still have an open wound, as Weber said, which is immigration. I too want to thank what the whole Parliament, with Mr Cicu, has done in putting these anti-dumping rules in place, because we need a common industrial policy to solve the unemployment problem, especially youth.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: - (NL) Mr Chairman, I first have a question for you as chairman.Today's agenda is the debate on the European Council.I hear one speech after another about Catalonia here and I think Catalonia is very important, but that is on the agenda this afternoon.So I would like to call for us today to debate what is on the agenda now, and that is the European Council.And there are important things on it.I now hear a lady calling for European defense.I am pleased that the EPP is finally also following the ALDE position on this.But I do not hear you say anything about the necessity of a migration pact.That is priority one.I think that we as a Union must act strongly.One European asylum application, strict surveillance of the external borders and above all: tackling human smugglers.I want it to be about that.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs Vautmans!I have now understood your intervention not as a question to Mrs Gardini, but as an intervention on the rules of procedure.That's why I gave you more than 30 seconds.We cannot mix and match at will.If you had listened to my answer to Mr Lambsdorff beforehand, you would perhaps already know that I discussed this with the President and that, even if it is not on the agenda, it will certainly be discussed at the summit and I willindividual colleagues cannot restrict the freedom of their mandate to set priorities here in the context of this debate.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: - Mister President!Challenge: refugees!Some rely on foreclosure at all costs.Real solutions look different.Three key points: Firstly, protect fewer refugees in Europe and protect European values, i.e. combat the causes of flight, strengthen countries of origin and transit countries so that they too can offer protection and new perspectives.Second, fast and transparent asylum procedures as well as agreements with countries of origin, withdrawal of rejected asylum seekers.Third, clear routes for labor migration, combined with rules to prevent wage and social dumping.By the way, many say: We would like to help real refugees.Amazing how low the numbers of resettlement are then!Walls are not a solution.Let's face this challenge boldly and together!

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, in my capacity as rapporteur for the reform of the Dublin Regulation, I am convinced that this House is about to find a common position, gathering broad support for backing bold, ambitious and realistic reforms. However, we need our counterparts in the Council – and I would ask them to stop pandering back to domestic egoism – to engage with us in building a common European asylum system which is fit for purpose. For too long, the Council has tried to find unanimity. Instead, it should try to find solutions to fix the broken, collapsed common European asylum system. Now it is high time to find solutions, and also one position. To the Estonian Presidency, I would like to say: stand firm. Knowing some Member States, you will never find unanimity, but a qualified majority is perfectly good enough, according to the Treaties. In my negotiating team, we are determined. We need to find a solution based on the fair sharing of responsibilities, aiming at taking back European control of migratory flows and ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I see that the Council intends to discuss the EU’s external relations at its next meeting. You guys have some nerve! You plan to lecture others on human rights while you sit on your hands while witnessing a vicious assault on peaceful EU citizens in Catalonia because they had the audacity to vote. The truth is that European leaders have disgracefully ignored thuggish human rights abuses that are happening within the EU. While this inaction on Catalonia continues, you have lost the right to lecture others. Let’s be clear, nobody, not a non-elected king, not a non-elected Commission, not even a minority government in Madrid, has the right to declare illegal the democratic exercise on self-determination by a people.  We are told that the EU stands for peace, democracy and human rights. Where were those values on Sunday? If you dare to use the Council meeting to talk about peace or democracy without standing clearly for those values in Catalonia, then the people of Europe, the people of the world, will rightly consider you to be nothing more than a shower of utter hypocrites.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: - President! All the topics for the Council meeting in two weeks' time are very important. Let me reflect on these. With regard to the migration situation, I would like to emphasize that a successful immigration policy can only be pursued on the basis of the views of European citizens. We Hungarians reject an unrestricted immigration policy. There is a need for effective but strict border protection, for assistance to persecuted locally, for controlled protocols that focus only on real refugees. Economic migrants must be returned to their country of origin as soon as possible, in accordance with the will of the taxpayers. I would like to refer to the recently adopted Ukrainian Education Law, which unacceptably undermines the right to use the language of the Hungarian, Slovak, Romanian and Polish national minorities living in Transcarpathia. I very much hope that the European Council will address this deeply infringing situation at its meeting and send a clear signal to the Ukrainian authorities. With regard to Digital Europe, I would like to emphasize that this can only be successful if services are accessible. The first reading of the accessibility package was adopted by the European Parliament last month, at its September part-session, so I ask the Presidency-in-Office to adopt their position as soon as possible so that the trialogue can begin as soon as possible.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the Estonian Presidency is already associated with a very positive digital image. You are a country of digital excellence, and you will be bringing this theme to the European Council, which I congratulate you on. But you have to do this in an inclusive way, as we like to say here. So you cannot wait until the last moment to deal with the social dimension of the digital universe. What does that mean? Our colleague Kósa has just spoken of accessibility, but there is also the question of the status of workers in the digital field, and from this point of view, access to protection, to the portability of rights, training, the possibility of leading collective claims, is a new challenge for social law that you must also tackle. Then, of course, there will be no social justice for digital workers if there is not an adapted tax system and, from this point of view, the initiatives which are launched here and there, a little in disorder, must not undermine the real reform of modernity in the fiscal field, which is that of corporate tax. No other ... (The President cut off the speaker).

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Minister, colleagues, I would like to dwell briefly on the three topics that the Council will be discussing: digitalisation, migration, defense and external relations. Digital technologies are the future if we want to have a competitive European economy on our continent, and it must guarantee better and more accurate content, cybersecurity and personal data protection, as well as the big issue of eHealth. However, when the Council pays attention to the topic of migration, let it stop talking, action is needed. The return of illegally staying and entering the European Union is a priority. For years, we have only heard talk about reforms in the Dublin Agreement, not action. Enough hypocrisy regarding the admission of Bulgaria and Romania into the Schengen area. I ask, or rather call on the Minister, to put this on the agenda in the Council as well. The feeling of a large part of European citizens is that the European Union, without distinguishing between institutions, is ineffective. The Council is called upon to change this. My call is for less talk and real action for more security. More common commitment to defense and effective foreign policy. With regard to the situation in Spain, we are in absolute solidarity with our Spanish friends - the constitution, the protection of the rule of law and, of course, the rights of all Spanish citizens come first.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to address you as a Catalan socialist in view of the events that we have seen recently. First of all, many of us have seen images that have horrified us, which, in our place, we have also denounced the disproportionate use of force against peaceful protesters. But today the European Parliament above all has to send a message about the underlying political situation and appeal to several things: 1) respect for the rule of law and not the law for the law, but the law as a guarantee of coexistence , the law as a guarantee that abuses are not committed by the public powers; 2) to dialogue, to find political solutions as the only possible way out, to find new political consensus that recognize and guarantee all their feelings, their feelings, their identities; and 3) to make a call to calm the current situation, to reject any unilateral path that leads the Catalan institutions to disaster, in order, as Europeans, to find solutions - the fruit of recognition and coexistence - for the conflict.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, allow me to comment on two closely related Council points. It is migration and foreign policy. Migration pressure has now eased and the EU is in good shape. But we must expect further migratory pressures in the future. It is a reality and we have gained time to prepare better now. I therefore expect the European Council summit to reflect on the effectiveness of existing measures so that we do not repeat mistakes in the future. It must not happen that the EU is taken aback again and not ready, which is why I support security as a priority. We must focus on protecting the borders of the Schengen area, speeding up return and assistance in countries of origin and transit, which are key, for example, with Libya's assistance, both financially and in terms of security capacity, in cooperation with the United Nations. This is where we need to strengthen return and resettlement policies in the nearest countries of origin. As regards the proposal for a common asylum system, reform of the asylum system is needed in terms of better coordination. And the decision to grant asylum must remain fully in the hands of the Member States, because the Member States are responsible for internal security. Solidarity is, of course, necessary, but it must be in agreement with the Member States. I would like to remind you that the Czech Republic is in solidarity when it has built a large camp for 30,000 refugees in Jordan. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Dear colleague, have you talked about migration, about responsibility, about securing the Schengen borders, but what do you think about countries like Romania and Bulgaria, Croatia, which are not in Schengen, but have the same responsibilities regarding migration?Don't you think it is necessary for the Council to decide once for these states that have the same treaty, the same responsibilities, but do not have the same rights?How to secure the Schengen borders?And who secures the other countries, and how?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Thank you for your question, we know that these are the accession of these countries to the Schengen area.I believe that it is precisely on the issue of migration that these countries have fulfilled their role, that they have behaved very responsibly.I would also like to remind you that the Czech Republic has sent aid to these countries in the form of security forces, and I am in favor of these countries being rewarded for their efforts to ensure security on their territory.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our future is Europe. Yesterday was the fourth anniversary of the Lampedusa massacre: it was October 3, 2013 and what remains in my memory is not only the number of victims, but the image of that tragedy. That day, we all said together: never again. Since then we have been committed to replacing cynicism and selfishness with solidarity, in defense of life. Yet the situation has almost returned to being the same. Something wrong. Something went wrong. Immigration is not a phenomenon that can be stopped, but it is a phenomenon that can be managed. The reduction in flows, as reiterated by President Pittella, cannot reassure us. It is the root causes that push people to leave their countries. We are also working seriously with the Council to give a global response to the migratory phenomenon and the results achieved so far have been possible thanks to the role of co-legislator of Parliament, which is currently preparing its position on the Dublin reform. And we do not hide behind our divisions and our political differences. We move forward because we believe in solid reform of the system ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Council must underline at its meeting that the European Union is a union of laws. They apply to all and everyone. To national governments as well as to local governments, authorities and citizens. That is the only way to stability, peace and dialogue. Secondly, the defence issue. We need to develop a defence facing all the challenges we see today, where Russia is not only a test case, but also a real challenge. On all the levels of threats coming therefrom, we need to strengthen our capabilities and our defence. Thirdly, the digital challenge. We cannot only talk about it, we need to ensure that we can be in the lead, phasing out not only roaming charges, but also roaming by pan-European networks, on mobile broadband, enabling other facilities and a scale of economy that can make us the leaders.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- President!Thanks also to my colleague for answering my question!You rightly mentioned that laws, European legislation, must be respected by everyone, including governments.It is important that you mentioned this, but will you tell these sentences to Fidesz, who is in the ranks of the People's Party, that the Hungarian government has been campaigning an amazing lie with the European Union in recent days, especially with regard to refugees,it reminds me of Nazi times, and I just ask [...] (The President withdrew.)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Szanyi!I do not think comparisons with the Nazi era are appropriate.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – This is a very simple question and it has a simple answer: laws are for everyone. There is no party and no colour attached to laws. We all need to abide by the laws. I can be critical of bad policies wherever they come from – whether they belong to my party group or your party group – but the main thing is that the laws are decided here. We have a court and a legal system to implement them, and that must be respected. I continue to call on the Commission to ensure that the laws are implemented, and followed. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the forthcoming EU Council risks being a complete non-event if ambitions are not raised. The EU needs to look seriously at reforms and at the implications of a no-deal Brexit: Capital Markets Union (CMU) for example, and the digital agenda could be another, given the strong presence of tech startups in the UK. The EU and the UK also need to maintain close cooperation on foreign and defence issues. This is vital in files where the UK has been leading, such as Syria, where, over the past two weeks we have witnessed the highest death toll in 2017. Heavy retaliatory strikes by the Assad regime and Russia in the north, even targeting hospitals, have taken away all credibility from the Astana Process. A real political transition has to be a priority in Geneva. The EU has to take political leadership to balance Russian and Iran, but also the USA. I urge the Tory government to be earnest about continued collaboration with the EU on defence, and not to use security as a bargaining chip. On migration, subsequent Commission plans have failed due to the lack of political will of Member States. I urge the Council to ditch the dithering and engage in substantial reform of the Common European Asylum System.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: - Mr President, today I must denounce with all the strength of my soul the unacceptable, continuing, provocative and brutal actions of Turkey against Cyprus, a member state of the European Union. Mr Timmermans knows, because he took part in the Crans-Montana negotiations, that Turkey, with its unacceptable and provocative positions, has led to a stalemate in the Cyprus negotiations, insisting that the occupying troops, guarantees and unilateral . This provocative and unacceptable Turkey with the occupation regime this morning imposed a ban on the passage of humanitarian aid for the heroic Greeks trapped in the Carpathians, imposing new accomplishments and policies of national cleansing in Cyprus. Mr Timmermans, the European Commission must react immediately, as UNFICYP did. I also call on the Estonian Presidency to raise this issue immediately at the next European Council to condemn Turkey with sanctions. I still call with all my might, my fellow MEPs, to vote against all those funds concerning Turkey in order to send a strong message. For Spain, I want to send a clear message: we must all, Mr President, defend the territorial integrity, the constitutional order and the constitutional integrity of each member state of the European Union. (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - President! The issue of migration and refugees will determine European policy for a long time to come. That is why we are facing a double task. On the one hand, there is a need to continue building a common European asylum system, an effective European asylum agency, a rethink of the Dublin Convention and the closure of pending asylum dossiers as soon as possible. There is an urgent need for a common European model of social integration, as this is the only way to avoid radicalization, the serious social problems that will follow. On the other hand, governments that use asylum for selfish and often lowly political purposes must be confronted much, much more firmly than before. Nothing does as much harm in Europe as incitement to fear and hatred, xenophobia, introverted nationalism. Of course, compromises must be sought, but there are limits to compromises. If we make too many concessions to governments that wink at the far right, we give up our own identity, we deny our own traditions.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Tallinn Digital Summit agreed on an inspiring agenda, and after that the Estonian Presidency concluded that the Digital Single Market could be completed by 2018. That is in one year’s time. The EU’s biggest problem still is implementation: bringing to life the spirit of Tallinn requires continued political determination to avoid returning to ‘business as usual’. Incidentally, President Macron, in his maiden speech, was surprisingly modest when he called just for strengthening of the digital market. Today our job is not to limit ourselves anymore to Eurospeak terms like ‘strengthening’ or ‘deepening’ but rather to complete tasks on which we have all agreed. It is also important clearly to understand that the single European cyberspace and single cybersecurity market do not merely constitute a lofty goal but could and should be become a reality in eight years’ time. May I express my full support to the Spanish Constitution and Spain’s integrity.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Mister President!I expect the heads of state and government not only to talk about the sunny side of digitization.Digital Europe must be discussed in the same breath as social Europe.The digital single market without minimum social standards is absurd.So we cannot just talk about simplifications for companies and boosting the digital single market when digital social dumping is already being carried out across Europe at the click of a mouse.Because regardless of whether as an Uber driver, a Foodora supplier or a factory worker - fair wages, protection under labor law and trade union rights must apply to all working people in Europe.When we talk about digitization, I also expect people to talk about how we can get the internet multinationals - Facebook, Google and Co. - to finally pay their taxes.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Turkey is on the agenda of the European Council meeting, and it is high time the European leaders developed a proper strategy on how to deal with developments in this EU candidate country.  Until now, the approach has been to wait, see and hope that things will improve in the country whilst the situation continues to deteriorate. The European Parliament has called on the Council and the Commission to formally suspend the accession talks if the new Constitution is implemented, as it runs contrary to the Copenhagen criteria. But it is also important that we stand in solidarity with the Turkish population in these difficult times.  We expect EU leaders at the Summit to make the same distinction in their approach. Strict when it comes to our own values and in reaction to clear breaches of fundamental rights, while sending a strong message to the citizens of Turkey that we are willing to continue supporting democrats and civil society in their country. It would be a mistake only to react to President Erdogan and to forget about the population.

name: Sergei Stanishev (S&D).
text: – Mr President, after many years of absence from the agenda of the European Council, security and defence are back, and with good reason. The citizens of the European Union expect us to act together in order to provide external and internal security, both for citizens and for our Member States. The European Union is known as a soft power and this identity should be preserved and developed. This is unique for Europe, but it is good too to have strength and to show the ability to protect ourselves. There are two major tools which we possess, or rather which are in development. The first is the permanent structured cooperation (PESCO) initiative, and I would like to stress that it should be inclusive, because if we are to have a single shield we cannot allow cracks in it. The other is the European Defence Fund. I would like to stress that the intention to have more than EUR 5 billion per year for this fund requires own resources for the European Union. I think that if we act together we can respond to the expectations of our citizens.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has accepted the digital challenge, but now the question is how to overcome this challenge. First: the digital single market must be completed as soon as possible, because it is a social and civil issue, as has been said, as well as an economic one. The abolition of roaming has been a tangible and appreciated progress by citizens but we cannot afford to take years and years to complete the digital single market. Second: we need to create the necessary infrastructure from broadband connection to 5G implementation. Third: massive investments in staff training are needed. Statistics tell us that there is a big, terrible gap between the skills that exist in the market and those that would be needed. So, investing in training, as well as in infrastructure, I think is the way to guarantee good employment, as my colleague Berès said. Fourth: we need to find the funds, by taxing digital companies right. The tax avoidance of the giants of the web, on the one hand, and the European delays in digital, on the other, are two sides of the same coin. And we can't solve one without the other. Finally, we must be aware that the development and proper management of digital technologies are a central issue for security and defense.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Europe was born as a project of peace, understanding, diversity and coexistence, and today there is a part of Europe where that project is in danger. Of course - as happens to many of my colleagues - there are images that we saw on October 1 that we do not like, that we reject and regret, but, above all, there is a reality, which is a social fracture that worries us. That is why we appeal to the rule of law. That is why we appeal to compliance with the law. Because we understand that you can vote, but you have to vote a social dialogue. We must vote after a political agreement by the forces of our country, to understand that we must seek those spaces for coexistence. I appeal to understanding, to dialogue. This is not the time for reproaches. This is not the time to come here to distribute responsibilities. Some may have come to say what their speech is to be applauded, but I think it is time to listen to what is being asked of us. Please, let's talk. Si us plau, parlem.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure.I ask for understanding.We have three times as many inquiries as we actually have time slots.That is why I will only consider one colleague from each group.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, both President Juncker and President Macron were right to point out for the need for the EU to harmonise taxation and adopt qualified-majority voting in taxation decisions. This should be a priority at the European summit, otherwise, the EU will continue to be bogged down by an ungovernable European monetary union, shrinking national and European fiscal resources, a fictional single market with competition distorted by tax dumping, and the tax jungle prone to be made worse by Brexit. The reality, however, is already alarming. We will not work for common security and defence by letting corruption and organised crime, including human trafficking and terrorism, continue, and by allowing the proceeds through our taxation and financial systems, taking advantage of the digital era. The Commission set alarm bells ringing with the report on VAT carousel fraud, showing it provides EUR 5 billion per year to organised crime, including terrorism. How can EU governments and the EU Council be effective with action on VAT and the common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB) if they go on enabling terrorists and mafia to get funds through our own tax system on a massive scale?

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the European Council will once again discuss illegal migration flows and nothing will change after that debate. Why? Because there is no consensus in the European Union on immigration policy, and thus on how to fight illegal migration. As long as this is the case, some members will continue to encourage immigration for some of their own reasons, and some will continue to resist it. In such circumstances, an effective policy cannot be adopted and pursued. All the differences between the members can be seen on this issue. Some are ready to agree to mass immigration out of their national interest, primarily due to the aging of the indigenous population and lack of labor, and some others have a significantly different economic situation and see this as a threat to their culture and tradition. If we really want to be "united in diversity", European immigration policy must take into account the arguments, wishes and ambitions of both sides in this debate. So far this has not been the case and that must change.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to use this minute to clarify some things that are part of the ABC of democracy and this House and what it represents. Spain is a member of the European Union because it has accredited a constitutional order and, to remain a member, it must maintain that order. Vice President Timmermans recently expressed himself in this sense because, indeed, the situation we are in right now is clearly European competence, but it is because Spain, which has its flag there along with the others, must maintain that order to remain a member . The only thing I want to say additionally is that the secessionists have tried to break that constitutional order, and what we are talking about here is representing and defending all European citizens and all Spanish citizens. When we speak of Catalans, we speak of all Catalans, and I want to recall here only the words of the Head of State, the King, who yesterday clearly expressed that there had been unacceptable disloyalty and an improper appropriation of the institutions. Therefore, of course, from Europe I demand that we convey to all citizens that we must defend the order of Spain.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, immigration is once again monopolizing our debate. The impoverishment to which large sections of the population have been driven by neoliberal austerity policies, along with the xenophobic rhetoric of governments, is paving the way for extremism, racism and xenophobia. Ladies and gentlemen, it is not too late to oppose Fortress Europe. It is not too late to finally implement a common asylum system, legal and safe migration routes and to oblige all Member States to assume their responsibilities with an equal burden. To oppose the inhumane policies of militarization of the Union's external and internal borders, which, instead of strengthening neighboring countries, turn them into border guards. The solidarity of the peoples is shown through development policies, which must promote peace and mutual understanding. They are promoted through policies that promote social development, social justice for the benefit of the peoples inside and outside the Union.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the issues on the agenda of the next European Council are very serious, although I believe that the same disastrous policies on immigration, defense and foreign policy will be pursued. Speaking to his country's parliament on Sunday, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdo .an said Turkey no longer needed membership in the Union. In addition, European Commissioner for Enlargement Johannes Hahn said Turkey under Erdogan's presidency had turned its back on its accession to the European Union. After years of stalled accession negotiations with Turkey, European citizens realize that the process is dead, knowing Erdogan's persecution of his critics, statements about Nazi governments in Europe and the referendum that gave him supremacy. But now is a golden opportunity for member state leaders to rid Europe of Erdo ναan and cut off all co-operation and talks with Turkey.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the comments made by the Members of Parliament. Many of the comments were made about the situation in Spain. I have taken careful note of all the comments, and I would like to refer those who put the questions and made the comments to the statement I will make on behalf of the Commission later today in this plenary. Now, going back to the agenda of the European Council, it is clear to me that there is a strong convergence of views between the Commission and the European Parliament on such issues as the digital single market, the social pillar and tackling the enormous challenge of migration. Let me reiterate that last week we put on the table a number of proposals in a holistic approach to the migration issue. There is not one silver bullet that will solve this challenge to Europe and its societies. We can only be successful in managing the challenge of globalisation and migration in that framework if we are better at protecting our external borders; if we make agreements with countries of origin to offer prospects to people where they are instead of having people think they need to find a better future elsewhere; if we have agreements with the countries of transit; if we are more successful at combating human trafficking, at combating this terrible criminal activity on the backs of innocent people; but also if we understand that the Dublin Agreement was made at a time of different challenges and that now it needs to be adapted to the world of today and tomorrow. This means that the issue of solidarity cannot be avoided and must also be tackled in this framework. It is my firm belief that, although there are different emphases in different Member States on parts of the package, the package as a whole is the only way forward. I count on the strong support of the European Parliament to convince the leaders of the Member States that this should be done now, with a sense of urgency, so that we can show Europeans, before the next European elections, that Europe is capable of answering their call that we should do better at managing migration and that we should do more for our collective security.  (Applause)

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their comments and observations on the next European Council meeting. I will convey them to the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, as it is he who sets the agenda of European Council meetings. On the Presidency’s behalf, I note that the reform of the Common European Asylum System was mentioned repeatedly during the debate. As first Vice-President Timmermans said, we should not lose sight of the fact that there are seven legislative proposals under this reform of the Common European Asylum System. Good progress has been made on some of them, others are already in the negotiation phase between the Council and Parliament, but the reform of the Dublin Regulation remains controversial. It was rightly mentioned that some Member States have not moved on this proposal, and I would add that this is the case with not just one but both extremes in this particular debate. Estonia is doing what the Presidency must do: we are in intense consultations with the Member States. The Estonian Minister for the Interior, at the Ministers’ meeting next week, will present the state of play, and we are also looking for guidance from the European Council meeting in two weeks’ time on that particular legislative proposal. The broader debate on the future of Europe was discussed over dinner at the Tallinn Digital Summit. President Tusk’s conclusion was that, within two weeks, he will consult the Heads of State and Government of the EU Member States and will then set out his way forward in this debate. Last, but not least, I would like to thank all the Members of this House for their comments on the digital single market and, more broadly, on the digital society. Ms Berès, Mr Kelam and others rightly brought out various aspects of the digital society. The debate is not only about the digital single market proposals, it is much broader, and the digital revolution affects us all. There was overwhelming agreement and a common understanding at the Tallinn Digital Summit last week that all these aspects must be tackled by the European leaders. This, if you will, is indeed the spirit of Tallinn.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The sitting is suspended until 12 noon. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - It was said that we should treat Turkey with policies that recognize the difference between the Erdoğan regime and the democratic forces. That's right. It goes without saying that policies that strengthen the Erdoğan regime and that it seeks to consolidate its power are wrong and should be avoided. Can supporters of upgrading Turkey's Customs Union with the EU justify how this policy weakens Erdoğan? This Erdo πουan regime that this morning decided to deprive the Republic of Cyprus of the food and humanitarian aid that it has been sending for decades - by mutual agreement through the UN - to the few Greek Cypriots trapped in the occupied territories that Turkey wants to expel. This is happening in the territory of the EU, in Cyprus, which Turkey has held since 1974. Regarding the referendum in Catalonia, the European Union must protect the national sovereignty, the rule of law and the territorial integrity of Spain, as well as the observance of constitutional order and the unity of the country. Only the people of Spain can decide on any change in their own country through democratic procedures.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - A new Europe is being born in the West. The French president announced the United States of Europe, also supported by the DK, last week, with a joint army, border guards, and European finance minister. Today, there are two types of EU Member States: smaller EU Member States and those that do not yet know that they are small. Germany, for example, the largest state in Europe, only goes to a medium-sized Chinese province. The European Union is the common destiny and future of European states. If there is a Union, Europe's prosperity, its social network and its health for all will be preserved. If not, we can say goodbye to everything. Nationalist nostalgia does not use it against Russian aggression or Chinese investment. This false nostalgia, the search for enemies, may distract us for hours, but the European Union is our only chance against the emerging powers. Some in the East are attacking this last chance solely for short-sighted political interests. The proposals just announced by the French President have been supported by the DK since 2014. Europe, and Hungary within it, has only one way forward, and that is to create the United States of Europe. That is why I support proposals such as the creation of a European university, a European FBI or a European Monetary Fund.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- Representatives of the European Council and the Commission addressed the forthcoming European Council, outlining four items on the agenda.The first point will be migration, where positive results have been achieved in terms of reducing the number of migrants to the EU.However, legislative action is needed to target smugglers, strengthen the borders of the Schengen area and deepen cooperation with the UN.I appreciate that, in the next point, both the Council and the Commission address the digital agenda, where we need to take framework action to prepare the EU for the changes that digitalisation brings.The third point that the meeting will address is security, where we appreciate the peaceful dialogue with Iran, which could serve as a model for a diplomatic solution to the world's conflicts.With the final point of the forthcoming meeting, there will be foreign relations, where many current issues will be addressed, such as relations with Turkey.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: signed up.- The European Commission is committed to presenting the new financial framework 2021-2027 in May 2018. Only in this way will it be possible for this financial framework to be adopted before the new elections to the European Parliament in June 2019 and to ensure the proper preparation of theall regulations necessary for the implementation of European programs and projects, starting in the first year 2021. This financial framework should already include the effect of decisions on the future of the European Union.It is therefore important that Member States also use this European Council to prepare these decisions, which will be taken in the first quarter of next year.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - On September 30, sugar quotas and what was the last agricultural quota regime still in force in the European Union ended. The decision to end sugar quotas now results from the 2013 reform of the common agricultural policy (CAP) that started in 2006 and which includes, among other things, the end of milk quotas and planting rights for vineyards. The end of sugar quotas ends up having a political meaning that marks the end of a shift towards the complete liberalization of supply that is now governed solely and exclusively by the law of the market. But as reality shows, the market that the European Union proclaims is nothing more than a mechanism designed to concentrate production in the richest countries, creating ties of pure dependence and vassalage towards the poorest countries. With the agricultural crisis in the background, it is now imperative to stop this neoliberal drift at the level of the CAP, whether by restoring the instruments for regulating supply, or at the level of the various free trade agreements that are putting unbearable pressure on our farmers .

name: President. –
text: Before we move to the vote, I give the floor to Ms Berès.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Madam President, having never had the honor of occupying your position, I appreciate all the difficulty of presiding over the sittings of our Assembly.However, this morning your predecessor, Mr Wieland, conducted the debate in such a way that, in the end, we had a ten-minute suspension, while he interrupted a number of speakers, including myself., under perfectly discourteous conditions and contrary to the coherence of thought.So, I wanted to make this observation.

name: President. –
text: Ms Berès, to show solidarity with Vice-President Wieland, I have never found him discourteous, but I take note of your comment. I will perhaps bring it to the Bureau and we could look at this issue because I also get criticism when I am very strict with time. My one observation is that yesterday I did not use the gavel during one debate, as an experiment, and it actually worked very well. But we take note of your comment.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, for over one month now this Parliament has failed to fulfil its duty under Rule 20 of our Rules of Procedure, which sets out an imperative requirement. I quote: ‘If it becomes necessary for the President, a Vice-President or a Quaestor to be replaced, a successor shall be elected’. Former Vice-President, Ms Gáll-Pelcz, left the Parliament for the Court of Auditors in September this year, and I wish to announce to this Chamber, to the democratically-elected representatives of the European people, that I have fulfilled the criteria for nomination, according to Rule 15(1). I ask the President to put the vacant post to the vote tomorrow, in order to stop embarrassing this Parliament with indecisiveness, and to give the EPP Group enough time to nominate their candidate. If they continue not to be interested in this important parliamentary post, I will humbly accept the seat of Vice-President by acclamation. These times are scary, colleagues, and Europe needs leadership, not vacancies and empty-seat policies.

name: President. –
text: Mr Tarand, your humility is noted and recorded. As you know, the Conference of Presidents sets the agenda. With respect to their prerogative in this area, we will vote when they set a deadline for submission of nominations for the position and put it on our agenda. But we take note of your comments. I have one announcement before the vote. The President has received from the S&D Group a nomination for membership of a delegation. This nomination will be noted in the minutes of the sitting. If no observations have been submitted by the time the minutes are adopted, the nomination will be deemed to have been accepted.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I wanted to present a point of order for article 186, because today the debate in preparation for the next Council has focused on the question of Catalonia, and whoever chaired the debate has complained.The problem with this is that on Monday they decided to allow the debate on the situation of fundamental rights in Catalonia only to the group presidents and in a very non-transparent way.President Tajani said on Monday that we were voting, first, if the debate took place, second, the time, and, third, the title;but at no time was the format voted on or decided in this House.Please do not try to cover up the seriousness of the conflict in Catalonia and the violence against civilians with a botch.We should clearly decide in what format we are going to hold that debate.The public and this Parliament deserve to decide it clearly and democratically.

name: President. –
text: Just to inform the House: those of us who were here at the start of business reached an agreement across the House as to how this debate would be handled. We are all extremely aware of the sensitivities of this issue. I think that, as a responsible parliament, we look forward to this debate and hope that we can assist in a very delicate situation.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in the previous vote I voted in favour, but the light changed by itself. I did not touch the button, so something must have happened. That is why. (Laughter)

name: President. –
text: Mr Melo, just be warned. Keep a close eye on the light on your vote should it move or change without your intervention.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with this report the rapporteur proposes to introduce a requirement for the registration of digital notification of passenger data through harmonized administrative procedures, aimed at facilitating search and rescue operations in an emergency. I have decided to support the work of my colleague Bilbao, due to the particular attention paid to the protection of passenger data and their destruction when no longer needed. One aspect, that of the protection of citizens' rights and data, is very expensive in Movimento. I am pleased to see that our proposal to add the date of birth and a contact number to the requested data has been accepted, thus contributing to greater clarity in identifications. Regarding some exemptions, although we had asked that they be accessible, through the creation of an online public database, the transparency of the exemptions is still guaranteed by their accessibility to the public. I thank my colleague for the work she has done and I welcome her efforts to improve the guarantee of European passenger rights.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and say that I supported this report because I believe that data protection is a priority and I believe that the way in which this was included in the report should have been voted on.I hope it will be applied because, many times, we have problems not with the regulation, not with the appearance of a new law, but with the application.It is important that the data is deleted, as foreseen in the report, and in fact the report went in line with the Commission's proposal, it was a technical report and I thank those who contributed.We have tabled amendments and supported this report, believing that we need to be clear about data protection on transit vessels.

name: Rupert Matthews (ECR).
text: – Madam President, some years ago I wrote a book about the wreck of RMS Titanic. That terrible night showed all too clearly the consequences of not enforcing safety rules at sea. These rules that we have passed today bring the European Union into line with the International Maritime Organisation, a branch of the United Nations which is based in London, a great maritime city with a seagoing heritage reaching back more than 2 000 years. That is a reminder that in many areas of international relations it is not the European Union that calls the shots, but other international organisations, and that Britain is already a member of many of those organisations. This is just another reason why I believe Brexit is going to be a great success.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Madam President!I have always spoken out against bureaucracy and am - as I have repeatedly argued - in favor of reducing it, which is why I adopted this resolution with great satisfaction.I am glad that the number of various potential interventions is limited to a smaller number of entities.I am also pleased with the announcement by President Juncker that the European Parliament will increasingly devote its time to important things, these key things, and abandon detailed regulations.This proof of today is, in my opinion, excellent to confirm the declaration of the whole Parliament.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Ms. President!A feasibility study carried out by the European Commission in accordance with the rules in force found that certain inaccuracies in the legal provisions led to differing interpretations by national authorities, in particular as regards the scope of the Directive for smaller vessels and other types of vessels.The European Commission is now tasked with simplifying and clarifying the requirements, so it has launched a comprehensive review.I agree with the rapporteur that the main aim of the regulation on the safety of passenger ships should be to ensure that passengers and crew can travel safely on board passenger ships in the Union.For all these reasons, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, my colleague, Rupert Matthews, just propagated an enduring myth, namely that the Titanic did not meet the safety standards of its time. It is an idea sedulously propagated ever since, not least in the film in which Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet show such impressive post-coital vigour and energy for the rest of the duration of the sinking. In fact, the Titanic was well in advance of the safety rules of its time on lifeboats and everything else, but I think there is a lesson to be drawn there about modesty, and about not thinking that you can declare some invincible or irresistible policy. Look at the things we are voting on today: all these plans to eliminate unemployment and become the greatest knowledge economy, and so on. We are like the architects of that doomed vessel, with the lack of self-awareness to see that we cannot decree these things and make them happen. Let us rather act in the spirit of the poor bandleader, Wallace Hartley, who, in his final minutes, played himself out with his threnody, remembering the hymn he had learned as a boy. If we stick to what we know, rather than presuming to tell the rest of the world what to do, we might be a little bit more respected.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in contrast to some of the bizarre views just expressed on the other side of the Chamber, this is a very important update to passenger ship safety laws. It is quite a technical measure but it is very important. The main purpose of these laws must be to ensure that passengers and crew can travel safely on board passenger ships and boats in the EU. This simplification should help to ensure improved implementation, monitoring and enforcement of the rules, and it should therefore be supported. However, it is important that passenger confidence is maintained and that penalties for breaches of the national provisions adopted will be adequate and enforced. Some of my amendments and the amendments of colleagues have ensured that. The final text moves in the right direction in these respects. It is absolutely worth voting for, and I am glad that I did so.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank my colleague Riquet for the work in this report which aims to eliminate the uncertainty arising from the coexistence of two directives on the inspection of ships, the 1999 and 2009 directives respectively. eliminate some uncertainties related to the timing of inspections of Ro-Ro ferries and high-speed passenger craft used for scheduled services by the competent authorities. Two aspects of particular concern to me are the safety of passengers and the social aspects of these inspections. As regards passenger safety, I have decided to support the work of my colleague, because the text guarantees high safety standards, the simplification of the previous directives does not affect the rights of passengers in this way. With regard to the social aspects, the inspections envisaged by this new directive take into account the working environments and personal life on board, thus combining greater attention to safety with the necessary respect for workers and their rights.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Ms. President!I voted in favor of the adoption of the report on the registration of persons sailing on board passenger ships arriving in or departing from ports of the Member States.I agree with the updating, clarification and simplification of the current rules and registers for the registration of passengers and crew on board passenger ships, which is expected to lead to an increase in the level of safety.Thus, I also find it useful to use the digital one-stop-shop notification proposed by the Commission for longer journeys, while sharing the rapporteur's views on the protection of passengers' personal data.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Madam President!The security of citizens or the security of their personal data - this is how the dispute I remember about the control of passenger movements began, and it concerned air flights.Today we have the same dilemma - very well resolved - with regard to ship passengers.I must say that, in my opinion, there is no contradiction between these two elements: you need to take care of both the security of personal data and the security of the passengers themselves.The two can be simplified, can be combined, and this resolution is the best proof of that.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this resolution because its primary objective is to ensure the safe operation of ro-ro, passenger and high-speed passenger vessels. With more than 400 million passengers passing through European ports every year, maritime transport has been one of the fundamental pillars of economic growth and prosperity in Europe. This Commission proposal is part of the program for the adequacy and effectiveness of REFIT regulations, with the aim of simplifying the legal framework, ensuring common, clear, simplified and enforced rules for high-speed ferries and passenger vessels from the European Union and destined for the European Union, reducing the administrative burden on shipowners and rationalizing the efforts of the maritime administrations of the Member States. Dear Colleagues, we have just approved a solid and coherent legal framework for maritime passenger transport. I believe that these measures guarantee and reinforce the level of common security and an environment of fair competition for all operators.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Madam President! In recent reports by WHO and the European Environment Agency, the harmfulness of chemicals used in the production of food, cosmetics, packaging and other plastic products to humans and the environment has been confirmed on the basis of current research. Hormonal disruptors cause fertility disorders and many other civilization diseases, such as defects, cancer, diabetes, neurological diseases, which Parliament has been debating since at least 2009. That is why I abstained, hoping for progress. On the one hand, an instructive debate showed a different position towards the applicable law, but above all the conflict between caring for human health and the environment and concern for the competitiveness of European agriculture on the global market. Despite the huge amount of measures, including biopesticides, there is no adequate level of chemical protection, as the producers of these chemicals focus on the most profitable large-scale crops.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, fortunately there is the European Parliament.We can be proud of our vote, which gives new impetus to European democracy, which has been violated, it must be said, from start to finish on this issue of endocrine disruptors.The Commission must now review its copy, as it gave us the impression of being held for eight years by the lobbies to which it has never ceased to submit, at the risk of being held responsible, tomorrow, forone of the biggest health scandals in Europe.These are very powerful lobbies, like Monsanto, whom the European Parliament has kept at bay by shutting the door of our institution to it.The Commission must act now by making the choice, not of the morbid interests of industrial lobbies, but of the health of European citizens.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - The President, therefore, the European Commission has once again given in to lobbies and to industry that wants to protect its own capital interests in particular, especially at the expense of human health, so I welcome the European Parliament's veto on the criteria set by the European Parliament.proposed by the commission to identify endocrine disruptors.The Commission has, of course, exceeded its mandate by proposing to exclude certain chemicals from the definition of endocrine disruptors, as the criteria would make it very difficult to identify endocrine disruptors, which means that very few products would be removed from the market.industry.Which means, of course, to re-emphasize people’s health for the interests of capital.We have repeatedly pointed out that these disruptors are substances that can alter the functioning of the human hormonal system and are extremely dangerous and in some ways pose a global threat, so I once again welcome Parliament's decision to veto this.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF).
text: - Madam President, the current proposal for a definition of endocrine disruptors, which it should be remembered that they are responsible for many cancers, an increase in sterility in men and women, a generalized drop in the intelligence quotient, or behavioral disorders in children, is in no way up to the firmness and courage that must be had on this subject. With a health cost of 100 billion euros per year for Europe, endocrine disruptors are a real scourge. Today, the Commission is mocking the world by debating a derogation for molecules specially designed to disrupt the functioning of the endocrine system. It is not the role of the European Parliament to encourage the manufacture of pesticides that have endocrine disruption as a mode of action. That is why, together with my colleagues from the Europe of Nations and Freedoms Group, I supported this objection which opposes the definition of endocrine disruptors proposed by the Commission.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the objection and I welcome the veto, which was approved by the European Parliament by 389 votes. It's an important message to the Commission that the European Parliament does not tolerate an excess of power, as was the case here with the Commission 's draft regulation establishing scientific criteria for determining the properties of an endocrine disorder. Because the discussion showed that the criteria used by the Commission, in practice, came from a political compromise and were not criteria related to scientific and technical specifications. Endocrine disruptors are known to be chemicals that are dangerous to public health and the environment, and I once again welcome the European Parliament's determination to send a message that lobbying pressure is not passing.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Ms. President! I abstained on this report, and mainly because it did not deal at all with the de facto type of child marriage that is typical of my country, Hungary, especially in Roma communities. So this is not about de jure, legal marriages, but de facto, actual situations where 14, 15, 16, 17-year-old girls are indirectly forced by so-called customs or traditions or traditions, not by some kind of physical coercion, but indirectly. forced to stop studying, have a child, run a household, raise children, and thus lose the opportunity to live differently from their mother’s generation, their grandmother’s generation. The most important pledge for the rise of the Roma, and especially for the rise of Roma women, is learning, education, vocational training, and this requires breaking through these centuries-old traditions. I wanted more practical guidance and advice on this from this report.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of this resolution in recognition that child marriage is a violation of children's rights and a form of violence against women and girls and must be condemned outright. Child marriage, whether precocious or forced, is a violation of the rights of the child and constitutes a basic denial of the right of children to autonomy to dispose of their own bodies and respect for their physical integrity. Recent data from the Save the Children Organization shows that, every 7 seconds, a fifteen-year-old girl is forced to marry and the latest World Bank report states that every year 15 million girls worldwide get married before reaching eighteen years, that is, 37,000 girls are denied fundamental human rights daily. Child marriage, dear colleagues, precocious and forced, must be one of the priorities for the European Union's external action in the field of promoting women's rights and human rights within the framework of respect for the fundamental principles and essential fundamental values ​​of the European Union, in particular, gender equality and the protection of children's rights.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I supported this resolution because I find the issue of child marriage to be extremely important and the search for a solution to it cannot be postponed. This problem also exists in my country, Bulgaria, which makes me even more sympathetic to the positions expressed in this resolution. According to experts, the early start of family and parental life creates preconditions for early school leaving, which normally means that these children fail to acquire the skills needed for life, and thus fall into the category of socially excluded people. In this regard, the world we live in is extremely dynamic and the failure to learn these skills leads to these people falling into the category of people who suffer from poverty throughout their lives. Even more so if we talk about health problems that arise from early pregnancy.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Forced marriage of children, most often girls, and often sent abroad, is an additional effect of mass Islamic immigration. The greater the effect, the more massive this immigration is, because the social integration of these families would be easier if they did not live in environments that maintain these non-European customs. And using this pathological practice to enforce the Istanbul Convention is perhaps the most bizarre example of left-liberal populism that we often witness. In this context, I would like to point out that the countries that oppose the Istanbul Convention - Catholic countries such as Croatia or Slovakia - are not familiar with this dramatic practice. The only country where she is present that has taken concrete action to oppose it, has launched an office, is the United Kingdom, and it has not ratified the Istanbul Convention either, so really think about it.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Obviously, in the motion for a resolution, I support the elimination of the possibility for children to marry, especially in immigrant circles, and at least in our Christian culture, in Europe, it has long been treated as violence and a crime, also existing in international law. However, child marriage is popular not only among European immigrant communities but also in Asia, Africa and Latin America as a whole, which requires action on the international stage. Sexual violence and forced marriages pose a serious threat to mental and physical health, drop out of education, increase the possibility of sexual abuse and violence, and even many diseases and death. While the protection of children and counteracting forced marriages should be a priority, the controversial provisions regarding the financing of abortion and the use of girls' tragedies to introduce no less harmful and traumatic sexualization cannot be accepted.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Forced marriage of a few-year-old girls is disgusting, they are pure pedophilia. I find it shocking that such marriages also take place in many countries of the European Union. We can especially mention here those countries that shout so loudly about the Istanbul Convention, which supposedly is supposed to protect against violence. And it is in these countries that such marriages also occur, especially in sharia zones. It is puzzling how the European Union wants to educate the whole world, but it cannot clean up its own house on its own. It is in connection with the intensifying migration crisis that pathological, criminal and bestial behavior is unfortunately spreading. I would like to say with all responsibility that the European Commission, its leaders, should take radical measures and initiate all procedures against the Member States of the European Union where this pathology occurs.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the resolution on the abolition of child marriage, because child marriage, early marriage and forced marriage constitute a violation and denial of the fundamental rights of children. According to the data, in developing countries 1/3 of girls getting married are under 18 years old, 1/9 are under 15 years old. It turns out, then, that in practice these children are deprived of education, in addition to the fact that they are led to early pregnancy as a supposed proof of fertility. In my view, the Istanbul Convention should be promoted, as it prohibits forced marriage.
