But as Mr Dombrovskis said, it was always intended. We can build on current results and not waste them.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fiscal compact is a wrong treaty twice: in form, because it is intergovernmental, and in content, because it expresses an antiquated economic vision, which contradicts the need for counter-cyclical policies and denies the fundamental function of public investment. . That's right, Mr. Starbatty, for the fiscal compact, throwing money into women and alcohol, as Dijsselbloem unhappily said, is the same as Franklin Delano Roosevelt's New Deal: there is no difference - that is, a vision, indeed, that decades of economic culture of the twentieth century have helped to overcome - and, moreover, disregards the concept of the aggregate fiscal position of the euro zone, as well as denying the fact that an economic policy is not conducted only on rules, on automatic pilot, but needs a government cheap. This is all the more so since the Economic and Monetary Union does not have a serious common budget worthy of the name, which would justify greater rigor at the level of the Member States. Moreover, this approach, as is well known - perhaps the 5 Star Movement ignores it - is also present in the Stability and Growth Pact, which is the true source of the rules we were talking about. In recent years we have opposed this vision and fought for a flexible application of the rules of the stability pact. And if today there is a recovery and the deficit is shrinking, as Niedermayer said, it is precisely because we have applied flexibility to rules, instead, conceived in an excessively rigid and antiquated way. And yet, it is equally clear that we must build better rules: it is not enough for us to simply find ways to apply them more intelligently every year. And in this sense, the real problem is not the fiscal compact, also because there is an article 2 - I will explain to you - which explains that it must still accommodate any changes in the laws of the Union, but is the we ask to improve it, to change it, to introduce a "golden rule", which distinguishes between investments and current expenditure and to introduce the concept of the eurozone's aggregate fiscal position.That is why we believe that the Commission would do well to use its time in a more useful way, to work on building fiscal capacity in the eurozone and improving the rules of the stability pact.If this is not the case, and integration is proposed, it is clear that the Democratic Party in Italy and in the Council will veto, unless there are profound changes in the content of the fiscal compact.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the fiscal pact is a system of imposing permanent "Merkel" austerity to the detriment of all the peoples of Europe. It even imposes the obligation to incorporate it in the Constitution of the Member States. In addition, it imposes on the Member States the famous Merkel Golden Rule, ie balanced or surplus government budgets. Otherwise, corrective mechanisms - the well-known "cutter" - are automatically activated - with reductions in salaries, pensions, social benefits and measures of violent fiscal adjustment. Thus fiscal discipline comes above growth. It is a fiscal "mantle", which imposes fines and sanctions, which limits national sovereignty, which increases unemployment, social inequalities. The troika and the Eurogroup are implementing this policy in Greece, which has become a guinea pig of the fiscal pact with millions of poor people and armies of the unemployed, with the sale of public property and an increase in shameful debt. But, Mr Dombrovskis, the Greek people do not tolerate memoranda and the troika and will send you the message soon.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the European Union's unique fiscal policy, with rules such as deficit limitation, restricts Member States' ability to respond to the economic cycle through their own fiscal policy. The budgetary treaty shows that the European Union has learned nothing from history and what it does is to reinforce two perverse aspects of the rules that already exist, the ultraliberal tightening of the budgetary rules, that is, austerity as a rule, aggravating the problems of the countries in the response to prolonged stagnation and high unemployment and when introducing the structural balance criterion, the arbitrariness that already existed in the imposition of rules, treating countries in an unequal way, which now becomes a rule itself. Integrating the budgetary treaty into Community law will be tragic. The role of socialists is crucial and I hope it is not as tragic as it was in previous moments. I appeal to all groups that claim the welfare state, the protection of work and social Europe to reject this conversion. I do not know if we are in time to save the Union. But not taking this step will be fundamental to this.

name: Marco Zanni (ENF).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry that Mr Gualtieri is gone, because I would have liked to remind him that his party not only supported the fiscal compact but also supported Maastricht and the Stability and Growth Pact. So it's a bit ridiculous, after twenty years, to come and apologize, and after the damage done to the Italians reduced to poverty. As for the fiscal compact, this is the essence of the European Union: the death of the state and democracy. It is madness to think that the budget of a state is managed like the budget of a family: it means being ignorant and not understanding how the budget of a state works. You made us believe that the problem and the cause of the crisis were public debt and the deficit. No, it is not the public debt; the public debt was a consequence of the heinous actions of the asymmetry that the euro has brought within the European Union. I don't say it: those you think are credible and common sense say it. The vice-president of the European Central Bank, Constâncio, says it, the President of the Central Bank, Mario Draghi, says the chief economist of the ECB and one of the highest executives of the ECB, Benoît Cœuré: a state that has monetary sovereignty, which has the power to print the currency in which his debt is denominated can always support his debt. Go and see the ECB website: this research and these speeches are public for everyone. Today we cannot support this system: within Europe, within these rules we die. The only way is to return to monetary sovereignty.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as Chair of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I will not refer to the substance of this Treaty but to the constitutional aspects of the Treaty. One may recall that the European Parliament has never been a proponent of resorting to an intergovernmental treaty governed by international law to strengthen the fiscal rules and compliance with fiscal discipline in the Union, and this is why, in the phase leading to the adoption of this Treaty in 2012 (which was exactly after the most famous, I think, of the British vetoes in December 2011), the European Parliament has insisted on certain safeguards to be put in the Treaty in order to guarantee conformity with the Union Treaties, the Union law in general, and to make the international nature of the Treaty temporary. It was the European Parliament that insisted on this specific clause contained in Article 16, which requires the substance of the Treaty to be incorporated into the legal framework of the Union before January 2018. The Committee on Constitutional Affairs is concerned with the institutional aspects of the incorporation of the substance of the Treaty in the EU framework, and we have been investigating this issue for quite some time. Now we have it in the Commission work programme; we have it in the letter of intent of Jean-Claude Juncker, so we are expecting the proposal. There is in the Treaty the substance that is not necessary or suitable to be incorporated, because the provisions relate to the intergovernmental nature of the Treaty and have no substantial content or duplicate existing legislation but also concern elements that could be established within another framework. There is also substance that is already – or can be – incorporated through secondary legislation, but there is also substance that most likely would require Treaty change, and this is about the key provisions of the Treaty. So we are awaiting the December proposal with a sort of curiosity, especially in the context of the declaration of the President of the Commission that no Treaty change is on the Union’s agenda.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the integration of the fiscal compact into the legal framework of the European Union should be envisaged only if the lessons of recent years are properly taken into account. The first lesson is that this Treaty is also about coordination and governance. When it comes to coordination, the objectives are not only stability but also growth and convergence. We have learned in recent years that this convergence should be guided by economic and social targets together and the European Semester should be designed with this purpose. When it comes to reforms, the assumption is that the reforms which should be recommended to Member States should take into account their real priorities and not invented priorities. But we also need to deal with the governance part of the treaty and the governance must be democratic, which is not yet the case. This means that, if a eurozone summit is now being convened, let me remind you that the Treaty provides for Parliament’s President to be invited. Most of all, we need to make sure that, all through the process, Parliament will play a central role: when we discuss the reforms of the economic and monetary union (EMU), when we discuss the fiscal stance and when we discuss the recommendations for the euro area. We also need to recognise that there is a role for the national parliaments – yes, there is – when they are involved in discussing the national reform programmes and the country—specific recommendations. But overall we need an interinstitutional agreement to set the rules for real democratic governance of the EMU. Finally, on fiscal discipline, let me be clear: of course we need common fiscal discipline in the eurozone to make it sustainable, but it is also clear that, in order to have this common fiscal discipline, if we do not want to hinder growth and growth potential, we need to complement national fiscal discipline – which should be intelligent – with a proper fiscal capacity, as all other monetary zones in the world have. No monetary zone in the world has existed and been sustainable without a fiscal capacity. So these are our lessons to be integrated into the new framework.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! When over six years ago, in my country, Poland, there was a debate on the ratification of the fiscal treaty, we clearly presented our reservations. They concerned the transfer to Brussels of the sovereign rights of national parliaments in budgetary matters, the advancement of the federalist concept of the European Union and the use of the resources of the entire Union and its institutions to achieve the goals defined by the incomplete Union, i.e. in the eurozone countries. Today we are disappointed to see that we have fallen a little bit into it. There is no positive impact on the economic growth of EU economies or the competitiveness of the euro area peripheral countries. The forced integrated fiscal rigor does not eliminate the persistent current account deficits in Greece, Portugal, Spain or Italy, as mentioned by Mr Zanni. Instead, it widens the gap between them and the strongest economies of the eurozone, mainly Germany. It seems to me that the Commission should now present, Commissioner, a thorough impact assessment of the Stability Treaty. How does it affect the economy of individual countries?

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, twenty-five years ago the Maastricht Treaty was signed. I was twelve years old, but I remember very well how many people understood already then that trying to impose, through a treaty, a neoliberal economic model was a direct danger to democracy, sovereignty and social rights in Europe. Since then, the history of Europe has consisted in the effort of the powerful to impose neoliberal economic policies against the resistance of the peoples. The signing of the Budget Pact led my country to modify the Constitution in the middle of a summer, which was a covert blow against the democracy of the great coalition of socialists and popular. The only thing that has been achieved with all this is to plunge the continent into a situation of permanent political crisis, massive unemployment, inequality and territorial crisis. Ladies and gentlemen, the Commission is now announcing that it intends to take advantage of the United Kingdom's departure to integrate this Pact into European law: we are telling you to give up your attempt. The Budget Pact does not lead to greater European cohesion, but to an increase in tensions and to the disintegration of the European project itself: we are not going to allow it. Desist from your attempt.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, including the fiscal compact in the Treaties is pure folly. The fiscal compact has made Italy even more slave to the diktats of Brussels and the troika. We are tired of the imposition of Europe and the central state: we want to be free to use our money for our citizens. Our regions, our municipalities, our territories have the right to use this money which is our money, not Europe, Brussels or Berlin. Let me give you an example: my Veneto and Lombardy have higher tax residues than all of Europe. It is the regions that pay more but receive less from the state. We pay more than anyone but we cannot use our money independently. On October 22, Veneto and Lombardy will vote in the referendum for autonomy: fifteen million citizens will be called to the polls and will go to vote, peacefully and quietly, not as happened in Catalonia. Official and legal referendums, sanctioned by the Constitution, which aim to retain more economic resources on our territory: less centralism and more autonomy for the territories and regions. This is the direction we must take, in Italy and in Europe, to govern better and to create development and well-being for our citizens.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the idea of a fiscal compact is not as new as it sounds here, because it is a very old rule: if you spend more money than you have then you will in the end cause problems either for yourself or for someone else. That is why, in solidarity and in respect for others, you need to have stability in your economy. If you spend more than you get, then you either need to reform and spend less, or reform and earn more. A third alternative is of course to borrow money, and if you borrow money then your deficit will increase and your debt will increase.  I say this because reality is much more important than the rules. The rules we have are important, but reality is the really worrisome thing, because if you are increasing your deficit and cannot finance your public spending then it is the deficit and the increased deficit that is creating the austerity, not the rules. The rules are there in order to hinder the road to austerity. The rules are there to make us keep together around a sound and stable economy, sound and stable public finances, and I can never understand, if we look at all the experiences we have had, when countries – Sweden at the beginning of the 1990s, others in recent times – have nearly not been able to finance the public spending, not because of the rules but because of reality. That is why we need a fiscal compact in order to safeguard our economies.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Mr President, it should be remembered that the Budget Pact and the Stability Pact are largely a consequence of the common currency. I would like to share with you a bit of historical reflection on what was the abyss that the European economy faced with the common currency a few years ago. The Stability Pact and the Budgetary Pact are the consequence of the fact that the differences between the different countries, the macroeconomic divergences between the north and the south, made it necessary to maintain the euro under a series of conditions. I don't like many of them. I do not like the Pact as a whole, but it is the consequence of a common currency, ladies and gentlemen. And this is what we have to ensure, that we have a common currency with which to face the crisis, the future, globalization. And I, who am a European, want a common currency and I assume some conditions. And these conditions, now, will be able to be discussed because, by incorporating the Treaty into Union law, we have the possibility that Parliament can discuss it, change it, make it more flexible, evaluate it. Yes, we have parliamentary control. It is not easy, but the Treaty is intergovernmental, Union law is parliamentary law. I would like to refer to those who are opposed to the common currency and to the people who want to return to the lira or the peseta or the franc. What future do you offer your citizens by returning to the lyre? Make it clear to the citizens, because there is no economic future outside of the common currency, even if this requires sacrifices.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it is simply astounding to me that so many in this House want to permanently impose an austerity straitjacket on the entire EU by inserting the fiscal compact into the Treaty. The evidence is stark. The fiscal compact has prolonged the downturn, stifled growth and ensured that stagnation is the new normal. It has tied the hands of governments in the diverse countries now entirely reliant on the European Central Bank’s one-size-fits-all monetary policies, which are running out of steam. Where are the strict rules to reduce current account surpluses that will inevitably cause a new debt crisis? A single Member State could veto this move to enshrine this failed model into the treaties, but will any government in the EU have the courage to say that the German model does not work for us? The failed austerity model has caused the rise of the far right in Europe. It has led to a crisis of legitimacy for the EU institutions. We have the opportunity to shake off the straitjacket. If we do not do so, the EU’s political and economic crisis will become a political and economic catastrophe.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! It goes without saying that the Fiscal Compact will be incorporated into Union law. Just as it was stipulated in the Maastricht Treaty that the euro is the currency for all member states of the European Union that meet the criteria, the intergovernmental fiscal pact stipulates that its provisions should be incorporated into the European treaties as soon as possible. I would even like to say that we should get a general clause from the Council that all European laws are drawn up and adopted on the basis of Union law and thus with the participation of the European Parliament. All measures for the further development of the monetary union and the economic and social union, for the creation of a banking, capital market, fiscal and investment union must take place on the basis of the Union law. Because only then is their democratic legitimacy given by this chamber of citizens. In order for our single currency to function, we need healthy public budgets, market discipline and clear guidelines for macroeconomic and budgetary surveillance. We must therefore make the Stability and Growth Pact less complex, but more binding and more effective. We need stricter and more effective sanctions against those who do not comply with what we have jointly decided on. The step-by-step plan for completing economic and monetary union, the so-called Pierre Werner Plan of 1970, states that all measures can be achieved within a decade, provided there is sufficient political will on the part of the member states. This political will is what matters, no more and no less.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as a convinced pro-European I agree with those who have recalled that the treaty is in force but it is not a Community treaty and therefore excludes this Parliament and the Community institutions from any power. Therefore the discussion must take place and it must also be clear that the current review will have to define new parameters that take into account the current scenario. When the fiscal compact was ratified by governments, states and national parliaments, the European economy was in a disastrous situation: I remember the spreads that rose to hundreds and hundreds of points and therefore the risk of concrete bankruptcies by the states was ongoing . Today the economy is recovering, thanks to the great efforts that have been made. Austerity measures are not enough, indeed they must be forgotten. It is necessary to face in a different way a revision of the economic policies of the Union, which on the one hand guarantees investments by the European Union, in the face of fiscal discipline and of the States, investments not only private but also those that provide public goods and produce occupation. It is only if there is a budget of the euro area, which makes it possible to relaunch growth and employment, that the issue of debt reduction can be tackled, which is certainly necessary, but in a framework that does not create poverty and hostility towards the European institutions. . Thirty seconds President because I was personally insulted. To Mr. Valli, who is not very honorable, I will answer on social networks that this is the only thing he knows ..... (The president interrupts the speaker)

name: Laura Agea (EFDD).
text: - Mr President, as head of delegation of the 5 Star Movement, I reserve the right to ask what statements my colleague Bresso made, addressing my delegation, and I want to know from the recordings whether the offenses she has addressed to us, while her colleague Gualtieri was speaking, correspondto what you said, because I reserve the right to act on behalf of my delegation.Nobody offended her!Behavior appropriate to this House and to the citizens whom you also represent.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Colleague!There is Rule 164 in our Rules of Procedure. If you feel personally addressed or offended or inaccurately portrayed, you can ask the President here to make a personal statement after the debate to rectify that.But you cannot interrupt the ongoing debate in which Mr Chountis has now had to wait.Please take a look at the rules of procedure, request the personal statement and then hand it in.It will be recorded.You have three minutes to do this, which is more than the few seconds you now had.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fiscal pact is the denial of democracy in the European Union. The signatory Member States transfer power over their economic policies to the EMU institutions. All countries are obliged to adopt, even in their Constitutions, balanced budget rules and automatic spending cut-off mechanisms. The result is a single policy, the neoliberal policy of balanced budgets, low social spending, reduced incomes, liberalized markets and privatizations, reduced rights and the bargaining power of workers. The results and consequences of such a neoliberal policy have been experienced by the Greek people for the last seven years in a dramatic way. Ladies and gentlemen, the people of Europe, if they want economic policies that serve their social justice and prosperity, must break with the policies and structures of EMU and the euro. If they want to restore democracy, they must go beyond the limits set by the European Union, the Stability Pact and the Fiscal Pact.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues!We have a bug on the board.The next speaker will be Mr Stolojan.Just allow me to say goodbye.That was my last meeting as Vice President.I was elected to the national parliament.I do not want to do that without thanking those who have helped me: the officials in the Directorate-General for the Presidency, the ushers, the interpreters for their excellent work and the technology that usually makes everything run smoothly here.I hope that you will place the same trust in my successor as you do me.Thank you very much and I hope the debate will continue.(Applause)

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the financial crisis and the unsustainable public debt crisis have reminded us that there is no substitute for budgetary discipline, fiscal discipline. All those who believed that they could sustain a well-being through continuous indebtedness were awakened to reality by the crises we went through, and the simple ones suffered the most, the pensioners, the people from both the public sector and the sector. private. The example of Greece is edifying. Greece, after years of suffering, has put its house in order and is currently showing positive results. Therefore, it is necessary for this fiscal compact to become the rule in European Union legislation, because before you think about fiscal capacity, solidarity, you must be aware that you must respect the rules on budgetary discipline, fiscal discipline and, after that is, if you follow these rules, think about solidarity within the European Union. That is why we are waiting for the Commission's proposals in December on transposing the fiscal compact into European law.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: - A common currency requires a common policy and not rigid rules. I stand in a Dutch tradition, once started with a liberal Minister of Finance, Gerrit Zalm, when I advocate a structural budget policy in which shocks are absorbed in the budget and are not averted by cutbacks and people have to fear for their jobs, and where the aim is to achieve full employment in good and bad times. The euro can do so much better. The euro should have brought countries together, but has made countries grow apart. The euro should have provided stability, but economies have proved fragile - especially in the south. So I argue for a euro with 1) a clear, delineated, European responsibility through a buffer fund, through shock absorbers to absorb the shock, through a European backstop, so that banks cannot overturn countries; but also with 2) a clear European accountability. Because the euro is ours and democratic accountability must be given to elected representatives of the people. This can be done by a European Minister of Finance and not by an unelected chairman of a shadowy euro group. And that can also be done through a fiscal union as currently proposed, but differently from what is currently established. In short, the euro can be so much better and the euro must be so much better.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, fiscal discipline is obviously an essential tool for the success of a Union of 27 Member States which share a common single market and a common currency. Only by maintaining a balanced budget can a country increase its resilience in order to face an economic downturn or a financial crisis. Fiscal rules make our economy stronger not weaker. Having a balanced budget means having more fiscal space when it is needed. It means having funds available to implement structural reforms, not only in bad times but also in good times. The time to repair the roof is always when the sun is shining. My country, Romania, has been part of the fiscal compact since the beginning. Joining it was the correct decision. Let me explain briefly why. The actions of the current government of the country make clear why the fiscal compact is necessary and why it protects our citizens from what is sometimes irresponsible governance at national level. In Romania, the debt-to-GDP ratio has increased by 4 percentage points from 37% to 41% of GDP in less than two years, and structural deficit has increased from 0.6% of GDP to more than 3%. Due to the significant deviations from the budgetary medium-term objective, the Commission issued a warning, and the Council followed. In the case of any country that does not comply with the provisions, the Commission or any other country can take the case to the Court of Justice. The last step is the imposition of sanctions. These current developments, in any Member State, highlight the importance of respecting EU fiscal rules and the importance of imposing them on governments that sometimes work only for short-term objectives. Otherwise, who will carry the burden of the increasing deficit and debt in any Member State? Certainly not the current government which just happens to be in office and which will have been voted out by the time the debt comes to maturity. Then it will be the younger generations who will have to shoulder this debt and who will have fewer options for the future than the previous generations.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: There was a blue card question.I would like to explain that this is a debate on the so-calledthe topic is current and we do not have a blue card formula, nor do we have a catch-the-eye formula.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the inclusion of the Stability and Growth Pact in the Treaties is, in my opinion, not desirable, at least not without in-depth modification of this pact. Because if the TSCG is to be replaced by a treaty which encourages the economic and social convergence of European countries and, more particularly, of the countries of the euro zone, it can only be so by obviously avoiding the resumption of measures such as those which have led to an increase in austerity. For the moment, let's face it, the Commission is only analyzing budgetary data, but no global vision is envisaged. However, it would really be more relevant to take into account all indicators, be they social, environmental or economic, and not just budgetary. By taking only part of the data into account, the TSCG prevents Member States from investing and, as we all know, without investment, no economic recovery is possible. This quite simply means fewer and more precarious new jobs for European citizens. Changing the TSCG is therefore an essential condition for offering quality jobs to as many people as possible and combating growing poverty in the European Union. The fact of seeing the budget as an entity disconnected from the lives of Europeans has created, as you know, unacceptable inequalities in Europe instead of providing solutions to reduce them. So have the courage to end austerity. We can see the damage every day. Restoring the confidence of citizens requires a major social and economic change of course. I think it is high time, Commissioner.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, as emphasized, the legal framework for the fiscal and stability pacts is very important, but only if it promotes convergence at the level of our real economies. From the entry into force of the fiscal pact in January 2013 until today, the result in terms of real convergence of our economies is disappointing. I will refer to specific examples, but I will stress that adjustments and changes are needed to improve the real economy. We need the involvement of the Member States themselves in planning their structural changes and not enforcement, not even one size fits all. "Responsibility" refers to the rules. Yes, the Commission should seek to correct macroeconomic excesses, but this should focus on both excessive deficits and excessive surpluses. After all, the deficits of men are largely the surpluses of others. As far as the Structural Funds are concerned, their connection with the European Semester must be stopped. Those who want to take away access to the Funds are working against the rules that govern their operation, the rules of solidarity and social cohesion. I end with a question: is it possible to get here without a pan-European deposit guarantee?

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Mister President!We have to bear in mind what happened in response to the crisis: social standards were dismantled, trade union rights were undermined not only in Greece, and the whole thing was made possible with an escape from European law.The fiscal pact and the rescue packages were built around the treaties, and democratic security measures under European law were circumvented.So it is obvious that we have to make European economic policy more democratic.We must ensure democratic control in the European Parliament.But for a sustainable European economic policy we need one thing above all: a departure from the neoliberal austerity policy - at the back of the employed, at the back of the weaker.Public investments in the future, for example in education, must be exempted from the strict rules of the Stability Pact.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The fiscal pact was created to lower the debt level in the European Union and to dampen new indebtedness. If you are now talking about whether you want to integrate the fiscal pact into the European treaties, then you have to look first: Has the fiscal pact actually proven itself? Did it work the way it should have worked? Did it work that states that exceeded their new borrowing ceilings time and again had to pay sanctions, as provided for in the Fiscal Compact? And then we find out that that was not the case, that these states were given respite again and again, that they turned a blind eye, that in the end, when the treaty made it mandatory that we must now impose sanctions, they said hat: Great, now we are imposing sanctions, namely sanctions of zero euros. What kind of politics is that? Every driver who goes a little too fast has to pay EUR 30, 40, 50 for a small offense, and here, when entire states do not step on the brakes in time, when they exceed their indebtedness, their new indebtedness limit over and over again, then they get a fine of zero euros! Vice-President Timmermans said earlier in the debate on the Catalonia conflict that the European Community is based on the rule of law. That is certainly true. But we not only need the rule of law, we also need the reliability of the law. We need to know that government action is predictable. But if the state repeatedly acts arbitrarily, if the laws are so flexible that you can simply disregard their spirit, then the reliability of the law is not far off.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this was an important opportunity to exchange views on the integration of the fiscal compact into the Union’s legal framework. The fiscal compact emerged five years ago as a stop-gap solution at a time of deep crisis. Even though today our European economies are sailing in calmer seas, the basic tenet of the fiscal compact, of pursuing responsible fiscal policies, remains entirely valid. Moreover, bringing the fiscal compact into the body of the EU fiscal framework will help enhance the resilience of the EU going forward, and it will do so in a way that ensures more accountability. But we also have to acknowledge that the incorporation is unlikely to be a routine operation. As we could also see from today’s discussions, there are serious political and legal implications at stake. This is why on the Commission side we are looking carefully into possible options. Once again, let me thank you for your persistent interest in this matter.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, in order 664 the deputy Mercedes Bresso declared during her speech that I would have insulted her at the beginning, when my debate was announced.As for me, I have revised my speech and made no insult.So I would like, in case, to see the recording of this debate and to declare that I have not insulted anyone, because I have respect for all the parliamentarians who are in here.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The very serious economic, social and political crisis that the European Union is experiencing has been aggravated by austerity policies that have had strong pro-cyclical effects and have generated unsustainable levels of unemployment, poverty and inequality, especially in the countries on the periphery of the euro area. In this sense, the feared incorporation of the "Fiscal Compact" into the legal order of the Union, with all that this entails in terms of budgetary constraints enforceable before the Court of Justice, represents a very serious danger that must be countered. We are convinced, in fact, that the "Fiscal Compact" commits governments to pursue budgetary objectives that are technically unrealistic and unsustainable from an economic, political and social point of view, and this because the austerity measures that will become necessary following its unfortunate inclusion in the EU legal system, will be so drastic as to fuel a further recession and a consequent disaffection of citizens towards the EU. I therefore fully share the alarm raised by my colleague Marco Valli, and I agree with the appeal made to the European Parliament to support our battle against the "Fiscal Compact".

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - I welcome the European Commission's proposal to include the fiscal pact in the EU legal framework. Its conclusion as an intergovernmental agreement in the midst of the financial and economic crisis was necessary to overcome the lack of unanimity in the European Council, but the Community method must be maintained and not weakened. The European Union has always developed dynamically when it has adhered to this method of decision-making, and has always stumbled when decisions are based on intergovernmental agreements without the necessary transparency and scrutiny by the European Parliament. The Union must carry out its tasks in the context of a single institutional framework and avoid the creation of new institutions outside that framework. Incorporating the fiscal pact into the EU legal framework will ensure not only better democratic scrutiny of budgetary discipline rules, but also greater legitimacy for the European institutions.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU 'fiscal pact' is a step towards further EU integration. The single EU budget, the European Minister for Finance, the European Monetary Fund, in competition, but also in the same role as the IMF, is the endless shielding of governments' anti-labor policies, under the constant supervision of the EU. budgets - within the framework of the "Stability Pact" - in case of exceeding, obliges states to instant anti-labor measures, with "automatic budget cuts", new cuts in salaries, pensions, social spending. In combination with the "ESM" and the "Euro Pact" for the suffocating European Union supervision until the repayment of the public debt, memorandums of permanence are promised. The demands of various governments, such as the government of SYRIZA - ANEL, champion in the implementation of memoranda, to exclude from the stability pact of "development" investment expenditures do not concern in any case the easing of anti-popular policy, but subsidies with big money and fro that the people will pay again with successive storms of measures and taxes. The experience of the peoples can be a criterion and basis for a counterattack of the labor-popular movement. Capitalist development without lasting sacrifices of the peoples, just development within an unjust system does not exist.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Proposals for reforming and deepening the EU have proliferated. In the European Union, formally or informally, they must be acknowledged and taken into account. Especially with regard to the eurozone, most proposals envisage further deepening of central management structures on a federalist basis. They then put a bracket around meaningful consolidation strategies. Yet, these should be considered the top priority. One reason why it’s not happening follows from the dogma that the eurozone cannot operate as a transfer union. But that is the rationale behind any federal arrangement covering a monetary union. The US, a mature federal system, operating as a transfer union, has less controls on the policy options available to its component parts, than the eurozone already has as of now. Meanwhile, the “terms of trade” defined by the eurozone’s implicit internal exchange rate, actually make it a sytemic ‘transfer union’ from south and east to north and centre. The EU should aim to bridge these contradictions through a political settlement. Firstly, it must focus on convergence between economies and consolidation of existing euro management structures. Otherwise, deepening of the eurosystem will remain either a chimera or a further curb on the weaker, smaller Member States.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the presentation of the Annual Report of the Court of Auditors - 2016 (2017/2765 (RSP)) I cordially greet the President of the Court of Auditors, Mr Klaus-Heiner Lehne.Once again, welcome to Commissioner Oettinger.

name: Klaus-Heiner Lehne
text: President of the Court of Auditors. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! This year the European Court of Auditors is celebrating its 40th anniversary. As the debates in this House this week have shown, the political, financial and economic framework of the European Union has changed significantly over the past four decades. Recent challenges have put our citizens' trust in European and national institutions to the test. We, who work in these institutions, have to react to this and find solutions, each within the framework of his or her own area of ​​responsibility. In this regard, I am pleased to announce that I will report positive things. In our estimation, the EU financial statements for 2016 give a true and fair picture. The 2016 revenue was not affected by any material errors. Above all, however, the estimated error rate in payments to the detriment of the European budget has continuously improved. Around half of the European editions we audited in 2016 showed an error rate that was below the materiality threshold of 2%. As a result, instead of failing, we issued a limited positive opinion on the 2016 payments. This is our first qualified audit opinion since we began producing an annual statement of assurance in 1994. It represents a major improvement in EU financial management. In concrete terms, this means: The estimated total error rate in EU spending in 2016 is 3.1% compared to 3.8% in 2015 and 4.4% in 2014. So this is a continuous improvement. The so-called entitlement-based payments, which are made when certain conditions are met, make up around 49% of EU Expenses and showed error rates of less than 2%, below the materiality limit. This includes direct aid for farmers, studies and research grants and personnel costs, to name a number of examples. In contrast, the so-called reimbursement-based payments, which are made to reimburse expenses, were found to have higher error rates. While actions taken by Member States and the Commission helped reduce the overall estimated level of error, we found that sufficient information was available to prevent, or detect and correct, far more errors. In our opinion, this means that no additional control levels are necessary, but the existing controls must be carried out properly. Let me also issue a warning, however: the total amount of payments that the European Union will be required to make under future budgets, at EUR 238.8 billion in 2016, was higher than ever before. The elimination of this backlog and the prevention of new backlogs should be the focus of planning European spending for the period after 2020, i.e. in connection with the next MFF. It is important for our citizens to know that public money is being spent lawfully. But just as important - perhaps even more important - is for people to know what they got for their money. Did building a particular road or airport in a particular location or any other infrastructure really make sense? Did it actually create jobs and growth? In order to answer these questions, we are increasingly placing the focus of our work on the efficiency and effectiveness of European spending and programs. In many areas of the European budget, control systems have been implemented serve to prevent, detect and correct errors, improved in recent years. This also offers us an opportunity to further develop the declaration of assurance with the aim of being able to rely more heavily on these control systems in future with regard to the correctness of expenditure. In this way we will be in a position to provide Parliament and the Council with more and better information as part of the examination of the European budget. Ladies and gentlemen, in the coming decades we will continue to act as guardians of European finances and the interests of our citizens. We will continue to be an independent voice, pointing out areas that work well but also speak uncomfortable truths. In a world where misinformation and data manipulation is becoming increasingly common, the European Court of Auditors will continue to provide reliable and impartial information. Let us work together at every stage of the legislative and budgetary cycle to ensure that the European Union delivers results efficiently on issues that matter to the citizen.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, Mr President Lehne and Mr Lazarou from the European Court of Auditors, ladies and gentlemen! For us as the European Commission, the annual report and the recommendations of the European Court of Auditors are an important basis for our further work. This cooperation between the various organizations - the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council and the Court of Auditors and, on the other hand, the Commission - is bearing fruit, I believe. The fact that we have had the reliability of our accounts confirmed for the tenth time in a row, that we are showing a further decreasing error rate, that the audit judgment of the Court of Auditors confirms us, shows that we are not unsuccessful together. A long process also seems to be worth it. The European Parliament can be proud of the contribution you have made in the context of the discharge procedure. Over the years you have ensured that we as the European Commission have become better through constructive and critical support. The Court of Auditors makes very specific proposals to ensure that public procurement is carried out correctly, that agricultural areas are measured correctly, that financial aid in the research sector reduces the bureaucratic burden for researchers and thus increases the value of our research program. One thing is clear: we are always closely dependent on the Member States. We have a shared responsibility, and the administration of the Member States and their regions is often jointly or even primarily responsible with us for the correct use of funds and the implementation of procedures. The limited audit opinion is very good news for us. But we don't say complacent: "That's it", we want to make our work more efficient and further improve it. Mr. President Lehne has Mentioned the backlog and the difficulties it created in the 2014 and 2015 budgets. As of today, we are again in the final phase of this period in a comparable development, because the funds that are available in 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018 will probably no longer be needed. In the next few days we will be proposing changes and making cuts to the current budget, but also to the budget for 2018. We must learn from this for the next period - the Member States and us. And perhaps a new MFF shouldn't be adopted just before Christmas last year. A year earlier would mean safety for everyone involved, and preparation and driving speed would be better from the first year. We are happy to say that we want to learn from all of the Court's proposals. And the issue of success orientation: the effectiveness and the question of added value, which we will and must justify, are in the foreground in all infrastructure measures, in cohesion programs, in new tasks such as migration - the added value that we at European level compared to the provision of tasks and funding at national level. We want to draw the House's attention once more to the reflection process. For the next budget framework we have presented a paper in which we identify options and where we value your opinion. That applies to the number of years of the next MFF, that applies to the priorities in the next MFF, that applies to the headings, and it also applies to programming, which in turn is crucial for the execution of the contract and for orientation towards success. My thanks go to the Court of Auditors. I believe that the basis for good consultation has been laid here in this House today over the next few weeks. (Applause)

name: Joachim Zeller
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear President of the Court of Auditors! First of all, many thanks again to you, Klaus-Heiner Lehne, and Mr Lazaro and the staff of the Court of Auditors for the annual report for the 2016 financial year. 322 pages of the Court of Auditors' annual report provide detailed information on how the Commission and the Member States are responding worked on the EU budget. Even if it is a look back, the Court of Auditors report, together with the special reports of the Court of Auditors, which I would like to mention again at this point, offer a very good analysis of the achievement of objectives in European programs and projects. The error rate, which has fallen again from an average of 3.1%, is encouraging, and we of course welcome this positive trend. A look at the error rate alone is not enough, however. Mistakes often tell more about the complexity of rules than they do about abuse and fraud. We must therefore further simplify the rules governing our financial management so that the beneficiaries can benefit from the European budget more quickly and effectively. The highest error rates continue to occur in the area of ​​shared management. I therefore appeal to the Member States and their administrative authorities to work harder to avoid errors. The considerable delays in entering the current funding period and the associated blatant payment arrears, as mentioned and noted by the Court and the Commissioner, are cause for concern, because 2016 was already the third year of the current funding period. This can lead to a considerable excess of payments at the not too distant end of the current funding period. It is therefore high time to work on the processing of the backlog so that the goals that are to be achieved with the European budget can actually be achieved.The current debates have limited my speaking time, which is why I can only comment on the Court of Auditors report in a very general way.But in the next few weeks we will discuss this opulent work in detail with the Commission and then lead it to a report by Parliament.Thank you again for the work you have done and for the constructive cooperation!

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Mr Lehne, Mr Commissioner Oettinger, in this plenary session where debates abound about - say - bad news for the European Union - a Brexit that is stalled due to the failure of the party that led to it and an example of how to obtain political gains secessionists not complying with the law and the rule of law and manipulating the goodwill of the people - however, we can only congratulate ourselves on excellent news that it took only 23 years to achieve. And success is due to you, Mr Lehne, to all your colleagues at the Court of Auditors and to all of us in general, since this Parliament and the Committee on Budgetary Control, especially, have fought and beaten the copper to achieve it: an opinion not negative, but only subject to reservations, which finally gives us a true picture of reality. A rigorous verification in the methodology of the result of huge investments in the improvement of internal and external audit systems, in the training of human resources at all levels, in visits and interviews with heads of institutions, with heads of Member States, regions , city councils, companies, universities, etc., to go, year by year, discharge after discharge, reducing the initial two-digit percentage to the current one, for 2016, of 3.1%; where, finally, we have, in addition, clearly data that allows us to compare, rigorously and according to the mandatory international standards for a public chamber such as the European Court of Auditors, which can be comparable, and not pears with apples. Hence, I am particularly grateful for the clarification on the need for another formula or format to control financial instruments and not to continue confusing European citizens. I also appreciate how, little by little, we have been getting the data and its presentation until we are able to present no only an error rate with better methodological justification but, above all, to indicate and encourage action to European institutions and Member States, knowing that the information they already have could have helped them to improve this error rate.Finally and quickly, I just ask you - and I promise our support for this - to improve the methodology in the internal systems, to improve the presentation and the pedagogy - that are comparable with those of the Member States, that the citizens understand.And, finally, the leap into the 21st century: a methodology for results and to be able to measure the budget based on results, which you have very well explained to us.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors for his annual report regarding the financial year 2016. You have done a great deal of work. According to your report, there has been improvement in the estimated level of error in payments from the EU budget. You have issued a qualified opinion on the 2016 payments rather than an adverse one. The overall level of error for EU spending was estimated at 3.1%. Your report indicates that ‘entitlement payments’, made for meeting specific conditions, and accounting for about 49% of EU spending, show levels of error below 2%. These payments include direct aid to farmers, grants to students and researchers and staff costs. However, higher levels of error were found in ‘reimbursement payments’, made for economic, social and territorial cohesion. The estimated level of error here was 4.8%. For ‘natural resources, world development, the environment, climate action and fisheries’ it was 4.9%. Action by the Member States and the Commission reduced the overall estimated level of error. However, sufficient information was available to further prevent, or detect and correct, many errors. If this information had all been used correctly the levels of error for economic social and territorial cohesion and for natural resources and ‘Global Europe’ would have been below the 2% threshold. We strongly encourage the Commission to continue focusing on performance and simplification because simple rules reduce errors and increase the effectiveness of EU funding.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: for the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Mr Lehne, Commissioner, this year's European Court of Auditors' 2016 Annual Report is not only an annual report, but also a jubilee report. It bears the serial number 40, which is truly respectable and also worthy of a small celebration. But I'm not sure if it's all about opening champagne. The general public probably would not understand, but all of us who deal with European finances could celebrate, for example, the fact that, after 23 years, the annual report contains a statement on the reliability of the operations carried out instead of a negative one. And in the case of entitlement and administrative payments, the error rate is even well below the materiality level. Reducing the error rate in the spending area of ​​the European Union budget is one of a number of priorities that we would like to achieve on a permanent basis when spending EU funds in accordance with the principles of sound financial management. The second, in my opinion even more important aspect, is the focus on performance and added value of all projects and investments. A new and difficult task before the European Court of Auditors is to find an answer to the question of whether low error rates automatically mean cost-effective, efficient and effective spending of EU funds. The European Commission and the Member States face the same task. The delay in the current multiannual financial framework results in a historic maximum of unused Union funds. We will certainly agree that the resources of EU citizens must not be spent solely on the purpose of exhausting national allocations. On the contrary. Let us work to ensure that the almost unbelievable, unspent EUR 240 billion is used to fund quality projects that will bring real benefits and added value to the European Community. Only then may it be time to slam champagne.

name: Dennis de Jong
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Thanks to the President of the Court of Auditors for presenting his annual report, which is a very important document as it forms the basis for much of our work on budgetary control. I would like to admit that in the past the discussion on the report has lingered on the finding that the Court of Auditors was once again unable to give an unqualified opinion due to an excessive error rate. That is not good, because it is of course more than just an error rate. That is why I welcome the fact that the Court of Auditors now wants to look more broadly at value for money. At the same time, the attention for the regularity of expenditure must not be allowed to diminish. If I have to read in a footnote that you can also say that the actual error rate is not 3.1 but 5.1 percent, then something is wrong. This concerns the justification of the expenditure from the financial instruments. The Court itself states that 2.3 billion euros was spent on expenditure outside the competent period, so without there being a legal basis to which Parliament has also approved. How is that possible? The same applies to the reservations of the Commission services, which increase from 21 to 26 percent of expenditure. Then it would be the first time that the Commission itself is more critical than the Court of Auditors. That would really be unique. How does the Court explain these contradictions? And can we continue to trust for the next 40 years that the Court of Auditors will check very precisely and critically for regularity?

name: Indrek Tarand
text: im Namen der Verts / ALE-Fraktion. - Herr Präsident, sehr geehrter Herr Lehne, Herr Kommissar Oettinger! Each step is taken from the other side of the body. In short, another report from the Court of Auditors makes us happy, because there are fewer errors and only 3% of the money goes to expenditure that cannot be justified. It's nice and encouraging. And it is interesting whether the costs that we are carrying out for inspections in Luxembourg to find out these audit results are also justified. And, as you know, my long-standing idea has been that, since the first round of enlargement in 2004, the European institutions have been unnecessarily inflated in favor of nation states. We know that every country must have a commissioner, every country must have a member of the Court of Auditors, every country must have a prosecutor or a prosecutor, and so on. In my opinion, this is not at all necessary if we want to think of the European Union as an effective organization. And I would ask Mr Lehn to definitely carry out an audit next year and analyze whether it makes sense to consider seven former Prime Ministers of Eastern European countries as Vice-Presidents of the Commission, where Commissioner Oettinger does all the work anyway and only vice-presidents, and whether it makes sense to have an Estonian auditor in the Court. who has dropped the airline, the shipping company, the train company, the ferry company, whatever, and now she controls us. Please audit this. Because, in fact, in the sense of the European Union, it is possible to do it in turn - once in Germany there is a commissioner, once in France, once in Estonia, once in Latvia. Thank you!

name: Marco Valli
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Court of Auditors for its report which every year gives us elements to assess what is the expenditure relating to European Union funds. We acknowledge the decrease in errors even if we must say that many of these errors, which very often are errors that are cited as bureaucratic procedures, put in a wrong way and reported in a wrong way, in reality, then, perhaps there were real fraud, such as procurement procedures that favor certain companies over others, and possibly including ineligible expenses and lack of supporting documents. And this, however, is only part, because the European Commission, as you know, is limited to taking these documents and paying the bills. He obviously doesn't have the ability to control everything. And everything, from what I understand, is delegated to the Member States, which I invite - obviously, to avoid the Commission then telling us what we must do - to create a more transparent and certification control system on the funds. Because, in all the States where I have been, in recent years, especially in the trips of the delegations, I have noticed how this system is very much based on conflict of interest, where the certification and control authorities are then appointed by the policy itself, such as it is logical that, however, at the same time, in many cases, parochialism or non-transparent relations are created. So it is up to the Member States, at this moment, from my point of view, to act to prevent a Commission from interfering in the future in the use of these funds.

name: Olaf Stuger
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Demonstrable tax money has been thrown down the drain for years. That is not surprising, because there is an error in the system. If you look at subsidy money, for example: it comes from Brussels, but must be checked by the member states. They have no interest in that, so it does not happen. Nevertheless, the Court of Auditors thought it had to give approval with a lot of engineering and flying and a lot of tricks, and that is unjustified. What does not make sense at all is that Mr Brenninkmeijer suggests opening champagne or prosecco. Because essentially nothing has changed compared to the past years. All I can think of is that we have European elections in 2019 and you can't start early enough on the good news show. But the worst thing I think is that Mr Brenninkmeijer, the Dutch member of the European Court of Auditors, is thus pulling one of the last rational bastions in EU violence - the European Court of Auditors - into the subjective political morass.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I want to welcome the report, the President of the ECA, and indeed the comments made by Commissioner Oettinger here today. This is a very important part of our procedure where we discharge on an annualised basis the expenditure under the EU budget. It is important not just because of the role of Parliament, but also the role of the Council in making sure that EU taxpayers know that their funds are being used properly in key areas of public expenditure. But we should never forget that we are talking about a very small fraction of total public expenditure in the European Union. That means that we should use that expenditure to the very best of our abilities and for the objectives of the programmes that we set out. This particular report this year is welcomed, not least because of the qualified opinion that the Court has been able to make – that is a very welcome development – but also because of a very significant improvement in the error rate. It is not fair for Members of this House not to recognise the fact that, over the past three years, we have seen effectively a 25% reduction in the error rate, from about 4.4% to 3.1% over the past three years. That is a significant improvement and it is something to be recognised and something to be celebrated in this House and within the Council. There are issues that we need to address. As other colleagues have said, the question of simplification of rules is crucial to reduce the error rate. One of the issues outlined in the report from the ECA this year is this question of outstanding payments. Substantial amounts of commitments are made into the future and the money is not spent. We have got to make sure we can get on with the task of spending those monies. But there will be enormous challenges, not least because of the question mark of the budget into the future on the question of Brexit, but also because we have to review the MFF. I think if we do this in a sensible and deliberative way, we can make sure that not only can we shine a light on what is bad about expenditure, but also shine a light on what is good and learn from that.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and, in particular, the President of the Court of Auditors and I wanted to welcome his new approach which I think has been a breath of fresh air. Also, of course, I wanted to welcome this year’s positive report. It is welcome to see that not only do we have a positive report, overall the error rate is reducing and I am also pleased to say that the error rate for economic, social and territorial cohesion is also reducing, down from 5.2% to 4.8%. Of course we would all like to see further reductions in the error rate in the future.  It would be useful to know what actions have been taken which have led to the biggest fall in errors. I think that this information could be shared between Member States and then used to reduce errors in the future. I believe this is something we should be looking at and focusing on.  It is also important to note, as the President said, that Member States have the information to detect and reduce the error rate, maybe even below the 2% threshold. So again it would be useful to know why Member States are not using the information they have, which would allow them to reduce error rates even further.  On the important question of measuring performance – and I think this is something we all welcome, we talk about it all the time and we need to find better ways of measuring performance in the future – of course a number of measures have already been introduced to measure performance. Previously in its report the Court does suggest the Commission continues to look at other ways of linking payments to performance. I would be interested to know from the Commission and from the Court what those measures might be.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I thank Klaus-Heiner Lehne and his team for their report and I am delighted to note that this is the first audit to receive a qualified positive opinion since the system began in 1994. This is welcome, but there is always room for improvement, and I note the continuing weakness in the areas of joint management. In public finance it is important to strike the right balance between rigorous checks and controls and, on the other hand, ensuring public funding is readily available. So for that reason, controls need to be proportionate rather than a barrier to entry. This is taxpayers’ money, and it is our duty to ensure that it is spent in a manner that is both beneficial and fully compliant. This is a most encouraging report and I urge the Commission to ensure that they continue the steady improvement that we have seen over recent years.

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the budget, as the annual financial framework of revenues and spending, is of significant importance for the implementation of the EU’s policies. In this regard, the European Court of Auditors’ (ECA) general conclusion that the revenue and payments for 2016 were legal and regular, with some exceptions for the payments, is good news. The estimated level of errors in the payments made from the EU budget for the last three years shows a clear trend of steady decrease from 4.4% to 3.1%. The bulk of the errors are concentrated within the areas of economic, social and territorial cohesion as well as in the competitiveness for growth and jobs. We should underline that, in the ECA’s report, there is an early warning on a number of issues that we should be careful about. The challenges are mainly related to budgetary and financial management. Delayed implementation of the programmes could create, at the end of the current programming period, a huge backlog of outstanding payments. We need a budget that provides more flexibility to respond to unforeseen events, such as financial problems, disasters and refugee crisis. We should continue our efforts towards a budget focused on results, in order to achieve maximum effectiveness of spending the EU’s financial resources.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE).
text: - I would like to thank Mr Lehne for the work he and his colleagues and their many assistants have done to deliver this calculation report. We are indeed hearing good numbers. 3.1 percent is a good figure, better than last year, even lower than the lowest figure ever in 2009. But I agree with Mr De Jong's questions. That note about 5%, the Commission's reservations: I would like to get an explanation of that in the course of the discharge procedure. Now, everything can be better. 3.1% is a good result, without any doubt, but we know that the vast majority of resources - 80% of resources - are co-managed, where Member States and regions bear responsibility. In the annual report we read that an extra effort is already being made to recover funds. This is undoubtedly under pressure from Parliament, but it can be done better. I have a question for Mr Oettinger: how can we together - the Commission and Parliament - force the Member States and the authorities of the regions to take better responsibility, to ensure that that margin of error is effectively below 2% comes true? Mr Oettinger, I think we must work together on this point, Parliament and Commission, and remind Member States and regions of their responsibility.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the qualified opinion on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the EU accounts is still a very, very serious thing indeed. If any business were receiving a qualified opinion on its accounts, it would rightly be worried. Even more worrying, I suppose, is the way that we have arrived at this situation and why it was not the even worse adverse opinion as previous years. Firstly, it is argued that errors are not pervasive, claiming that the errors are only high for reimbursement-based expenditure, but it needs to be pointed out that the errors exist across every single area of spending within the EU budget. The error rate of 3.1% is still over EUR 4 billion of taxpayers’ money every year. If it were just that, it would still be bad enough, but it is not just that; there is an awful lot more to it than that. First, the error rate does mask a far, far higher rate of projects where there are errors. For example, 23% of EAGGF payments had errors, but the error rate reported is 1.7%. For Rural Development and Environment, 39% of projects have some errors within them but the error rate then is 4.9%, so it masks something that is somewhat bigger. Second, about a third of all errors are not quantifiable and those therefore do not show up in the statistics. Third, foreign aid sent via third-country governments is just assumed to have zero error, which for accountancy purposes is understandable, but in practice is palpable, self—evident nonsense. Fourth, we are only talking about money spent outside of the rules and waste of the money within the rules is not counted. Fifth, the errors in special instruments are not included, which would have led to a 5.1% error rate, rather than 3.1%. Sixth, the burden of proof is unequivocal errors, so these are only the errors that we are absolutely certain about. There are clearly more in practice.  Then we see that, in effect, there are blind eyes being turned left, right and centre. On page 47 of this report, we are reminded that pension contributions are not ringfenced but used to fund the general EU budget. Now that is something which, in any context and in any organisation, is not good practice. This is also the reason why we have the whole pension liability question in the Brexit debate in the first place, since this has not been done properly at EU level for many decades. I now have deep concerns with regard to the Court of Auditors because auditors should always be completely independent of the organisation that they audit. That is the whole point of auditing. But now we are in a situation where nearly 40% of the Court are ex—politicians, and most of those are ex—MEPs. When all but six of the auditors are former civil servants, it starts to undermine a level of public confidence in those same auditors. Throughout this report the perspective seems to me to be one of excusing problems so when 31% of projects contained errors on page 260, the report instead described them as 69% error free. It is not the job of the auditors to excuse failings. It is the job of auditors to expose them.

name: France Jamet (ENF).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, according to the report of the Court of Auditors on the 2016 budget execution, we can welcome the overall level of error which is, we are told, at 3.1% , or nearly 4 billion, which is not nothing. On the other hand, while the expenditure of the European Union in 2016 amounted to 136.4 billion euros, the auditors tell us that its leaders have already committed for expenditure to the tune of 238 , 8 billion euros. We therefore have no further possibility of action until the end of the mandate. You noted earlier the exceptional nature of these results. I note here a dramatic recurrence. While our fellow citizens are subjected every day to demands of austerity and austerity imposed by the Union, the latter, without being criticized here, allows itself freedoms with its own management. So this double standard is unbearable. The technocrats of Brussels on one side, the people on the other, fiscal hell for some, and grace for others. This administrative steamroller that impacts our daily lives must be radically reformed, in our opinion. This is the vision we stand for in the interests of our compatriots.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this Parliament benefits highly from the expertise of the Court of Auditors. The annual report gives us a great amount of useful information and plays a crucial role in the discharge procedure. It acts as a basis for a thorough analysis of the implementation of the EU budget, so congratulations on this important work.  This year we can once again be mostly satisfied with the Court’s report itself and the conclusions it incorporates. However, despite improvements in the error rates, there are still some weaknesses. I have to emphasise in particular the issues of compliance and performance. Indeed, the issue of the error rate as such can be seen as of relative importance. Unfortunately – a confusing case of non-compliance regarding the eligibility period of disbursements within financial instruments – the estimated level of error for cohesion expenditure does not necessarily represent the true state of its implementation. It has to be made clear, this is not the Court’s fault. The Court is not at fault here. It did what it was bound to do within the legal interpretation. But the point beyond that is this: the European citizen has to have direct access to clearly understandable numbers, and there we still have some work to do.  We do appreciate that the Court has begun to put more emphasis on performance audit and this is the right path. In the coming years we still need more data on actual results and added value, also in and by Member States.

name: Arndt Kohn (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President Lehne! I too would like to thank you, Mr Lehne - on behalf of the European Court of Auditors - for the audit work you carried out and the detailed report. The limited positive audit opinion, which the Court of Auditors has issued for the first time since 1994, shows that there has been significant progress in the management of EU funds over the past few years. For around 50% of the EU funds used, the error rate is below the materiality threshold of 2%. And even if the error rate in the area of ​​cohesion policy is 4.8%, here too we can see clear improvements compared to previous years and learn from your recommendations for the future. Cohesion policy must continue to play an important role in the next multiannual financial framework in order to promote social, economic and territorial cohesion in Europe. Whether the people live on the Black Sea, the Atlantic or the North Sea, with these funds Europe becomes visible and tangible. Cohesion policy should continue to be largely based on grants. Financial instruments are more difficult to access, especially for smaller recipients such as municipalities or SMEs. Parliamentary scrutiny of EU finances is essential. European citizens have a right to know how and what the money has been spent on. Transparency creates trust, and it is only through the trust of the citizens that we can regain enthusiasm and support for Europe.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: - It has already been mentioned here: the error rate is decreasing, but there is still more than EUR 4 billion in European subsidies that are not spent according to the rules. So we have to deal even more efficiently with tax money. That is why I propose that we go for even better and clearer European rules. These should ensure that it becomes easier to assess the ultimate effects of the expenditure and thus also better prioritize. Secondly - and this has already been mentioned, among others by Mr Staes - it is important that the Member States also take their responsibility: after all, they are responsible for 75% of the money spent on behalf of the European Union. Finally, we must also ensure that only those expenditures are incurred that have European added value. When I see that we are still going to spend 12 million euros on free InterRail tickets, I think that unfortunately we still have a long way to go here.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, thank you, Mr President and Commissioner, thank you for presenting the annual report of the President of the Court of Auditors, Mr Lehne. To our delight, we can say that we have finally reached below the materiality threshold in error margins. Maintaining this positive trend requires constant work, because, as we all know, development stops with satisfaction. For this reason, a good annual report inspires us to believe that even better results can be expected if and when we continue along the same careful lines in the European Union's economy.
