However, the annual report highlights concerns that we need to pay more attention to in the future. They have certainly been prepared by the Court of Auditors. One significant factor is the record high payments in this year's budget, which also means an increase in the number of inspections. We must continue to guarantee the principle that EU citizens have the right to know where their money is being spent. They must also be able to trust that these funds are being properly controlled. In this view, the appropriateness of funding is also emphasized, and I would like more and more efforts to be made to ensure that taxpayers' money is not only used in a technically correct way, but also that the use meets the objectives of the funding.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Court of Auditors does not send them to say this time either: it clearly tells us that there are financial resources that should not have been disbursed by the European Union as they are not used in compliance with the law and, plus, in the areas of natural resources, therefore, rural development, environment, action for the climate and fisheries and economic, social and territorial cohesion. Europe has made several errors in payments. Mistakes made with public money. What mistakes? Lack of essential documentation, ineligible expenses, conflicts of interest and irregularities in procurement. Then there is another important aspect that is underlined by the Court, namely the complexity of the financing mechanisms, which has continued to increase. The Commission justified the massive increase in the number of subjects and instruments participating in the financing of the implementation of European policies and programs with the need to face new challenges, such as immigration, Brexit, climate change. We honestly don't find the link. So much so that the Court finds it difficult to manage, control and report expenditure, with the real future risk of not being in a position to understand how the money is actually spent. In fact, as many as 1052 financial instruments had already been established at the end of 2015, the use of which has not always been precisely traceable. Furthermore, the Court points out that one of the main advantages of these instruments, namely the ability to use the funds more than once, has not been fully exploited. In conclusion, therefore, there are too many gray areas, too many errors in the accounts of the Union budget. We must intervene and avoid repeating the practices that have led to anything but exciting results. The Union, which so often speaks of transparency and efficiency, has a duty to use e the money of European citizens effectively.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We can be satisfied with this Court of Auditors report because it gives us hope that the work we are doing here will lead to something. So I think this is one of our better days today. What worries me is that budget management problems have become very acute in recent years. The question of RAL, question n + 3, the question of some Member States. That is why, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, I would ask you to identify the problem where it is so that we can take targeted action. We believe that not all Member States have the same problems. That is, we need to know where the problem is and what we can do to help solve that problem. This is very important to us. I am concerned: your report says that only three quarters of the authorities have been appointed by the Cohesion Fund. If there are no authorities, how can the money be spent? Why are we doing this and why are the authorities not named, Commissioner? What can we do? Performance reporting - congratulations on the chapter. But we cannot be satisfied with the fact that we only partially achieve the goals in 50% of the Structural Fund projects. But it would be important to know which part we get and which part we don't. Of course, we cannot be satisfied with the fact that the costs are not reasonable in a third of the projects in rural areas. The table with which you - it is a great job - shows the number of performance indicators per billion is almost satirical. The bigger the program, the lower the performance indicators, the smaller the program, the higher the expectations. It is of course also clear that this will go wrong. Of course, we also need a remedy here, it definitely cannot stay that way. A challenge: financial instruments. Commissioner, we cannot wait until 2020 for financial instruments to know what is going on.

name: Георги Пирински (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court, for the first time since 1994, when the Court drew up a statement of assurance, it gave an opinion with reservations on budgetary expenditure in 2016, and not as in the whole period so far - negative. Whatever we say, the reason for this opinion is the clear downward trend in the error rate found by the Court. In response to the imperative need for a results-oriented budget, the objectives and indicators of the budgetary framework need to be drastically reduced and optimized as soon as possible, in line with the Court's explicit recommendation. We will look forward to the concrete actions of Commissioner Oettinger on this task. It is high time that the Commission also implemented the Court's strong recommendation in a series of reports to present a comparative analysis of financial instruments and grants in terms of the final effect of their implementation on the budget. Only on this basis would we be sure that we are properly selecting the appropriate means to successfully meet the individual objectives that are to be included in the multiannual financial framework after 2020.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Gentlemen, Chairman! Commissioner! As I take the floor in this debate, I would like to express my thanks to President Lehne, who is here, for the high quality of the audit material provided to Members, as well as the analyzes which are based on them. In particular, I would like to highlight two important special reports. The first concerns help for young farmers and shows the huge problems of agriculture in Europe. Despite enormous expenditure from the EU budget, about a thousand farms, mainly family ones, disappear every day in the EU. The village is aging, only one in five farmers is under 45, European agriculture is on the way to liquidation. Deep changes to the CAP are needed to save them. The second is the excessive deficit procedure report. It shows that governments teaching others to learn the rules - I am thinking mainly about the government of France - are themselves breaking EU rules that the public finance deficit should not exceed 3%, and public debt should not exceed 60% of GDP. And the European Commission tolerates this breach of the rules: although it should launch sanctions, it does not do so. When you compare this with the determination with which the Commission attacks my country, Poland, for imaginary problems with the rule of law, you can clearly see that it applies double standards.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, ladies and gentlemen! As every year, the Court of Auditors provided us with a comprehensive report on its activities. It is more comprehensive than exciting. As shadow rapporteur for the budget of this House, I found the ten pages devoted to the chapter on administration to be extremely poor, especially when you look at the 316-page overall report. Of course, the 0.2% margin of error is a great thing, even when compared to the overall margin of error, which we heard is 3.1%. Nevertheless, the European Parliament has an amount of EUR 1.9 billion to cover the costs. I would go into more detail, but unfortunately this annual report does not provide the basis for me to go into further detail. I find it regrettable or perhaps a little questionable that the hearing with Mr Klaus Welle will probably give us more information than this report. If the one who is being controlled is the main source of information, I think something is not going quite right. There are some questions left for me. I would like to mention only a few: What about the driver service? What do we do in the field of translators? What about building security? How do we feel about the fragmented parliamentary administration? And one of the most important questions: will there ever be only one seat of the European Parliament?

name: Iris Hoffmann (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, Mr President Lehne! I would of course also like to thank the European Court of Auditors for their work, which has resulted in the overall error rates for EU spending falling continuously. According to the 2016 annual report, the European Commission has all the information it needs to reach the 2% materiality threshold in the future. The Commission must continue to orient itself towards this and work hard on it. The same applies to the European Development Fund. I am pleased that the allocation of funds has improved compared to previous years. However, European development cooperation no longer only consists of the development fund. A number of trust funds have been established in recent years. The new European Fund for Sustainable Development is also intended to complement development cooperation so that investments in the billions can be generated for Africa through European guarantees. I expressly welcome the establishment of these financial instruments and consider a more ambitious policy in this area to be extremely important. However, it is not always easy to keep track of these complex guarantee and donor structures. Of course, that does not make the audit and parliamentary control of these instruments any easier or simpler, and it damages the transparency of European development efforts. In the long term, we should achieve uniform development cooperation under the umbrella of the EU budget.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to greet the presence of the President of the Court of Auditors, Mr Lehne, and congratulate the Court on its 40th birthday. I have withheld a piece of information from his intervention that has satisfied me, which is the increase in public confidence in the institutions, Commissioner. I believe that this data has a lot to do, in some way, with the way in which the institutions use the resources that the taxpayer makes available to them. With other colleagues, I congratulate myself on the reduction in the error rate, that there are no generalized errors, that, indeed, the control measures have taken effect; But, as Mr Zeller or Mrs Grässle said, it is important that we not rest on our laurels - even if they are deserved - but that there is also a lot of work to do. One of them is to put the accent on these 280 billion, which is a record in terms of deferred credits, and which should make us reflect on how to improve our procedures; in the increase in global financial risk, which increases considerably and which also affects the European Union; and, of course - it has been pointed out here in this debate - in the number of financial instruments, the number of entities that benefit from the budget resources. I think that compromises, in some way, accountability and transparency. We will continue to work in the coming weeks on the preparation of the discharge report. The report of the Court of Auditors is, of course, a precious instrument, and we must continue working so that we have a more efficient, more agile and more transparent budget.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Thank you, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, for having today presented the annual report that we are all awaiting because it gives us an accurate picture of the use of the Union budget. The fact that in its analysis the Court is paying increasing attention to data on the performance of results is, for the European co-legislators, a fact of fundamental importance, because it helps us to outline the priorities in the choices and changes, in some cases necessary. of the various policies of the Union, especially those relating to the Structural Funds. It is certainly comforting to know that there has been an improvement in the general financial framework, a sign that the reforms requested in the past by this Parliament, if properly implemented, can contribute to a constant improvement of the Union budget and its implementation, with a error rate, we have seen, steadily decreasing. I would also like to underline the importance of a specific audit in the areas of security of citizenship, whose budget, although it constitutes a relatively small part of the Union budget, nevertheless represents one of the fundamental support tools for the Member States. A final consideration: the qualified opinion provided by the Court following its control activity regarding the use of the Union budget for 2016 has a particularly significant value, I feel I can say, since it contributes, albeit indirectly, to increase citizens' trust in the European institutions.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Mr. President! The European Court of Auditors plays an important role in building citizens' trust in the European Union, especially in recent years marked by negative, often dramatic events, which are cynically used by populist politicians to build their own strength at the expense of European Union unity. And it is against the background of these phenomena that the proper functioning of European institutions and the proper economic management of citizens' money become particularly important. Therefore, the results reported in the European Court of Auditors' report for 2016 are to be welcomed. Let us hope that the creation of a chamber responsible for the control of financing of the European Union and administration and the Quality Control Committee will additionally improve the quality of control procedures. Just like the establishment of chambers, each dealing with a specific thematic area, it will allow the process of specialization to be deepened. It should also be noted that in 2016 all the annual and special reports were carried out as planned and that as much as 80% of them were published within the prescribed period. It is also important that in 2016 nearly 70% of the special reports were prepared in less than the current target date. We will be able to initially evaluate the effects of these organizational efforts next year.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! President Lehne made such a characteristic sentence that the goal is to tell the truth. We have not questioned any of the sentences in this report, so I understand that this report is true. And the truth is: we just function better and better; The Commission is working better and better, the Court of Auditors is getting better and more efficiently assessing the results of this Commission - that's the truth. Of course there are mistakes and you could say that every mistake is one mistake too many, but not in that reality when we have the Commission, when we have Member States, when we have life alone and when we also have a legacy about which Commissioner Oettinger he said, i.e. the delays from 2014-2015, which translated into 2016. Please note that this report does not mention the word "abuses", but in this report there are phrases such as "effects", "functioning" and in fact we should here in In the spirit of this report, we should speak not so much about spending money as about investing money, because here the Court of Auditors also shows us the rate of return or the European added value. And I would like to heartily commend the words of warning that President Lehne spoke of regarding the future and also those dilemmas that Commissioner Oettinger spoke of, how to avoid the mistakes that happened in 2015-16 in the next two years.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank and highlight the fact that the error rate for budgets actually fell from 3.8% to 3.1% in 2016, despite the Court's finding of a number of irregularities. But as the predecessor has already said here, I think there is a huge shift here and that shift is quite positive. The annual report on the implementation of the budget also shows that the absorption of available EU funding is still the biggest problem. And here I think we agree with Commissioner Oettinger that we need to focus on this in the future. Drawing on European funds is often a tool of various criticisms and misinterpretations. There is talk all the time about the so-called simplification of European money. I think some of the results have come. But some need to be changed even further, but especially in the Member States. I still see a huge administrative burden in the Member States here. I still see changes in the conditions for drawing, excessive control of funds, where some funds are checked five or six times, and the unpredictable outcome of the whole procedure. The fact that the Member States do not draw money as they should creates a financial deficit and, in practice, there is a lack of resources from the EU, which is reflected in the macroeconomic situation of the countries and the EU as a whole.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, thank you for the report. I think it's a very complete report. Regarding the Report on the protection of the Union's financial interests, there is an improvement over the previous year: 15% fewer irregularities, 8% less in amount, but the amount is still quite large, over two billion. It is obvious that the activity of punishment is important, of identifying the problems, but, at the same time, the activity of prevention is also important - I think. And for that we have to work a lot on regulations. There is already an attempt to simplify through the amendments to the Financial Regulation, but I think that the Court, through a special report, can think of other instruments, because having the same type of regulations, the same rules in all regulations for all funds would be a very good thing, to have cost standards set in each Member State, to try, perhaps, to turn the public procurement directive into a regulation and then an electronic activity - everything, from the application, from the evaluation, from approval, from tracking, to be done electronically - I think it would bring great benefits. I will make some such proposals in my report.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the European Court of Auditors for making this step forward with the annual report. It is much more analytical – something which I appreciate. It is not just numbers and percentages, but it has very fruitful information for us. Obviously, dropping the percent of error rate is something which we should celebrate and appreciate. By saying this, I am not saying that we can shift the focus from fraud prevention to something else, but we could have other priorities as well: for example, fully-fledged audit reform. What do I mean? First: single audit. Let us prevent double checks by managing authority, certifying authority and audit authority by same beneficiary. Why not introduce risk based audit as well? Those beneficiaries with a proven track record and those who are object of audit of national authority should have lighter control, otherwise we make their life worse. Another thing: we can have simplified audit as well, introducing more simplified approach and removing unnecessary requirements. After all, I think we are moving in the right direction, and I am sure cooperation between the Court of Auditors and the Parliament will go in even greater perspective.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, without a doubt, the Court of Auditors is one of the most important institutions in Europe. However, some comments should be made in the context of the current report. Thus, I believe that both the Court of Auditors and the other European institutions, but especially the national authorities of the Member States, must be concerned with the implementation of single and simplified procedures at European Union level regarding the spending of public money. Defining errors is extremely important. Not every error should lead to the suspension of payments for beneficiaries, as preventing their occurrence entails strengthening the role of guidance and coordination of the Court before the role of control. The unitary approach to legislation at Union level is absolutely necessary, so that, either in Bucharest, in Prague or in Rome, there is the same interpretation on a legal norm. It is inadmissible today to have a certain conduct that is incriminated as a violation in Romania, but, at the same time, to represent a correct and legal approach in other states. National audit and regulatory authorities must be explicitly prohibited from adding conditionalities beyond European rules, as this always leads to excessive bureaucracy. Changing the procedures during the implementation process of a European project is another limiting factor for the beneficiaries of European Union funds. However, I am convinced that good cooperation between European and national authorities can lead to a streamlining of the process of absorbing European funds.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, we do take the work of the Court of Auditors very seriously, because it strengthens the confidence of the citizens of the Union in the way European funds are managed. But this confidence is being shaken in Greece, Mr Oettinger, Mr Lehne, because citizens are watching NSRF projects that have been funded enter privatization. Specifically, Fraport, in the context of privatization, has taken the airport of Thessaloniki, where NSRF projects worth 400 million euros were executed, the airport of Chania, where NSRF projects of 100 million euros are still being executed, and NSRF projects of 30 million euros in Skopelos. Is this possible? We believe that NSRF projects should not be privatized. Not even five years have passed. I want you to look at these issues because they are serious, because Greek citizens believe that the regional airports in Fraport are being sold out in this case.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, of course, and I want to congratulate you. I think we need to criticize when we need to criticize and congratulate when things are good. On the other hand, I come from the private sector and I know very clearly that prevention is better than the finding that you make, and it is not your fault, you find some mistakes. I believe that the European and national system and regulations need to provide for more rigorous ex ante control, because you can no longer correct, possibly helping us for the next period. Then, it was said here, I think it is very important, Commissioner, to see the law on public procurement. I was an entrepreneur, I accessed European funds, I have already amended the Public Procurement Directive, but it doesn't work. I tell you for sure, there is a possibility of making mistakes. Also, normative acts - an entrepreneur, an SME, if he wants to take European funds on various axes, has various procedures. The possibility of error increases, and then I think that if you come with additional measures, and especially the Commissioner, - that I am addressing you now because, of course, the Court of Auditors can find new control mechanisms -, we need to have uniform, simplified procedures in the European Union - bureaucracy costs and can lead to error.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the discharge exercise is highly important to the European Parliament, and it must be carried out with the utmost political commitment and objectiveness, while putting at the centre and safeguarding the financial interests of the European Union’s citizens.  With regard to the Court of Auditors Annual Report 2016, I am glad that sustained efforts have been taken which generated an improvement in the estimated level of error in payments made from the EU budget, with a decrease from 4.4% to 3.1%. Furthermore, pertaining to the level of error, I am particularly glad to see that a slight decrease has been recorded in the area of European Development Funds as well.  Finally, I believe that while efforts have been mobilised, there is still scope for improvement, for instance, further action should be oriented towards the way in which the European Union’s added value could be measured.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I thank the Court of Auditors for the report.These reports are always very important to us, because they help us to improve the system of managing funds from the EU budget.Of course, what we have to pay attention to is that in addition to focusing on the legally earmarked in accordance with the rules of use of funds, we also focus on the efficient and timely use of funds and meeting the set goals and results.That is why I appeal to the Court of Auditors to make as many recommendations and assessments as possible in its audits as to how far the European objectives in the Member States have been met through the use of European funds.If we create new jobs, if we reduce youth unemployment, if we achieve growth and development that is long-term and sustainable, that is what I must look out for together.Likewise, if we are simplifying the system, it is important that auditors follow this, for example when it comes to simplified cost methods.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you Mr President of the Court of Auditors for the comprehensive annual report. The Court's qualified opinion reflects a major improvement in the management of the European Union's finances: the percentage of overheads was further reduced and for 2016 payments the Court did not issue a negative judgment, but a qualified judgment. This is the first time this has happened since the Court began issuing a Statement of Assurance. However, I regret the lack of flexibility of the European Union budget in responding to unforeseen events, as highlighted by the Court itself: just think of the crisis in the agricultural sector, to which the European Union has not been able to give the right answers in quickly. Another negative aspect concerns the complexity, however increasing, of the financing mechanisms of the European Union: if this trend persists, there is a risk of compromising compliance with the reporting obligation and the transparency of the European Union budget. The Commission must accept the Court's call for a greater focus on performance. EU funds must be spent in accordance with the principles of sound financial, economic, efficiency and effectiveness.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear President Lehne! We have heard the multitude of constructive and critical contributions, but also the words of praise, and we will evaluate them thoroughly within our services. I will limit myself to a few points. Firstly, we really want to maintain our ambition to further reduce the error rate. In other words, a certain shift towards the topic of effectiveness, success-relatedness, performing should not mean that one disregards the error rate. Hopefully further progress can be achieved here. With the new authority and public prosecutor's office, the EPPO, represented here by Mrs Jourová later, we have an instrument which, as a partner at European level, will certainly help fight fraud, embezzlement and corruption in the European budget. Second, I share the view that new financial instruments - guarantees, loans - are an addition to our leverage and are not a substitute for cash. For important projects in important member states, especially in rural areas and with municipalities, you will still need co-financing and cash from the European budget for the implementation of projects. It was rightly pointed out that still not all Member States have named the authorities responsible for implementing the program. We have written to these Member States, we have made progress, but not yet at 100%. We are working on this, but ultimately we in the European Union are dependent on the constructive cooperation of the Member States. We do not have our own administration or our own sub-structure in the regions. And that the member states do not call up the structural funds that are actually due to them - basically the voter should notice how successfully his administrations work, and this for himself Make voting decisions that are pending a benchmark. We can only advise the governments in the regions of the member states. We help where we can with words and deeds. But the application for funds, the implementation of projects and then the invoicing of the amounts paid - all of this is the responsibility of the Member States, the regions, which are the contact persons for us on the spot, but which we cannot replace. We are counting on hopefully more cash outflows over the next two years and the timetable for the next MFF - we talked about it yesterday - should be crucial. We shouldn't take our time, we shouldn't deliberate in the new parliament, we shouldn't deliberate until 2020. I urgently want to propose that this Parliament, together with the Council and the Commission, use the time from spring next year until the European elections to have as much, if not all, decided and in dry cloths for the next budget period so that implementation can then be carried out by January 1, 2021 and has no wasted time at the start of the next budget. Simplification in the procedures was critically noted here. This is exactly what we intend to do with our “omnibus” and the reform of the Financial Regulation. We are counting on the fact that Parliament will lead the deliberations to a result in the next few weeks and that the corresponding financial support procedures can then be simplified as early as next year. Otherwise, many thanks for your cooperation. I look forward to the deliberations that will now take place in the Technical Committee on the basis of this. We are ready to give any further answer, including in detail, to the Members.

name: Klaus-Heiner Lehne
text: President of the Court of Auditors. - Mister President! First of all, I am pleased that you are feeling better and that you are back in your chair up there. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think that has also become clear in the course of the debate, but I want to say it again here: A restricted audit opinion does not mean that everything is perfect, it is a clear yes, but. Anyone who reads the report will also recognize that we have looked at an overall picture and have found significant changes and improvements within the framework of this overall picture. But if you go into the chapters and look in detail at what we have written in detail in the report, you will find that there are a large number of points in which concrete improvements are pending and must be made. The error rate is just one factor in the overall view. We have endeavored - and that is also our task - not to decide or judge anything within the framework of a mathematical guillotine, but rather a so-called professional judgment to make a qualitative assessment of the overall picture. That is why we have come to what we have come to. I also want to make it very clear: this is not our performance. As a farm, we only had to judge facts and the picture. It is essentially the improvement of financial management by the Commission. Of course we contributed indirectly to that. We, that is the Court of Auditors, but above all you too, ladies and gentlemen, former colleagues in the European Parliament. The sustained insistence on this in your work - above all in the Committee on Budgetary Control - and the interaction between our organs - that can really be said - have resulted in this improvement. I think we can be really proud of that, and it is a process that we want to continue, which shows that our efforts have borne fruit. I think that has already been explained in detail by Mrs Ayala Sender, Mrs Dlabajová, Mrs Gräßle and Mr Liberadzki. Regarding Mr de Jong's remarks: he asked the questions, some of which were already part of the Committee on Budgetary Control last week. Why did we rate the issue of financial instruments in the bugs as we did? Thats is quite easy. I want to say that again here: we have of course referred to the errors that we have criticized here in the past for reasons of transparency in the current report - that is clear - but it would not be factual to include them again in the error calculation was justified for the very simple reason that it was a question of atypical errors, errors the cause of which is essentially to be found in another legal conception that we do not share. Against the background, a corresponding inclusion in the error rate would simply not have been objectively justified. Here, too, we applied our professional judgment to this question. Perhaps I would like to point out again what significance this estimated error rate actually has. Perhaps that should be said again clearly here in the plenary. We are not saying that the error rate is exactly 3.1%. We apply a mathematical statistical procedure in which we evaluate the results of a sample and at the end - and you will see this when you read the explanations in the report - say that the actual error rate is in a corridor with a probability of 95% moved between 2.2 and 4%. What we have stated is the 3.1%, which is quite simply the relatively most likely mean. That's all. You have to do this in the context of the overall picture, if one has to judge this question, of course also take it into account. I think this explanation is important. Mr Tarand raised the issue of the size of the institutions. It is not up to us to decide, it is decided by the primary legislature of the European Union, the constitutional legislature, in other words, in plain English, the Convention, in which the European Parliament can also participate, then the Intergovernmental Conference and, moreover, the parliaments of national member states. That is something that we cannot judge what the constitutional legislature of the European Union thinks on these questions. Mr Vaughan, Mr Staes and Mr Ashworth raised the issue of the details, the causes of the errors. In view of the limited time we have, I do not want to comment on that now, but leave that to the debates of the committee. I share the view that has been expressed by Mr Takkula, Mr Salafranca and others - it is also in the report: we need more understandable, clearer, simpler rules and figures. We will endeavor - Ms. Gräßle mentioned this - in the future, with the new approach that we have, to give more country-specific information and also more concrete information on causes. One comment on Ms. Schmidt - which is unfortunately no longer there now - that I have to make. It is actually quite obvious that we have only dealt with the administration in a few pages in this report. Because with an error rate of 0.2% you can't say much. The report essentially deals with the issues of legality. The questions that Ms. Schmidt addressed relate more to questions of economic efficiency. I will simply give it back: if we, as the Court of Auditors, are asked to carry out a detailed performance audit of the administration of the European Parliament as part of the discharge decision, then of course we will seriously consider. That’s where it belongs. It’s a profitability issue and not a legality issue. Therefore, this question that was asked there is probably also answered. The subject of control density was raised by two colleagues, Mr Zdechovský and Mr Novakov. That is actually a central problem, and you will have gathered from what I said at the beginning: Our goal in future is to pay more attention to the quality than to the quantity of the control mechanisms. We are well aware of this problem of excessive control density, because that can of course also be an obstacle to the implementation of European policy. So it is better to have more quality than quantity in this question, better and fewer controls than too many control levels, which are theoretically possible. That is a very specific, clear goal. Mr Buda has called for uniform application, a Europe-wide regulation. I think we are in complete agreement on that, there is no question about that. Mr Caputo mentioned something that we have also mentioned repeatedly: the lack of flexibility in the overall budget. This is an issue that I hope will be addressed in the MFF. Finally, I would like to thank you once again for the interesting and valuable debate and, above all, for the encouraging words with regard to our work. I will inform my colleagues of this in tomorrow's quorum meeting and I am sure that it will be met with great approval and joy.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the EU budget. During the final accounting procedures of each financial year, the regularity and efficiency of the use of funds and the management of each institution are checked. The final accounts for the financial year 2016 will start with the presentation of the European Court of Auditors' annual report in committee and then in plenary. It is a very important result that, for the first time since 1994, the European Court of Auditors has issued a non-negative opinion on the regularity of the underlying transactions for 2016. A significant part of the expenditure audited in 2016 was not characterized by a material level of error, and the estimated level of error in payments from the EU budget has also steadily improved over the last three years: from 4.4% in 2014 to 3.8% in 2015, 2016 decreased to 3.1% in. The European Court of Auditors states in its report that the Union's annual accounts for 2016 give a true and fair view of the financial situation of the Union. As the person responsible for several final accounts in recent years, I consider the discharge procedure, as the main parliamentary tool for financial control, to be very important in ensuring the regularity and efficient use of the Community budget.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. - In its 2016 report, the European Court of Auditors reports that there has been a gradual improvement in the estimated level of error in payments made from the EU budget. The auditors issued a qualified opinion on the 2016 payments, not a negative opinion as in previous years. About half of the EU expenditure audited in 2016 was error rate below 2%. In addition, the auditors issued an unqualified opinion on the reliability of the entire 2016 report. In 2016, EU spending amounted to € 136.4 billion. This expenditure represents around 1% of the gross national income of the Member States and corresponds to approximately 2% of the total public expenditure of the EU Member States. This year's qualified opinion reflects a clear improvement in EU finances. I welcome the Court's decision to continue to improve its methods of controlling the EU budget.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing.- I am pleased that in 2016 the error rate was reduced to 3.1%.However, I am a little less happy that we find the greatest degree of error again in programs and policies where shared management takes place.In this respect, it is necessary to point out again the spending area of cohesion policy, where the percentage of erroneous payments is up to 4.8%.Although this is not always an intentional mistake, I must express my disappointment that this percentage also includes intentional damages and misinterpretations of the rules.I am very sad about the fact that the Czech Republic is one of the examples of ineligible beneficiaries in the official report.The fact that these scams are happening in several countries does not mean that they are acceptable.I therefore believe that the Commission, the Court of Auditors, OLAF and, more recently, the European Public Prosecutor's Office will not ease and reduce these ugly statistics.

name: Soraya Post (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Court of Auditors in its special report last year with the title ‘EU policy initiatives and financial support for Roma integration’, stated that although Roma integration is explicitly mentioned in the European structural and investment funds, additional efforts are required from the Commission and the Member States to make sure that this will result in projects which contribute to Roma integration on the ground. As the Court of Auditors report says, the Commission should make sure, when checking the relevant operational programmes, that the supported projects are inclusive and fight segregation. Segregational practices should be clearly described and explicitly excluded from funding under the structural and investment fund framework and particular attention should be paid to education and housing projects. Unfortunately, we can see that most mainstream programmes systematically fail to reach out to young Roma (for example the YEI or Erasmus+). We would, therefore, call on the Court of Auditors to check the performance of EU employment and education programmes in a more thorough way and on a regular basis.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation drawn up on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on a draft Council regulation implementing enhanced cooperation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office (09941/2017 - C8-0229 / 2017 - 2013/0255 (APP))(rapporteur: Barbara Matera (A8-0290 / 2017))

name: Barbara Matera
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have finally reached the last stages of a legislative process that began with the Commission's proposal for a regulation dating back to 2013 and which saw us engaged in a grueling work of research and intense activity, made up of negotiations, compromises and many meetings of comparison. With a legal basis based on Chapter Four of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters, the European legislator felt the need to combat crimes affecting the financial interests of the Union, through a special legislative procedure, aimed at establishing a European Public Prosecutor's Office. Fraud, corruption and other illegal activities affecting the financial interests of the European Union constitute a serious threat to the achievement of the objectives which, through the use of its own resources, the Union itself intends to achieve, and therefore require effective law enforcement, which also requires recourse to criminal law. The establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office undoubtedly represents a fundamental step in the process of European integration in the area of ​​criminal law, a requirement that arises from the numerous crimes that are perpetrated. According to data provided by the European Commission, European national budgets lose nearly € 50 billion in VAT revenue each year due to cross-border fraud. Organized crime, acting on a transnational level, earns billions of euros by circumventing national rules and avoiding prosecution. Just think that in 2015, the Member States identified and reported fraudulent irregularities to the Commission for an amount of around € 600 million. The tools available to national prosecutors in the fight against large-scale cross-border financial crime are limited. The new Union Prosecutor's Office will provide coordinating action, conducting rapid investigations across Europe and exchanging information in real time. Criminal investigations into fraud and other crimes against the EU budget are often hampered by divergent legislation: national law enforcement authorities, prosecutors and judges in the Member States decide on the priorities set by national criminal policy and on the basis of national competences. As a result, the level of protection of the Union's financial interests differs significantly from one state to another, with often disappointing results. OLAF has warned us that the rate of successful prosecution of crimes against the EU budget varies from 19% to 90% from state to state. The coordination activity of the prosecutor will thus lead to greater effectiveness in the prosecution of all crimes that have a cross-border dimension. With regard to this perspective, I join the many voices that in recent weeks have expressed the need to expand the powers of the European Public Prosecutor as soon as possible. This was stated by President Juncker during his State of the Union address, declaring that he considered it more appropriate than ever to entrust the new European Public Prosecutor's Office with the prosecution of cross-border terrorist offenses. This was also repeated by the President of the French Republic, Macron, who at the Sorbonne, a few days ago, proposed the creation of "a European anti-terrorism prosecutor". A position therefore in line with the wishes of the President of the European Parliament Antonio Tajani. Expanding the range of powers of the Prosecutor's Office will create the conditions for greater efficiency in the fight against organized crime and terrorist organizations: to be united, to be stronger, and to be less vulnerable.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to be in the Parliament today and, believe me, that is not just a courtesy phrase. Just before the summer break, after long and extremely complex negotiations, the Council reached a political agreement to set up the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) as an enhanced cooperation, and I am happy that 20 Member States have already expressed their agreement to bring the protection of financial interests to an entirely new level through the establishment of a new Union body. The EPPO will considerably step up the current efforts to fight crimes against the EU budget such as fraud, corruption, money laundering or VAT fraud, since its work will be more effective, especially as regards cross—border criminality; more criminals will be put behind bars; more money will be recovered; and more money will be put to the right use. The regulation provides a robust set of procedural rights of suspects and accused persons. The EPPO will become the centrepiece of a new system, joining together national law enforcement, judicial authorities and EU actors such as OLAF, Eurojust and Europol. It will be to the benefit of the EU as a whole, the Member States and European taxpayers. Criminal investigations are essential to counter the most serious forms of abuse against the EU budget. The EPPO will carry out this task on the basis of a truly European investigation and prosecution policy. OLAF will closely cooperate with the EPPO to ensure complementarity of their respective mandates. The missions of the EPPO and OLAF are clearly defined. Strong energies will need to be created in order to allow both the EPPO and OLAF to perform their tasks in the most efficient and productive manner. There will be no duplication of work. On the contrary, I believe that the result will be a significant enhancement of our capacity to tackle fraud. The Commission has just transmitted, on 2 October, the evaluation of the OLAF Regulation and is analysing the need to adapt the OLAF Regulation to ensure that OLAF can cooperate smoothly with the EPPO and has the tools it needs to fulfil its mandate. Also, Eurojust will continue to play an important role as a crime fighter in Europe, focusing more on other forms, such as the trafficking of human beings or drugs. I am therefore pleased to see that you are advancing well on the Eurojust reform under the leadership of the rapporteur, Mr Voss. We would not be here today without the Parliament’s strong support. I would particularly like to thank the Parliament’s successive rapporteurs on the EPPO, Mr Iacolino, Ms Macovei, Ms Matera, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs, for their tireless efforts for a strong, independent and efficient EPPO. I would, of course, also like to thank Ms Reding for her efforts, because I took over the EPPO from her in a very good condition, ready to be finalised. I would also like to thank Ms Grässle and Mr López Aguilar for their crucial work, in particular on the Anti-Fraud Directive, which included serious cross—border VAT fraud in the scope of the material competence of the EPPO. The EPPO and the Anti-Fraud Directive are two sides of the same coin. They are constitutive parts in our joint efforts to better fight crimes affecting the EU budget. The Parliament made its voice heard in key moments during the negotiations and improved many important aspects of the regulation. For instance, you have ensured a clear delineation of competences between the EPPO and the other European actors; helped to design appointment procedures and introduce permanent chambers which guarantee the EPPO’s independence; ensured a robust judicial review of the EPPO’s procedural acts, or made sure that, from the beginning, the EPPO can cooperate on a solid basis with non—participating Member States. But the Parliament’s involvement does not stop here. You will have your say in the selection process of the European Chief Prosecutor, as well as in ensuring the general political accountability of the EPPO’s activities, and you will have a decisive say on its budget. I have no doubt that this House will continue to support the EPPO in its operations. As President Juncker said in his State of the Union speech, there is a strong case for tasking the new European Public Prosecutor’s Office with prosecuting cross—border terrorist crimes and, as announced in the letter of intent, the Commission will issue, in the next year, a 2025 perspective – a communication on a possible extension of the tasks of the new European Public Prosecutor’s Office to include the fight against terrorism on the basis of Article 86/4 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The Parliament will debate this question in due course. I am convinced that the Members States that can participate in the EPPO but are still missing will soon see that this is a game changer and will join. We will welcome them with open arms – the sooner the better, and they know it from me. Your vote tomorrow will allow the Council to move to the final adoption of the regulation at next week’s Justice Council, and it will allow the Commission to start setting up the EPPO so that, by 2020, the first cases can be investigated and prosecuted. I would like to thank you for your support and to encourage you to give a strong consent to the EPPO regulation presented to you.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! Indeed, after four years of negotiations, the time has come: tomorrow we shall vote on the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. An important step towards a common European judicial area, yes, a great day for Europe as a whole. Especially when you briefly review the much longer history. For example, more than 20 years ago - in 1996 - Parliament called for the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and as early as 2002 the Commission presented a Green Paper on its creation, which states, among other things: “Should the credibility of the European project not be damaged , the Community must guarantee its member states and European taxpayers that fraud and corruption will actually be prosecuted, including criminal law. ”This is exactly what it is about: Crimes against the financial interests of the EU such as subsidy fraud or cross-border VAT fraud are not peculiar offenses! The annual damage runs into the billions, but we all pay the bill as European taxpayers. It is really high time to act. Parliament can only say yes and no to the negotiated text, but the Member States did not have a blank check from us. We closely followed the negotiation process and made it clear: the European Public Prosecutor's Office must be able to act independently, it must have efficient structures, and the procedural rights of the accused must be guaranteed at all times. With all this in place, our group will give the green light to the European Public Prosecutor's Office. We want European taxpayers' money to be protected more effectively in the future. It is deeply regrettable, however, that the European Public Prosecutor's Office will only be created within the framework of enhanced cooperation and that only 20 states will be there for the time being. This undoubtedly weakens the European added value.Speaking volumes, I think that the governments of Hungary and Poland in particular do not want the public prosecutor's office.Hungary receives the most EU funding per capita, while Poland receives the most funding of all with 86 billion in 2014-2020.We will therefore fight in the future for all member states to participate so that this European joint project can take full effect.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, tomorrow we will vote on the Rules of Procedure of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. We have been negotiating with the justice and home affairs ministers of the Member States for a long time, precisely because we wanted a strong, independent European prosecutor's office with a clear mission and investigative powers that would allow us to investigate anywhere in the Union. After almost three years of negotiations, the European Public Prosecutor's Office will finally be set up. In short, the cases of cross-border fraud with European money and some terrorist offenses will be investigated from start to finish, including by prosecution, by the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and in cases of conviction, money stolen from our pockets. Fraud in the European Union, I recall, is 500 million euros every year. The European Public Prosecutor will then gather evidence from each Member State involved in cross-border fraud. For searches, for example, in Romania, Romanian law will be followed, for interceptions in Germany, German law, for hearings or other investigations in other Member States, the law of those Member States will be observed. All these evidences made in different states, however, will be admissible and valid in the court that will judge the case, the case with cross-border fraud. This is very important and this will make all these cases investigated and tried much faster. The European Public Prosecutor will have priority over all offenses, including the so-called VAT carousel. For offenses with European funds, minimum penalties are provided, ie judges cannot be sentenced to less than the age limit set in the European Fund Fraud Directive.

name: Roberta Metsola
text: the PPE group. - Grazzi Sur President, grazzi Kummissarju, tad-dedikazzjoni tiegħek fuq dan is-suġġett. Nixtieq ukoll nirringrazzja lil kollegi li għal dawn is-snin kollha tant ħadmu fuq dan il-proġett tista ’tgħid, nibda minn Monika Macovei u Barbara Matera, meta l-gruppana. Dan l-uffiċċju huwa verament importanti. Meta aħna ktibna u imdimna fuq it-Trattat ta ’Lisbona, għarafna l-bżonn li jkun kreat uffiċċju li l-għan tiegħu jkun biex jipproteġi l-interessi finanzjarji tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Kien hemm minn kellu xi dubji dwar dan l-uffiċċju meta bdejna niddiskutuh imma tul is-snin rajna l-importanza tiegħu. U allura jiena nixtieq li nkunu nerġgħu nistgħu nkunu f'din il-kamra u naraw li kull Stat Membru tal-Unjoni Epropea jkun jista Stat Membru tal-Unjoni Ewropea huwa favur li nikkumbattu, il-frodi transkonfinali. Dawn huma affarijiet li aħna kollha nistgħu nkunu on-board sleepħu u jiena nerġa 'napella lil kull Stat Membru, kull gvern li qiegħed ipoġġi fil-Kunsill tal-Ministri biex jara u Jisma' l-appell tal-Kummissjoni Ewropea, ħalli kulħ 'jingħaqad f'dan l-uffiċċju. Jiena minn naħa tiegħi nista 'nkompli nuri l-appoġġ tiegħi, tal-grupp tagänna għal dan il-Prosekutur Ewropew u ser incompomplu naaddabie sabunx ikament verament effiċjenti f'dak li jagımel fl-attivitajiet tiegħ deikop mogħtija lilu fit-Trattat.

name: Louis Michel
text: , on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I for one am convinced that the European Parliament will bring unprecedented added value in the protection of the Union's financial interests and I welcome, in particular, the inclusion, despite certain limits, which I also regret, of VAT fraud in the jurisdiction of the prosecution. Although we have no power of approval on the file, Parliament's concerns have been satisfactorily addressed. A shadow on the table, of course: some Member States have decided not to participate, thus pushing others to engage in enhanced cooperation. However, I would like to point out that the fight against fraud in the Union's budget is a shared responsibility: that of the Union and that of the States. We are talking about the money of European taxpayers here. I therefore find it particularly regrettable, even shocking, that Member States, some of which are among the largest recipients of European funds, can shirk their moral and political duty to do their utmost to fight fraud. As far as I am concerned, I also believe that serious consideration should be given to linking the granting of European funds to the obligation to submit to this duty. In my view, it is inconceivable that the financial interests of the Union do not enjoy a uniform level of protection in all Member States. Fortunately, we still have to congratulate ourselves on the fact that no less than twenty Member States have decided to move forward to protect European public money. This is a crucial step in European integration and in the construction of our area of ​​justice. I sincerely hope that the public prosecutor's office can quickly demonstrate its efficiency and that its powers will in the future be extended to other cross-border threats facing all European states, such as cross-border crime, terrorism and organized crime that we know today.This would be the minimum to extend the skills to these subjects.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Mr.The Lord easily accuses countries that have not entered into enhanced cooperation, although this enhanced cooperation is essentially voluntary.It is easy for you, but it is primarily the responsibility of nation states and Belgium has a judiciary that is often subjected to very severe criticism, also from other states, such as French politicians.Wouldn't it be better to start with restoring the justice system at the national level, before accusing others of not engaging in voluntary cooperation?

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: , answer "blue card".- Mr President, my answer will be extremely brief.I really, very incompletely understood the significance of this question.It was not a question, it was ..., I don't know ... He sent me back to Belgium, he thinks that Belgium is one of the 20 countries which therefore joined forces to do thisenhanced cooperation, so I did not understand the scope of the question, really, so I apologize to the speaker.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, despite some of the positive changes that have been made by the speakers here, I remain skeptical about the proposal to set up a European Public Prosecutor's Office for several reasons. I believe that we already have sufficient mechanisms in the EU to combat financial fraud, such as Eurojust, Europol and OLAF. Another problem, in my opinion, will be the complex structure of deciding on the competence to investigate, where it will first have to be assessed whether it falls within the competence of the national or European prosecutor. It is also not clear to me who will be able to file appeals and other remedies. The issue of supervision also remains unresolved. Last but not least, we are moving towards the gradual harmonization of criminal law in the EU, which is a thorny path. The endless establishment of new and new European offices will hardly contribute to speeding up criminal proceedings and reducing procedural errors.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen! We are experiencing a historic moment here this evening: around eight years after the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, we have the final debate on the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. This is a really historic moment and I think we should cherish it. I am all the more disappointed that once again the Council is not here and that the Member States are not really appreciating this progress and are actually not bringing it to life. I hope that will change, and I also hope that the 20 Member States that have accepted the European Public Prosecutor can persuade the remaining Member States to take part in this instrument. It is important for the citizens of the European Union, for the EU budget. We lose hundreds of millions of euros every year in these crime areas when it comes to crimes against the EU budget. Some bills even go well beyond that. We got this read out, for example, in the special committee against organized crime, corruption and money laundering: it can even be several trillion euros. This means that the damage is enormous, and it is therefore all the more important that we really use this instrument now, that it be filled with life, that the Member States take part in it and that they use it as a model for proper police and judicial cooperation Take criminal matters. That is precisely the priority that we must give ourselves if we are to move forward with effective law enforcement in the European Union. It makes little sense to call for new investigative measures or any kind of databases when in the end the staff and the infrastructure for proper cooperation between the police and the judiciary are in place European Union not be made available.We can only tackle these tasks together, and the European Public Prosecutor is a great example and an important step in this.In this respect, we Greens also absolutely support this proposal.We will be voting in favor of this creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and we also believe that the recent proposals to expand competencies in future to include terrorist offenses, for example, must be discussed absolutely, that this is a correct proposal.As the European Parliament, we should stick with it and, of course, continue to create high procedural standards.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, I listened carefully to your speech, which was very optimistic.I admit that I am not so optimistic.Let me ask you a question.Do you think that until other states eventually join this new institute, before, as you said, join the European Public Prosecutor, this new office should work with the judicial authorities of those Member States that do not want a European Public Prosecutor?Should such cooperation take place here?

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear colleague!In any case, close cooperation should be agreed between the states that are now setting up the European Public Prosecutor's Office and those that - at least not yet - are not there, but will join as soon as possible.A country like Poland in particular would do well to take an active part.We still have the Eurojust regulation on the table.I am absolutely in favor of arranging a very close cooperation there.But it is not the case that you will enjoy the same benefits in Eurojust.They will only be able to fight this crime effectively if they also participate in this instrument.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with today's vote the long-awaited European Public Prosecutor's Office will finally see the light of day, which we regard as a central element in the fight against corruption in the European Union. First of all, it is regrettable that some Member States have preferred to remain outside the sphere of competence of this new body of the Union and, in this sense, we are confident that they will quickly repent. The prosecutor, as also underlined in the resolution of the European Parliament on the fight against corruption, of which I was rapporteur, must be efficient and independent from national governments and the institutions of the European Union, but above all, protected from political influence and pressure. I believe that the work of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, thanks also to the use of the resources already existing in the European context and thanks to the exchange of information with other bodies to combat fraud and corruption, such as OLAF, Europol and Eurojust, can guarantee a implementation of both repressive activities and in order to prevent crimes perpetrated against the European Union. Therefore, I hope that human and adequate financial resources will be assigned to the European Public Prosecutor's Office for its tasks and I regret that its mandate does not fall within its mandate, at least explicitly, the competences necessary for the fight against organized crime. I say this with the awareness of those who have seen millions of euros of European Union funds go up in smoke, for example for agriculture in the regions of Southern Italy, funds that, unfortunately, have ended up in the hands of scammers and organized crime, as noted among other things in the latest report of the Committee for the fight against fraud against the European Union, set up by the Italian government, which has registered, among the cases of fraud against the financial interests of the Union, even cases of perceptions of contributions, in agriculture, by subjects subjected to anti-mafia prevention measures.In conclusion, more and better could have been done: but there is no doubt that today the European Union is making a significant step forward in fighting crime.

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, I mentioned during the votes that I am going to try not to use the gavel. We are running slightly over time and I would ask you if you could cooperate with me and see whether, as an experiment, we can have a good debate without my having to use this. I think it is inappropriate.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: , on behalf of the ENF Group.- Madam President, thank you for the reminder.Criminal justice is a sovereign prerogative which has always belonged to States and is inseparable from their sovereignty.This is why I am opposed to the creation of a European public prosecutor's office, which would have the power to prosecute the perpetrators of offenses against "the financial interests of the Union".It is up to the national prosecution offices to prosecute these kinds of offenses, cooperating with each other when necessary.I am therefore opposed to the idea of a European public prosecutor's office which would strip them of their powers.I am opposed to it, especially since it will work closely with OLAF.But OLAF is discredited by the scandals.The Union is perverting all its areas of competence, which is why I am telling it stop, I do not want it to pervert criminal justice too.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Madam President, the European Public Prosecutor's Office is another repressive tool added to the already dangerous network of repression in the European Union and its Member States. Europol and Eurojust, national police and judicial authorities, databases and "dossiers", European warrants and more will be at the disposal of the Attorney General and European Public Prosecutors in each Member State. The European Public Prosecutor's Office is thus intended for the role of coordinator of the repressive mechanisms, EU and national. The fight against fraud is a pretext and a precursor to expanding its activities to other areas of persecution and repression, such as the so-called "fight against terrorism". The regulation is being passed with deliberate vagueness, already expanding the scope. But the real goal of all these mechanisms is the workers' popular movement, the suppression of popular freedoms. That is why the struggle against the repression of popular freedoms and rights must be aimed at the real enemy and adversary: ​​the power of the monopolies, the shielding of which serves their unions and mechanisms.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! So some colleagues should really be forbidden to speak here because they shouldn't speak on the topic at all due to a lack of specialist knowledge. The European Public Prosecutor is a milestone in the history of European justice because it - my colleague from just now: pay attention! - is the only body at European level that can determine for itself which cases it investigates. For all others, the Member State must ask for an investigation. And we now have Member States where we can have serious doubts as to whether all crimes are really being investigated, especially crimes from which Member States themselves benefit. We can no longer rely - and that is the problem, and please take note of it, instead of talking so stupidly, sorry - that the judicial authorities really work as they should. That is our problem and that is where the EPPO helps. Commissioner, congratulations! Today is a great day. Dear colleague Matera, you did a great job! It's been a hassle, but it's important. I really want to say that thanks to your persistence, Commissioner, this story is now being brought to a reasonably happy ending. Unfortunately, many small minds in the Justice and Home Affairs Council have not been able to promote a real community model at the EPPO. We have considerable deficiencies in the organization and construction, and these deficiencies will keep us busy. I want us to do what Mr Michel said: no more European money for those who do not take part in the EPPO. That must be the result of the next MFF negotiations. This is the only way to do it! We have to force countries into the European system where we have doubts about their judicial system. If you want money from us, you have to make sure that in case of doubt, financial crimes will be pursued.I would like to tell you that we will still have difficult days ahead of us with the EPPO, with Eurojust and with Europol.We have to ensure that we have good cooperation between these new authorities, also together with OLAF, which of course cannot even begin to compare in terms of powers with the EPPO.We have to make things work.But we also have to ensure that the EPPO is not overloaded with tasks.Therefore: Be careful when you ask for new skills to be expanded.I don't think much of it.First, let's get the current organization working!

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Jourová. Finally the European Public Prosecutor's Office! We are taking a historic step. After four years of hard work, debates, yellow cards in national parliaments and vetoes from some Member States, a strengthened cooperation with twenty out of twenty-five possible participating Member States is going ahead, taking into account that the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark have excluded themselves from this area of ​​freedom, justice and security. But it is a really huge step that we are taking, and the European Parliament did everything in its power to facilitate it, because we effectively approved the substantive criminal law, the Directive on the protection of the financial interests of the Union by means of criminal law - and I thank you for remembering, Commissioner Jourová, I was rapporteur for the report - as this tool will be crucial to protect the financial interests of the Union and the Union budget against fraud, which can amount to 500 million euros per year according to the lowest estimate. And it will do so by overcoming all technical difficulties, the difficulties imposed by what has been called the royalty of the States, a tool for collecting evidence, collecting evidence, measures to guarantee rights, defense, procedural difficulties. and the link of the national State prosecutor with the European Public Prosecutor's Office when there is a specific interest of a Member State. It is a very significant step, and what we want is for the legal basis to be broadened to also cover serious transnational crime under Article 83 and terrorism and so that the rest of the Member States can get on board this formidable instrument that is the European Prosecutor's Office. Hopefully it will be able to be effective as soon as possible and recover financial resources against fraud, which will be essential to combat unemployment and produce employment and economic growth in the European Union.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: - The European Public Prosecutor's Office or EPPO has to combat complex cases of fraud. No fait diverse, because the difference between the estimated VAT income and the actually collected VAT amounts in 2015 was around 152 billion euros. That is equal to the entire annual budget of the European Union. Some Member States, such as Belgium, are leaders in the fight against fraud. Allow other countries to act. The new EPPO will be able to oblige these Member States to initiate fraud investigations. Of course we cannot be against that, but there is one. At first, despite ongoing negotiations, we did not know which crimes the EPPO was going to prosecute. After it became clear that the focus would be on large-scale fraud, it was decided to establish a new agency. But according to the Treaty, the EPPO was to be embedded in Eurojust, the European Judicial Cooperation Unit. Unfortunately, it was decided to allow the EPPO to function alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Not very efficient, but given the importance of fraud prevention, we will accept this.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, if you have to use the mallet, you can use it with me. I'm not going to be original, but I want to be fair. As Mr Aguilar has pointed out - as has already been said - the public coffers of the Member States are supposed to stop collecting at least 500 million euros due to cross-border VAT fraud and various frauds that have a huge impact on the financing of public policies of the States, that is, on the well-being of citizens. In addition, as has also been pointed out, they are often linked to criminal schemes that finance terrorism and drug trafficking. It is not original to say it, but it is important: the EPPO is crucial to protect the financial interests of the Union, which is to defend citizens. Thus, the new European Public Prosecutor's Office will be able to initiate criminal proceedings and will do so with a structure and a functioning that pursue efficiency; it will be independent of the Member States, and it is intended to do this quickly - this is harder to believe, but we will see. We know that it is not a magic solution and, although a grain does not make a barn, something will help improve the viability of our welfare systems, and it is important.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office represents a step forward in the process of European integration, in the communitarisation and harmonization of justice, namely in the criminal area, aiming at a servile justice to the interests of the great powers and big capital. The attack on the sovereignty of the states continues, reinforcing the federalist stance of the integration project, in this case the judiciary, through supranational bodies in which more and more powers and powers are concentrated, obliterating the necessary and desirable free and sovereign cooperation between National States. The creation of some and the strengthening of others in these European bodies are intended to protect and override the legitimate institutions of the Member States, to condition their ability to intervene in their own defense of their interests and to limit their judicial sovereignty. With these proposals, entities that escape democratic and jurisdictional control are centralized, structured and reinforced, surpassing guarantees regarding the rights and freedoms provided for in national legislative and constitutional frameworks.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the money of European taxpayers will now be better protected, and cross-border fraudsters more prosecuted. This is the message the Union sends with the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. This will have the power to investigate and prosecute the perpetrators of fraud affecting the Union budget, such as embezzlement or VAT fraud, which amounts, as everyone knows, each year to more than 50 billion euros. After more than four years of discussions, it is time for the Union to set up a body capable of dealing with this phenomenon, which is sometimes used to finance terrorism. Of course, we would have preferred all Member States to participate in this parquet, but I am convinced that the first 20 countries will soon be joined by the others. How can we ignore the ravages of financial crime any longer? Of course, the powers of the prosecution could be broader and cover, for example, environmental crimes, but its powers may be extended in the future. What is essential now is to provide the public prosecutor's office with resources to match its ambitions, to ensure effective cooperation with Eurojust and, above all, to guarantee it genuine independence. It is on this that its added value and its ability to investigate depend, particularly in cases which may prove to be too sensitive at the national level. The prosecution is a step forward for the Europe of justice. Let's give it the means to make a real difference.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the stated purpose of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office is to pursue financial and economic crimes committed against the European Union. Now, the intention is to pursue criminals for crimes against the EU’s budget, but also the EU’s wider financial interests, for example cross-border crime such as counterfeiting and VAT fraud. This new office usurps the authority of nation states and control of their own legal systems. For that reason, eight of the 28 Member States have opted out of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. Britain has an opt-out, but we are leaving the European Union. I have always maintained that these opt-outs are essentially worthless, because the Prosecutor would be able to utilise the EU’s existing legal instruments and legal institutions in order to circumvent the opt-outs. On Monday, 25 September, I asked this very question at a meeting in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE).
