The representative of the Commission present confirmed that what I have said all along is correct, and leaving the EU will not make any difference for Britain. Ms May has said that she wants a new security relationship treaty with the European Union. The treaty would include our subservience to all the existing EU legal instruments and institutions. We are being lied to, as usual. If Ms May has her way, Britain will be subject to the European Public Prosecutor after we leave the European Union.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, thank you very much for being able to address this subject this evening, which, regretfully, I will not be supporting tomorrow in terms of the vote. Now, my colleagues have described how it is going to be portrayed, but can I just issue a big reminder? The European Union has an absolutely abysmal record in terms of finance, budget and accountancy. It has had numerous scandals, that have been mentioned, and therefore to even begin to establish an organisation like this makes one wonder whether it actually has the competence to investigate what is happening within its own body?  Mention has also been made of the fact that a number of states have opted out. I think that is a very good move. The signal they are sending is that this ought to be stopped for a moment, a review ought to be conducted, and the financial systems and investigations that the EU currently has ought to be addressed, before embarking on something new which is going to cost, which requires resources and which ultimately takes away sovereign power from Member States.

name: Viviane Reding (PPE).
text: - Madam President, a European public prosecutor's office able to find and prosecute fraudsters ... Finally! In 2013, I put the project on the table in my capacity as Commissioner for Justice. Commissioner Jourová completes it today and it will enter into force in 2020. And this is a major step forward. Finally our European budget will receive the European protection it deserves. Gone are the days when crooks could easily embezzle the European taxpayer's money, knowing full well that they would not be prosecuted and, therefore, end with impunity. When criminals act internationally, our response too must be transnational and European. I am delighted that twenty Member States have decided to go ahead. Enhanced cooperation is thus proving its worth and showing that a Europe of precursors can drag in its wake the Member States which, even today, hesitate to protect taxpayers' money more effectively. The creation of the post of European public prosecutor is proof that Europe can and must move forward with a vanguard, and this proof has already been provided by the divorce regulations and the inheritance proposal. The European area of ​​justice is slowly being established, and it will be an honor for Luxembourg, as the seat of the judicial institutions, to welcome the new European prosecutors. Europe is acting and must continue to do so, so I call for the broadening of the powers of the organized crime and counterterrorism prosecutor in the future to better protect our citizens. Commissioner, the window of opportunity is open, the Treaties allow us to move forward, and it is therefore up to us to do so.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is undoubtedly one of the major advances in the European integration process of criminal law, because it is a body that will not only have coordination functions but is, for the first time, a direct power in the exercise of the prosecution and that will find in the PIF Directive a harmonized criminal law for the protection of the financial interests of the Union. The text negotiated by the Council represents a good compromise which takes due account of many of the suggestions made by the European Parliament. Among these, the inclusion of VAT fraud within the competence of the Prosecutor's Office, the inclusion of adequate rules on the processing of personal data and the provision of specific procedural guarantees, especially with reference to the judicial control of the decisions of the Prosecutor itself. The regret remains for the failure to reach unanimity. Nonetheless, I am convinced that the text guarantees, as requested by Parliament, adequate measures for coordination and judicial cooperation even with those non-participating countries, which must remain as much as possible within the European system of criminal law enforcement of PIF offenses. The hope is that the European Public Prosecutor's Office will be able to start its activities on schedule, for a more effective fight against financial crimes against the Union, with the prospect, as you yourself pointed out, Commissioner and also for this I thank you, a possible future extension of competences to other serious cross-border crimes, such as organized crime and terrorism.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Fighting financial crime should be a universally accepted and supported goal. However, this will continue to be primarily the responsibility of the judiciary of the Member States. The European Public Prosecutor's Office can contribute to this goal, but will not replace national bodies and institutions. I regret very much that this debate did not address the objections of those countries that did not join the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and these include both countries that have long been part of the European Community and those that have joined the European Union in recent years. At this point, I wish Commissioner Jourova that this institution will be effective and show trust and good cooperation towards the Member States, because efficiency, trust and good cooperation with the Member States are a condition for other countries to join this institution in the future. . The worst thing you can do is what has been said several times in this House: scaring budgetary discrimination against those who have not joined the European Public Prosecutor's Office. This is a very unfavorable, dangerous and harmful thing from the point of view of European cooperation and trust in the institution that is taking off.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: - Madam President! I would like to begin by congratulating Commissioner Vera Jourová and also on all the 20 Member States that have now chosen to join the Joint Prosecutor's Office. Unfortunately, I also want to take the time to address the countries that have chosen not to join. Unfortunately, it is Sweden, my own home country, which, together with countries such as Hungary and Poland, has now chosen to distance itself from joint law enforcement and cross-border cooperation in order to step back into the future. That's what it's about not trying to retaliate against the cross - border criminal networks. I think it is very important that they join as soon as possible. I would urge the Swedish government to do the same. The establishment of the Public Prosecutor's Office is very important. Criminal gangs know no national borders and the law enforcement authorities in Europe must now do the same, that is, work across borders and not allow national borders to preclude effective law enforcement. This is how we can build a safer Europe for all of us.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, for many VAT is that loathed tax that adds to the cost of our weekly shop. The reality is that consumption tax is meant to fund our schools and hospitals and the other vital public services. However, it is being avoided on a massive scale and the proceeds of VAT fraud are being diverted to fund global terrorist organisations. A staggering EUR 50 billion is being lost each year in VAT fraud. A nice round figure to publicise on the side of a bus! Indeed, it is extremely disappointing that the UK is one of a number of EU countries that have fought tax cooperation, the tax cooperation we so desperately need. By opting not to take part in the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, the UK is contradicting and undermining its own insistence on maintaining defence and security cooperation with the EU after Brexit. I call on the UK Government to stop its anti-terrorism posturing and go to the heart of the problem by joining the EU in its battle to fight VAT fraud and starve the terrorists of the funds they need to function.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! There is undoubtedly a need for greater protection of the EU's budget and financial interests, as there is certainly an example of Structural Fund aid being used in an illegal way, ie fraud. Under the principle of subsidiarity, of course, this is the responsibility of the public prosecutors' offices in the Member States, but in many cases these are cross-border frauds, which the European Public Prosecutor's Office will be able to provide serious assistance in investigating. The use of the institution of enhanced cooperation is therefore justified in this area, but, like all enhanced cooperation mechanisms, it should be open to Member States that have not yet done so and allow them to join the EPPO. That is why we must clearly reject the assumption that only those Member States that join this enhanced cooperation will be able to benefit from cohesion funds after 2020. The efficiency, impartiality and professional work of prosecutors in the newly created institution could convince the dropouts to benefit if they join. I do not think that proposals like this, even if they take the form of a press release, will help to increase the cohesion of European states or strengthen the confidence of European citizens in the EU. This requires completely different measures, such as the effective work of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which can really reassure citizens that the Member States are using the resources of the common budget responsibly. In this case, I have no doubt that the states that are now missing out will also consider joining.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Madam President, congratulations, Commissioner, congratulations to the rapporteur and everyone who worked on it! We lose around EUR 500 million in public money every year due to corruption and fraud. 500 million that we could - and should of course - invest in our youth or in secure jobs. The European Public Prosecutor's Office as a real cross-border law enforcement agency with direct investigative powers in the participating member states is a huge success - a huge success for the European Union and for all member states that benefit from it. When I wrote the JURI opinion in the last legislative period, there were so many doubts - Member States, MEPs - and it is all the better that it will now work. But one thing is important, especially with regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework: all member states that use EU funds should take their noses and participate in the EU corruption prosecutor's office. It must not be the case that those member states that receive the largest share of EU funds evade justice here. The previous speaker from Hungary spoke to his country, he argued the other way around. I would specifically like to call on Poland and Hungary to participate in this instrument. If they don't, we should consider other increased controls and enforcement rights. Because this instrument is something great, and I can only urge everyone to participate.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and consider the need for institutional measures at European level to effectively prosecute fraud and other crimes affecting the financial interests of taxpayers in the Member States of the European Union. union, for urgent. Bulgaria is part of the twenty member states of the European Union wishing to launch enhanced cooperation for the establishment of this service. I am pleased to see that in its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs endorses this decision of the Council. The protection and prosecution of crimes against the European Union budget and the financial interests of the European Union are the exclusive competence of the Member States. OLAF, Eurojust and Europol do not have a mandate to conduct this criminal investigation and therefore the functioning European Public Prosecutor's Office will fill this institutional gap. Misuse of European Union funds must be a crime to be prosecuted with the creation of the new service. And I will be extremely happy and satisfied if this happens during the forthcoming Bulgarian presidency.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Treaty of Lisbon provides an opportunity for the European Union to set up a European Public Prosecutor's Office. Unfortunately, negotiations on this new structure have been stalled for years, but I am glad that a solution has finally been found and we will approve the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Crimes do not recognize borders, be they national or European. For more than 20 years, we have been trying by various means to improve cooperation and the exchange of information between the various Member States, and that is why we have set up Eurojust, for example. But when we talk about fraud with European funds, that is not enough. Obtaining evidence abroad is slow and slows investigations. Cooperation procedures also do not always bring the desired results and do not correspond to the reality of open borders. Our economies and taxpayers deserve better protection for the money they spend on the European project. Every year, at least 50 billion euros of VAT is lost due to various cross-border crimes, including European funds. European funds must contribute to stimulating growth, creating jobs, increasing cohesion between the various Member States, and not favor criminals. I believe that the new prosecutor's office will improve the investigation and cooperation of these crimes. It will be strong, independent, with the necessary investigative tools. It will cooperate with Member States in the investigation of a number of crimes related to European funds, fraud, corruption, money laundering. It will improve cooperation and information exchange. At the same time, it will ensure a high level of respect for procedural rights in the European Union. In order to carry out this activity, the prosecution will need some of the best prosecutors, effective internal rules and an adequate budget. All this will be agreed during the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council and I hope for constructiveness on the part of the Member States.For my country - Bulgaria, one of the earliest supporters of the prosecution, it is an honor to ensure that the European Public Prosecutor's Office will start working fully in 2020. I believe that for the other Member States participating in this new structure, this is a priority..

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Ms. President! Corruption, tax fraud and organized crime have long ignored borders, which is why it is not possible to fight them only within Member States. That is why the European Public Prosecutor's Office had to be set up, as the European Public Prosecutor's Office will enable us to fight corruption much more effectively. We know for a fact that it is useless for OLAF to make any effort if there are public prosecutors in the Member States who, for political reasons, are unwilling to actually investigate allegations of corruption. Unfortunately, I do not have to go far for concrete examples, my country, Hungary, is perhaps one of the saddest cases in this respect as well. In recent years, a total of three of the twenty-two cases proposed by OLAF have been effectively investigated by the Hungarian Public Prosecutor's Office. In these cases, it was always EU money, European taxpayers' money, which the Hungarian government spends on building illiberal democracy and not for the benefit of the country. This practice can only be stopped by the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and the Hungarian government is therefore unwilling to support the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I am in favor of strengthening judicial cooperation between Member States, especially with regard to the implementation of the European Arrest Warrant and Investigation Order, as well as further developing cooperation between national police forces bilaterally, but also within common instruments such as Europol or Eurosur. I believe that closer cooperation is important if we want to have a functional community and a single market. However, I also believe that the initiative to initiate legal proceedings should remain exclusively within the competence of national public prosecutors. Since it is very difficult for me to imagine how the European Public Prosecutor would be more effective in this, it is a clear undermining of the principle of subsidiarity. In cases of fraud against the financial interests of the Union, I would like to remind you that we have recently adopted a directive harmonizing the judicial frameworks of the Member States in this area, so we should work on improving this mechanism instead of creating parallel institutions.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Public Prosecutor's Office, as a separate institution, has emerged out of necessity, out of evasion, out of cross-border evasion. Only from VAT, it was said here, the huge amount that is missing and is missing, after all, from national budgets, therefore, from taxpayers' pockets. Obviously, the European Public Prosecutor's Office is an institution that must be very well defined as tasks by Olaf, Eurojust, Europol, this has also been said. I think, Commissioner, that the hardship is beginning now, because, of course, it took many years to convince the states. Not all states are convinced. I think it is very difficult to have this enhanced cooperation when 7 states do not participate. What is happening at the borders of those states? I think it is very important to clearly define the powers of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I don't think we have to put everything in his charge, because then, what are the other institutions doing? It must be a cooperation with the national prosecutor's offices, but I cannot refrain from asking a question, Commissioner: if it is a question of enhanced cooperation, what do we do with the responsibility of the magistrates, who have been told that it belongs to the field of subsidiarity? However, we must also have a strengthened cooperation here - regarding the magistrates.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Madam President!We have the following situation: we have a common economic area, we have a Europe without borders in terms of economic and trade turnover, the movement of people - but we do not have a common area of investigation.We obviously have a common area of crime, but not of prosecution, so I welcome this idea and look at it not only as a protection of our budget, but also as an instrument to protect our financial interests, our economic interests.This prosecutor's office should be such a signal: the probability of detecting a crime is increasing, therefore the risk taken is also increasing, ergo economic crimes should be less and less profitable for us.I expect that if the prosecution service starts and is effective, the countries that have so far refused or hesitated will find it in their best interest to join - and that would be our success.Thank you so much, just a minute has passed.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office fills the void represented by the impossibility for OLAF, Eurojust and Europol to carry out criminal investigations, a very severe limitation on the operational level. For the moment, the European Public Prosecutor's Office will have only an additional task and a limited mandate to protect the financial interests of the Union: it will combine the efforts made at European and national level in the field of combating fraud against the European Union, framing them in an approach unified and exceeding the limit of the current exclusivity of the conduct of investigations by national authorities. But the integrative activity is only a first step. Over time, the Prosecutor's Office will have to take on a general task and prosecute all types of crimes with a cross-border dimension, actively including all Member States, including, of course, even those who do not participate in enhanced cooperation today. There is no lack of pilot experiences in this sense and there is no lack of political will to take a step towards a unified administration of justice. For now it is a small step but it is a necessary and significant step towards a united Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the protection of the European Union's financial interests is currently taking place in the Member States. There are national prosecutors, there are law enforcement authorities and we know very well that, from the time complaints or lawsuits are filed, there is criminal prosecution and there is criminal punishment. Why, then, should a supranational authority, a European Public Prosecutor's Office, be set up to have the right to prosecute? Prosecuting authorities, as you know, exercise sovereign rights. Only states have prosecuting authorities, not supranational organizations. What is being done in practice is to create "out of the window" repressive mechanisms by the European Union itself, which is not enough or may not trust the repressive mechanisms of the Member States. We have Eurojust, we have OLAF, we have Europol, now we will have the European Public Prosecutor. I think this model makes no sense.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this very interesting and important debate. I will react to what we have just heard. This is EU money and it requires a response from the EU institution. I think that is very clear. In the EU we see that crime is on the rise, cross-border crime is on the rise, we see permanent structures working against our interests, against our taxpayers’ financial interests, and we need to come with a permanent structure. This is a very practical response we are coming with. This is a very important moment for me too, because I worked for many years in cohesion policy, and I always found this to be a policy which is driven by a very strong ethical impetus. There is solidarity in it and there is a very strong, legitimate expectation from the European taxpayers that we will guarantee the protection of their money; and we have to do that! This is what we are doing now by the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) which is not replacing national prosecution services. It is going to work in a very strong synergy with national prosecutors, which will come into play in cases where the national prosecutors cannot come with an efficient response.  Here we heard a lot about the missing, non-participating countries. Three countries – the UK, Ireland and Denmark – have a permanent opt-out from criminal justice policies. What about the remaining five countries? I had to convince many more than those five, where we have failed for the time being. This was a very important time when, yes, we had yellow cards and it forced me to go to the national parliaments and have very intensive communications with the national authorities, national co-decision-makers in the field of the fight against crime, arguing that this is a very important step forward. I had to bring a lot of arguments, facts, figures. You mentioned EUR 500 million. I will add EUR 50 billion which we have as an estimation of the cross-border carousel VAT fraud. That is why it is very important that we added this cross-border carousel fraud under the remit of the EPPO. This was a real game-changer, and I must again thank those who worked on the Fifth Directive when we added this to the remit of the EPPO. We had to solve the unsolvable problem: we had the duty or the task not to touch the national criminal prosecution, because the EPPO will work under national criminal prosecution rules; and I am sure we have managed to do that. So, what about the missing Member States? I will keep trying to convince them. From Sweden and the Netherlands I heard the arguments: our prosecution works well. I have to be better in explaining that this is not about well or badly functioning prosecution services, it is about guaranteeing the protection of your taxpayers’ money. So this is my task for the near future. On Poland and Hungary I have never hidden that I see the need to take the EPPO as a factor in the negotiations on the future multiannual financial framework and for the possible future Cohesion Policy. I will be very strong on this because I am convinced that the EPPO will work as a very strong deterrent and, let me use the word, repressive body.  If a Member State does not have the EPPO then we will have to be much stronger in preventive action. Already now in the Cohesion Policy, in structural funds distribution, there is a lot of control, a lot of audit, a lot of preventive measures, and still you see so much fraud and corruption in it. For the Member States which will get the Cohesion Fund money and will not be under the EPPO we will simply have to be much stronger in enhancing this control and audit. This will be my effort for the months to come when we discuss the future Cohesion Policy. Thank you very much for your support. I hope the vote tomorrow will reflect the mainly positive debate here in Parliament, and I will keep you informed about the next phase – after, I hope, having the final adoption by the Council – about the practical steps towards the implementation of the regulation and full functioning of the EPPO.

name: Barbara Matera
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too join in the words of Commissioner Jourová, reiterating the regret that the regulation is the subject of enhanced cooperation involving 20 Member States and not the whole of the Union. I trust that the reasons that have led some countries not to participate in the activity of the Prosecutor will soon be overcome. The integration process does not pass only through a transfer of sovereignty, but also through pure and simple coordination, which allows a complex system such as that of the European Union to function better and more effectively. Ensuring effective coordination of investigations and judicial proceedings will solve the age-old problem linked to the significant differences between the various applicable legal systems. Ensuring that the Union's limited financial resources are used in the best interests of Union citizens and are protected from fraud is also and above all indispensable for the legitimacy of expenditure and for ensuring trust in the Union. Protecting the interests of the EU budget, therefore, means protecting taxpayers' money: this is not a trivial detail. We are witnessing a detachment of our citizens from the European institutions, a collapse of confidence and a twisting of populism. The Prosecutor's Office will give prestige to the system as it was conceived and I am proud to have been rapporteur of the European Parliament: someone here said: "today we write a piece of the history of this Union". I thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful cooperative spirit they have demonstrated and implemented over the years. I thank Commissioner Jourová and her staff for their support and continued work over the years. Finally, I thank my fellow speakers who have preceded me and I especially thank the various presidencies in office and I regret that they were not with us this evening and took part in the debate.

name: President. –
text: Thank you for your work. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - I broadly agree with the objectives behind the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO). At the same time, respect for the principles of subsidiarity and efficiency must be essential, which is why Hungary, along with many other Member States (such as the Netherlands, Sweden, Malta, Poland, Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom), has chosen not to participate. in enhanced cooperation. The establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as an independent institution also raises the issue of compliance with the Basic Law in the case of my country, since according to the Basic Law the Hungarian Public Prosecutor's Office is the sole enforcer of the state's criminal claim. There are several EU institutions, such as Eurojust or OLAF, that deal with perpetrators of crimes against the EU's financial interests, which should be strengthened rather than created by another EU institution.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The European Public Prosecutor's Office is the first EU body to be able to protect the Union's financial interests through criminal law. This is a major breakthrough, even if not all Member States join the EU-level law enforcement organization yet. The lagging countries argue that EPPO unacceptably affects national sovereignty. However, this is not true. The existence of the EPPO does affect the sovereignty of the Member States, but in the context of criminal offenses which are currently not prosecuted at all or effectively prosecuted by the Member State authorities. An example is the range of cross-border VAT frauds. The dropouts fear that, in addition to the domestic prosecutor's office, the EU prosecutor's office will have powers over the control of EU funds, and this is likely to affect their economic interests. Yet we cannot allow inconsistency. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council, as well as my fellow Members, to allow the use of the EU money-sharing system when the next long-term financial framework is adopted, only with the acceptance of the EPPO's remit. In the absence of this, the system of criminal law instruments can be circumvented: financial crimes, including VAT fraud, will then be committed not in Germany or France, but in Hungary or Poland. And if we prescribe EPPO membership as a precondition for spending EU money, we can be confident that even the most conceited governments will be more subject, as they cannot afford to lose resources.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - The national budgets of the countries of the Union lose EUR 50 billion a year in VAT fraud. Hundreds of millions of euros are reported in other fraudulent irregularities. This is a cross-border crime where the competences of national investigating authorities are limited. There is no single, independent and effective institution in the Union empowered to investigate criminal offenses relating to fraud involving Union funds, in particular serious VAT fraud. The required unanimity in the Council lacks eight votes on the legal and factual establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Therefore, twenty Member States have made use of the possibility offered by the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and re-submitted the proposal for a regulation to the Council. Such enhanced cooperation will only apply to participating Member States. I fully support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which will ensure the rapid, efficient and independent investigation of criminal offenses. In cooperation with OLAF, Europol and Eurojust, as well as national authorities, it will contribute to the implementation of a zero tolerance of fraud on Union resources. I appreciate that the Slovak Republic, which during its presidency advocated the finalization of the text of the regulation, belongs to the states of enhanced cooperation.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: in writing. - The task of the European Public Prosecutor's Office will be to protect European funds and taxpayers' money by fighting fraud and abuse. The European Public Prosecutor's Office is to be created under "enhanced cooperation", ie without the participation of EU countries that are reluctant to do so. The European Public Prosecutor's Office will be created thanks to the cooperation of 20 Member States: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, Germany, Greece, Italy, Finland, France, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Slovakia and Spain . Other Member States will be able to cooperate at any time. The European Public Prosecutor's Office will be responsible for investigating, prosecuting and bringing to justice perpetrators of offenses against the Union's financial interests. Currently, only national authorities can investigate and prosecute fraud against EU funds, but their jurisdiction does not extend beyond national borders. Since 2014, MEPs have already adopted several resolutions in favor of the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, stressing the need to ensure the independence of prosecutors. The European Public Prosecutor's Office will be based in Luxembourg but each Member State will second at least one local prosecutor. In the future, the list of serious crimes falling under the jurisdiction of the European Public Prosecutor's Office may be extended, for example to include terrorism. I hope that the Polish government will change its decision and that Poland will join the group of countries cooperating in this regard.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: signed up. - The prosecution of offenses against the European budget is the exclusive competence of the Member States and there is no European Union authority in this area. Under this Regulation, Member States will cede their national sovereignty in the field of investigation and prosecution of offenses against the financial interests of the Union, provided that they are already bound by the Treaty (Article 325) to protect the financial interests of the European Union in the same as national financial interests. The European Public Prosecutor will change the mode of cooperation, hitherto horizontal, between the competent authorities of the Member States, to a vertical one, which implies the transfer of sovereignty. I doubt the contribution of such a body (new, complex, on several levels) to the efficiency of the investigation and sanctioning of crimes. In addition, the costs of setting up this institution outweigh the potential benefits. In fact, there are already institutions with competences in judicial cooperation at European level, and the creation of a new institution (too complex and too expensive) will affect existing institutions and the fight against fraud in general. I believe that this project, which has been negotiated for so many years, is just another attempt by the Commission to invade the powers of the Member States and to become supranational.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - The proposal to set up a European Public Prosecutor's Office is one of those that has really been forced by life to finally protect the interests of European taxpayers in a concrete and effective way. That is why I urge the strong consent and swift implementation of the EP. It is unfortunate, but the experience of recent years has shown that the judicial organizations in the Member States are not suitable, and in some cases unreliable, for detecting and sanctioning abuses and fraud in the spending of European funds. And for OLAF, Eurojust and Europol, as we know, the Treaty does not provide such powers, as the legislator simply could not have foreseen a situation where complete corruption mafia systems parasitizing European funds could be built within the Union, with government support. It is a sad fact that the most obvious example of this today is my own country, Hungary, which has been left out of EPPO co-operation, where Orbán's authoritarian anti-European regime is largely based on systemic corruption financed by the deception of European funds. This practice is disguised - rather than exposed by its profession - by a prosecutor's office under the political control of the regime, where OLAF's inquiries are stalled. I trust that, in the foreseeable future, all Member States, including my own, will be part of the important cooperation within the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. - Fighting crimes affecting the European Union budget, which finances the most important EU social and development policies, is an important challenge, especially in the context of increasingly sophisticated criminal methods. It is also important that the effective protection of the Union's financial interests often requires cross-border criminal cooperation, which has often turned out to be ineffective using the existing methods of cooperation between the judiciary of the Member States. The European Public Prosecutor's Office is a strong response to these challenges, but operating in an enhanced cooperation format may significantly reduce its intended effectiveness. Therefore, joining the project of other, still undecided Member States would certainly be a decisive step forward in the process of integration and deepening cooperation - in the interest of all EU citizens. Moreover, I believe that the numerous recent terrorist threats justify starting a discussion on a possible extension of the mandate of the European Public Prosecutor's Office to the fight against particularly serious organized crime. However, first of all, this office must be established in order to demonstrate effective fulfillment of the mandate in the field of protection of the economic interests of the European Union.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on Interpol arrest warrants (Red Notices) (2017/2873(RSP)).

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start by underlining that the possible abuse of Interpol Red Notices for political purposes is a matter of great concern to the Council. Following a letter from the German and the Swedish Foreign Ministers to the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, regarding the arrest of two EU citizens with dual nationality on the basis of Interpol Red Notices, the Presidency decided to address this topic at the joint meeting of the Political and Security Committee and the Standing Committee on Operational Cooperation on Internal Security, on 26 September. This was just the first step and the Presidency plans to raise the topic again at the half-yearly meeting of the EU Justice and Home Affairs Senior Officials with Interpol on 20 November. We aim to discuss then possible improvements to the existing Interpol systems, and we will listen carefully to Interpol’s plans. The number of Red Notices has increased over recent years, and they are an extremely useful tool in obtaining the provisional arrest of persons sought for extradition for serious crimes. This was shown by the result of a Commission questionnaire in 2016 regarding Members States’ use of Interpol Red Notices. Over the years, these notices have indeed resulted in the arrests of numerous criminals. Nonetheless, it is important that the proper review should take place before Red Notices are issued, which is a demanding task. It is essential that the rights of our citizens are protected and that an effective redress mechanism exists. The Presidency is aware that the Interpol general assembly last week, 26-29 September, discussed Red Notices. Interpol has an internal, systematic and proactive review process for vetting the legality of new Red Notices entered into the Interpol database. The Presidency will discuss with Interpol how this process could be speeded up and improved. The use of Interpol Red Notices for the purpose of obtaining the arrest of persons sought with a view to extradition is not new. The 1957 extradition Convention of the Council of Europe, to which all Member States are parties, as well as Turkey, allows Interpol to be used for transmitting requests for provisional arrest. Whether a Member State accepts an Interpol Red Notice, pending a decision on an extradition request, falls solely within the competence of the Member State. I would like to emphasise that an Interpol Red Notice will never be the basis for a decision to extradite, as that decision will be the subject of judicial review in a separate judicial procedure. Therefore, there is always a judicial review before a person is extradited. It does not appear feasible to have such a judicial review a priori but, as I have indicated, we will discuss with Interpol on 20 November how to improve the review of Red Notices by Interpol itself.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am aware that Interpol’s Red Notice system has been used for political purposes in some cases. Obviously this is of great concern and it can have a significant impact on the persons involved. The overwhelming majority of Red Notices are genuinely used to seek the arrest of suspects and serious offenders. Exchanging information with Interpol is important in preventing and fighting serious crime. The arrest in Brazil of one of the most wanted Italian mafia criminals is an example of the added value of Interpol Red Notices. EU Member States are members of Interpol and make use of its Red Notice system. They are, however, not obliged to act upon them. It is for the EU Member States to assess what action they can take when they encounter a Red Notice and to consider such notices carefully in the light of their originating country. If there are abuses of Interpol’s system, it is for Interpol to put in place the necessary measures to prevent such abuse. As the EU is not a member of Interpol, the Commission cannot directly influence how Interpol puts in place procedures to avoid such misuse. However, the Commission has already, in the past, raised concerns with Interpol about misuse of its instruments. The Commission conducted a number of fact-finding missions and meetings in order to understand the procedures that Interpol has put in place to process personal data. Since February 2015 Interpol has presented a new framework for processing personal data. The processing of notices and ‘diffusions’ against refugees will not be allowed if the status of refugee or asylum seeker has been confirmed. It will also not be allowed if a person fears persecution by the country establishing the notice. I understand that Interpol has completed the process of reviewing its procedures and tabled a draft resolution to its general assembly last week. The Commission will raise this issue with Interpol as part of its November EU-Interpol senior official meeting. The Commission is ready to provide, as it has done in the past, any support that may be deemed necessary. As regards the procedures put in place by EU Member States, the Commission gathered information in October 2015 in order to understand how Member States are using Red Notices from Interpol. A large majority of Member States indicated that the upload of Interpol Red Notices into national databases is done only after further examinations and checks. The Commission will continue to follow this important question closely in cooperation with our Member States.  I want to thank the House for your attention and I look forward to fruitful discussion with you.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, we have heard very clearly from the Council and from the Commissioner a very clear recognition of a potential abuse of Interpol Red Notices, and it is refreshing to hear that very clearly. The issue really for us today is to understand what we do about it, and the Council went some way to explaining that mechanism – 20 November, and I want to say more about that in a second. The Commission also explained some of the limitations to what can be done, and again we must address that today. But let us be very clear what is happening – and again we have support from both the Commission and Council in recognising that these notices and the systems have been abused to – let us be very clear – harass and detain political opponents and dissidents. The countries involved include Russia, China and Iran, let us be very clear. A process to prevent this abuse is needed to resolve the issue, which will become ever more important as databases are increasingly, directly and automatically consulted. This is not an issue that will go away on its own and I respect the honesty of the Council in recognising this. There have been a number of recent examples of abuses of the system in Turkey. After the failed coup in the country last year, we have seen worrying signs that the situation of human rights is deteriorating, and we see this additional problem with the Interpol Red Notices as exacerbating the situation. We have received reports from journalists who are watching this debate carefully that they are now being harassed, and many others – including the Nobel Peace Prize nominee Can Dündar who is living in exile in Germany and who is currently on trial – are also being affected by this situation. We have heard from Fair Trials International, the Organisation for Security and Co—operation in Europe (OSCE) and others of what we need to do. As Members of the European Parliament, we need not only to speak out whenever there are incidents of political repression, but also to ensure there are safeguards in place to prevent the abuse of Interpol arrest warrants, which are an important tool in ensuring the security of the EU. My questions then come back to the Commission and Council: can we provide more detail on what has been done to ensure the rights of EU and third—country citizens, and whether there is a better mechanism to ensure that necessity and proportionality checks are carried out on Interpol alerts from certain countries. Could the Commission also provide guidelines on a common response on how best to handle extradition requests from third countries. I understand the limitations and the legal limitations, but I am happy that, in the initial responses from the Council and Commission, there is a clear recognition that we cannot see these potential abuses of Interpol Red Notices happening on our territory; we cannot see these obvious abuses of human rights. We respect our freedom, we are a European Union of values, so let us not see these abuses continue.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! Neither Interpol nor the public prosecutor's offices - it has to be said clearly - are allowed to make themselves bailiffs of dictators. Article 3 of the Interpol Statute expressly forbids the misuse of police searches for political, military, religious and racist purposes and thus also arrests, as happened in the case of the writer Doğan Akhanlı. We therefore not only demand that Interpol simply comply with applicable law, but also that all databases on Red Notices are checked in order to prevent further misuse. In particular, we ask the Spanish authorities to finally change their practice and not comply with politically motivated requests for detention, as all other EU Member States do - only Spain does not. Akhanlı is not the only example that shows that something is wrong at Interpol, and whether the new boss, of all things, the only Vice-Head of Internal Security in China, gives hope for improvement is in the stars, because China is known for it, exactly Wanting to get over dissidents and refugees with such requests for arrest. Again: Interpol must strictly uphold the requirement of independence and neutrality, and we should campaign for that.

name: Bodil Valero
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! I would like to begin by thanking the Commission for answering the question I asked during the last plenary sitting today. It was about the Swedish journalist Hamza Yalcin with a Turkish background, who was imprisoned in Spain pending a possible deportation. As far as I know today, he has been released pending a final decision. Interpol is an organization that was created for, and whose task is, to prosecute crime and prosecute criminals. International police cooperation is necessary and welcome. But we have a problem when the system is abused for political purposes, and we are seeing more and more examples of that. It is, as has been said here before, very important to emphasize that this warning is not an arrest warrant and that Interpol does not issue arrest warrants or force Member States to arrest a person on red notice. Each state makes its own assessment. One should be especially careful when it comes to people who have protection status of some kind. There I would also like to emphasize that it is important that not only those who have been granted refugee status, but that those who have been allowed to stay on some other ground of protection, because there are different levels and at different times - at least in Swedish law we have had three, four different articles with protection grounds, but this is the only one where you get a refugee declaration according to the UN system, so to speak - so it is important that those who have been allowed to stay on other protection grounds are also given special consideration. It is also extremely important that Member States really push for Interpol to use this system, so that Member States follow it; I would like to say that.

name: Tim Aker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, it is very noble to criticise the governments in Moscow and Ankara for using arrest warrants to round up political opponents. This would have been very laudable had the events of last weekend in Spain not happened. But one cannot lecture on other governments’ human rights records when this institution and the European Union turn a complete blind eye to what happened in Catalonia last Sunday. The responses that we had from the Commission about dialogue and the rule of law were, frankly, toothless. These were people who were going to put a cross on a bit of paper in a box. They were not calling for armed revolution, they were not trying to impose force on other people. They were expressing an opinion. And here we say to the governments in Moscow and Ankara that expressing an opinion is a human right.  Do not lecture other governments until you get your own house in order. Get tough on Spain because had it been any other government you would use all the powers you have to hold it to account. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, just for information, this is not a debate on Spain. Mr Aker, I really allowed you extra privilege to make your contribution.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Interpol is the largest police organization in the world. It unites 192 states. It cooperates in the persecution and arrest of criminals. Interpol must also cooperate with non-democratic states. It is cooperation with dictatorial regimes that brings the possibility of abusing Interpol to extradite political opponents to these regimes. Interpol countries include Russia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Turkey and Moldova. Interpol has therefore included in its constitution an important Article 3: It is strictly forbidden to act in matters of a military, political, religious or racial nature. Nevertheless, many people remain in search of undemocratic countries. Although the extradition of these persons has been rejected, they may still be on the wanted list, at risk of detention and detention, and not able to travel freely or find work. Interpol deals with the demands of undemocratic governments. For example, Akhmed Zakayev, Prime Minister of the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria, was arrested in Denmark on terrorism charges. It was not until 2003 that he was granted asylum in Britain after Russia's application was recognized as politically motivated by British courts. In some cases, Interpol rejected the requests. For example, in the case of William Browder, the author of the so-called Magnitsky Act. Under Article 3, Interpol also rejected the arrest and extradition of 3 MEPs, which Azerbaijan had called for "illegally" visiting Nagorno-Karabakh this year. We need Interpol in the fight against crime. That is why I welcome the ongoing reform of Interpol. Interpol should take far greater safeguards against abuse.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! I wanted our debate not to weaken Interpol in the first place or confuse what it was supposed to do. We have the times we are and there is a social expectation that what is needed is simply efficiency in prosecuting all kinds of criminals. This is the first - in my opinion - essential message. The second thing - Interpol should judge when it is to take action and whether it is to be fully effective, when it is not to take action. I believe that the debate on the criteria is by all means good and fruitful, and the criteria, once written, cannot be fixed, because our lives, our practice is very dynamic. Therefore, if Interpol is to respond at all times to the needs of the moment, this dialogue, these premises, areas, countries and criteria should be clearly defined and debated. I would also like to underline very clearly what Commissioner Jourova said: redress procedures, remedying damage if there is a mistake. Mistakes can happen and these procedures would be important. So our debate should help Interpol. This is the expectation that it will continue to be an effective organization.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, Hamza Yalçin, a Swedish journalist of Turkish origin, has spent 56 days in prison in Barcelona because the Government of Mariano Rajoy followed an Interpol order that the Turkish Government had filed: an order for insults to the president, for writing in a magazinenot adept at the regime and due to terrorist ties for being a member of a leftist partyThe Government of Spain of Mariano Rajoy has acted in complicity with the autocratic regime that President Erdogan has imposed in Turkey, which keeps 163 journalists imprisoned, has closed 128 media outlets or keeps 78 mayors and 13 deputies in jailand MPs from the Kurdish and Turkish left.But it seems that as long as Turkey collaborates with the xenophobic project of this fortress Europe, the European Union is ready to be an accomplice of repression.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would also like to join the voices of my colleagues who are calling here for the reform of Interpol and the reform of the red announcements. There have been a number of cases where, for example, Turkey has abused this institute to harass and punish dissidents who leave Turkish territory. These are not just examples in Spain, I am from the Czech Republic and we also had such a specific case in the Czech Republic. Perhaps it is known to the Commission, it was the case of Nazmi Sahin, who was a Turkish citizen of Kurdish nationality, sentenced in Turkey to six years for criminalizing links to organizations with political interests incompatible with the Turkish state. That is, it was clearly a political offense. So the red announcement came, he left his homeland, so the red announcement of Interpol came and the Czech judiciary dealt with this. Of course, the Czech judiciary did not extradite the person in question, but the whole proceedings took more than a year, and the Sahin in question was simply detained, restricted in his rights, basically indirectly bullied, and at the same time the Czech judiciary proceeded in accordance with the law. I think that the reform must be carried out by Interpol itself, the red notifications must be reformed, because the individual judicial authorities are then deciding how to proceed, in accordance with the substantive law in the Member State concerned. And even if the person in question is not released, in my opinion, several months of bullying is completely useless. After all, what one of my predecessors said is true, even if, for example, this person was not issued by the Czech Republic, this red notice continues to apply and he may be detained in any other state, and again the person in question may get into trouble. This means he is basically permanently bullied. So I'm also calling for a reform of the red announcements.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, this is a debate that is not only timely, it is a necessary debate, because Interpol's Red Notices - 'red information' - system has led not only to dysfunctions, but clearly intolerable political abuse . For example, in my own country, as noted here, in the summer of 2017, a Turkish-Swedish citizen and a German-Turkish citizen were both the targets of reprehensible extradition proceedings, on the very clear basis of political persecution. And the Council of Europe has already warned, as the Parliamentary Assembly has done in a 2017 Resolution, of the need to prevent countries with infamous human rights records from using Interpol to go after their opponents. It is important that the Commission clarifies to this Parliament what it intends to do to ensure that this distortion cannot take place, that the system is subject to all the checks on the substantiation of extradition proceedings so that they cannot be subject to violations or abuses of human rights, unacceptable uses, and, in particular, in the information exchange system through the second generation SIS, through ETIAS, through the Entry and Exit System and the exchange of information between Member State systems and Interpol. And that is why it is important for the Commission to clarify what measure it intends to adopt to be extremely rigorous, to prevent a mandate of deprivation of liberty or an abuse of the fundamental rights of individuals from being exercised through Interpol notifications.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe enacted Resolution 2161 en masse, entitled Abusive recourse to the Interpol system: the need for more stringent legal safeguards. Interpol is an efficient instrument for international cooperation in the fight against transnational crime, including terrorism, and is based on mutual assistance between national law enforcement authorities and must operate in complete neutrality and with respect for the human rights of suspects. The globalization process has opened up several channels of transnational criminal activity. Today, threats are complex, numerous and destabilizing, so international collaboration between police and judicial bodies is the answer to the internationalization of crime. The international alert allows Member State police to share critical information regarding crimes that have occurred, namely the red alert. Available data tells us that in the last decade, the number of red alerts issued has increased dramatically. Commissioner, I think that all of this is possible as long as there is respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Interpol red notices constitute a request for international cooperation by the criminal investigation authorities to locate and arrest, or otherwise restrict the freedom of movement, of persons in the territory of another state. On the subject of red notices, cases of improper use by some countries are known, including to repress individual freedoms and to pursue political purposes. According to a report by the NGO Fair Trials, there has been a significant increase in red notices from countries where fundamental freedoms are less protected and also in relation to the basis of a resolution of the Council of Europe highlights a consistent growth in red notices in recent years, with more than 12,000 notices issued in 2016 alone. More vigilance is needed on the correct use of red notices, ensuring that the rights of citizens of the European Union and third countries are not violated through the use of Interpol data by Member States and that the Commission take safeguard measures against abuses in the area of ​​external border controls and the use of information systems.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the role of Interpol is indeed important both in tackling global crime and in tackling terrorism. Of course, Interpol cannot be a state within a state. There must be control. It must respect fundamental freedoms and personal data in its activities. The Council of Europe resolution, as has been said, clearly states that the red mark is being abused because a number of countries are issuing, for political reasons, a red mark and then many people who are activists are being imprisoned and remain, possibly, in prisons for a long time or even extradited. We must therefore consider the conditions under which the person concerned may also intervene and bring an action against the red mark. Finally, I would like Interpol to work much more closely with the European authorities in dealing with the jihadists, who are a danger to our society.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I think we all agree that Interpol and police co—operation across borders are extremely important for our security. However, when the Interpol system is abused by undemocratic regimes to silence and persecute legitimate voices and human rights defenders, we must all be deeply concerned. The exiled Turkish journalist, Can Dündar, is now facing a Red Notice request in Germany after the Turkish Government submitted a request, accusing him of propaganda. He is one of an increasing number of individuals facing this type of persecution from afar.  The Kazakh Government is another serial abuser of the Red Notice system, with more and more dissidents and opposition leaders being targeted or simply being unfortunate innocent bystanders. Although Interpol does respond to requests to review its decisions, we need much more robust guarantees and serious safeguards and we need accountability for decisions that put human rights at risk.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this interesting debate. Interpol Red Notices are a useful tool to seek the arrest of suspects and serious offenders. It is first and foremost for Interpol and its member countries to address weaknesses in the system. It is for EU Member States to assess what action they take when they encounter a Red Notice and to carefully consider such notices in light of their originating country. Let me assure you that the Commission has followed and continues to follow this issue very closely. The Commission monitors in particular compliance by Member States with the principle of non-refoulement enshrined in EU law. This is to make sure that refugees are not returned if there is a risk of persecution.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the speakers, in particular Mr Moraes for the very pertinent questions about the situation. Indeed, we are in the situation where the EU Member States are members of another international organisation where there is no clear agreed common EU line or policy. At the recent meeting of the Political Security Committee and the Committee on Operational Cooperation on Internal Security (COSI), ideas were floated to address this situation. There were those who emphasised a need for a common approach, a need to share best practices. The Estonian Presidency invited all Member States to provide their ideas and to take this discussion further, even before the 20 November meeting with Interpol, to give ammunition to the Presidency at this meeting. We are committed to keeping this important topic on the agenda and we will of course ask Interpol about its plans on how to improve the review of the notices – because that is one of the main issues, the way that Interpol a priori reviews those Red Notices – and we may also expect requests by Interpol to provide more resources for them to do so. So the topic is on the agenda and discussions will be taken further.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - A lot of things don't work at Interpol. Interpol cannot be used for political purposes, as a mere tool at the service of repressive governments, but must uphold its standards of neutrality, and be used to share information that allows the arrest of real criminals, and not wayward journalists. Interpol should be a useful mechanism for sharing information, something very necessary and which has proven insufficient in recent years, with the terrorist attacks in Barcelona, ​​Paris or Brussels. It is unacceptable that some countries misuse Interpol's red notice system for the sole purpose of stifling freedom of expression or persecuting political opponents. Interpol's Regulation in its article 3 is clear: it prohibits the investigation of people on the basis of race, religion, etc. but we know that this is not true. Turkey uses Interpol red notices systematically to persecute people for political reasons. How long will we continue to consider Erdogan's authoritarian regime as a priority partner of the EU? Until things change, we won't tire of asking this question.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on safety on Europe's roads by Tomáš Zdechovský, Roberta Metsola and Michał Boni, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) (O-000060/2017 - B8-0601/2017) - (2017/2875 (RSP)).

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, for two years now, there has been a growing number of migrants around Calais who want to enter the United Kingdom illegally. They want to use the waiting trucks for the journey, into which they break into by force and unsuspecting drivers face heavy fines from British controls for this. Already in September 2015, the first worrying cases of Czech, Polish, Romanian, Spanish, Danish, Dutch and other drivers were recorded, in the trunk of which migrants were found during border checks. While the French inspection in Calais found no persons in the cargo hold of the trucks, on the British side, during the same inspection, they found refugees who, without the knowledge of the drivers, penetrated the cargo hold because they were trying to enter the territory of Great Britain illegally. In that case, the British authorities were uncompromising. They fined drivers, and therefore transport companies, for smuggling, although they passed the inspection in France without any problems and complied with all safety regulations. This question was actually started by the situation from this spring, when a Polish driver died on the grounds that obstacles had been put in his way. You wrote in your reply to the European Commission that there is currently no EU legislation governing the safety of land transport, which remains a matter for the Member States. Yes it is true. But on the other hand, I believe that the safety of drivers and the safety of EU citizens is one of the EU's shared competences. Therefore, I would like to address you with a question about what measures you are preparing in this context and how to effectively prevent these cases of unjustified accusation of drivers of smuggling.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, a year ago the Commission held an exchange of views on the impact of the migration crisis on the European commercial road transport sector and, in particular, on truck drivers in the Calais area. The Commission was aware then that the security threat to this vital sector was not only from irregular migrants, but also from organised crime seeking to steal vehicles and cargo for profit. Accurate, up-to-date statistics are hard to find for criminal incidents affecting the road transport sector across all EU Member States. The most comprehensive data are collected by the Transported Asset Protection Association, which has recorded a 24% increase in the number of cargo crimes in August compared with August 2016. They recorded almost 8000 criminal incidents affecting hauliers over the five years from the start of 2012 to the end of 2016, with a rise of about 213% between the full-year figures for 2012 to 2016. About 4.3% of the incidents involved violence or threat of violence against the driver, although the figures suggest a downward trend. Just over half of the incidents occurred in unsecured parking locations, with the majority happening at night. The worst hot-spots are motorway service stations or road laybys. It is important to add the caveat that these figures as they are based only on those reported to the Transported Asset Protection Association, and some EU Member States collect and report on many incidents compared with others. This data can therefore only be described as an indicative sample, and the actual number of incidents will be far higher.  Indeed, we must also sadly add another threat that has become all too apparent since the summer of last year, which is the hijacking of trucks by would-be terrorists to use them as a vehicle-ramming weapon against crowds of people. In these cases the threat to people’s lives extends beyond the truck driver, as we have seen in numerous incidents across Europe this year. We therefore take the matter very seriously, and within the limits of our competences continue to work with Member States and transport stakeholders to find viable and lasting ways to reduce the adverse impact of these threats on the critical road transport distribution chain. The Commission believes in taking a holistic, rational and proportional approach in order to ensure high levels of security and safety in our road transport system, but with minimal disruption. We are taking action to help improve security for commercial road transport with a project underway, in partnership with the sector, to create a comprehensive security guidance toolkit so that everyone with a role to play in securing the road transport chain has the knowledge to better help protect it against a range of security threats and all kinds of unauthorised intrusions using best practice tips and guidance. All relevant stakeholders have been consulted in the development of this toolkit. The Commission is now reviewing the delivery of the draft toolkit ahead of publication and dissemination over the coming months. This will include the translation of the toolkit into all Community languages and the creation of a website where additional information will be provided.  The use of digitally connected security systems will be a major enabler of the transformation of the current road transport system, including the development of new security solutions. In particular, the Commission supports Member State initiatives, such as the Swedish Government’s response to the Stockholm attacks through the development of geo-fencing to automatically restrict commercial vehicles from entering centre city zones such as pedestrian areas. The creation of safer and more secure truck parking areas along the trans-European transport network, the so-called TEN-T corridors, is a crucial element of the strategy to increase the security of drivers and cargo in road transport. The TEN-T Regulation specifically requires, in the TEN-T guidelines, that the corridor network is equipped with safe and secure parking areas approximately every 100 Km. To help make this a reality, the Commission has made EU funding available through our Connecting Europe Facility Programme over recent years to finance such parking places, and the Commission has provided almost EUR 30 million since 2015 to support nine secure parking projects. The European Parliament additionally provided a budget of EUR 850 000 to the Commission earlier this year to be used towards further developing safe and secure parking areas across Europe. The Commission is using this funding to launch a twelve month study to identify the appropriate location of safe and secure parking areas and the best design for a parking reservation system. Most importantly, the study will deliver a concrete roadmap for the gradual completion of the network of safe and secure parking areas, including a description of the actions needed and their timing. The results of the study will constitute the basis for future work of the Commission to eventually ensure that drivers can rest in secure conditions and sleep soundly. Improving the availability of secure truck parking is only part of the answer. Existing capacity needs to be optimised by information on the location and equipment of existing parking areas, as well as by optimising the parking spaces’ specific methodologies. On the basis of the Intelligent Transport Systems Directive, the Commission has adopted a delegated regulation on the provision of information services for safe and secure parking places for trucks and commercial vehicles. The delegated regulation indicates the way to collect, update, share and disseminate the necessary information on the location of the secure parking, including the provision of reservation services.

name: Емил Радев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, 'safe parking areas' in Europe are currently lacking in almost the entire European Union. It is necessary to create parking lots and rest areas, equipped with the appropriate security technology, both for drivers and for the loads themselves. They must cover both the main road arteries in Europe and the key road junctions in each Member State. This need is further reinforced by the recently proposed changes envisaged by some Member States, which introduce mandatory rest requirements for drivers, subject to certain sanitary conditions. In practice, this would mean that any driver would "abandon" the load he was transporting and go to a hotel. Something that is unthinkable in the driver's daily life, at least due to the lack of safe and secure places where vehicles and cargo can be left. But this issue is much more complex. It also affects road safety, as well as the reduction of road accidents and deaths caused by drivers asleep at the wheel. Because last year, for example, a total of 25,500 people died on European roads, and according to a study in the UK, about 40% of accidents involving drivers asleep at the wheel involve truck drivers and trucks. Secondly, when discussing the issue of road safety, the issue of road network density and traffic should also be addressed, as well as the safety standards of the car fleet in Europe. We are all aware that the countries of Central and especially Eastern Europe need additional assistance in the form of European funds to catch up with the construction of their road infrastructure. The lack of motorways, bypasses for lorries and their adjacent road infrastructure is an additional obstacle to solving this problem and removing barriers to the integrity of the single market. Let We acknowledge that any delay, any obstacle to the movement of goods and services within the Union is a direct loss for European companies and competitiveness.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, at this key moment in which we are addressing the presentation of the most important legislative package in recent years, regarding the review of all regulations that organize road transport and where precisely we have missed more regulations - and more courage also— in relation to road safety —although it is true that we hope that in the second part of the package the issue of infrastructure safety will appear, although it is not exactly or we do not see, at the moment, that it can face the current problem - We therefore need to speak precisely and confront as soon as possible the incidents that have been taking place for years. We are now talking about the last ones ... We have talked about kidnappings in case of terrorism, we have talked about the cases of Calais, as was raised in the question. But we have also had the case of Spanish truck drivers, who every time they crossed the French border were also targeted by farmers who were not happy with the free movement of goods - why are we going to fool ourselves? In other words, these drivers are also facing new challenges. Therefore, if now they are going to be required, as is being considered, to sleep away from the truck, we certainly need to make serious and credible commitments, not only about safe parking, but also and essentially to rehabilitate the sector, rather than continue to denigrate it as before, and, above all, to get more traffic safety officers on our roads.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Dear Commissioner, It is not the first time that we are debating the safety of truck drivers in this room. In the last year alone, we have called on the Commission and the French Government at least twice to act decisively in Calais. The problem has not been fully resolved so far, and a Polish truck driver has paid the price of his life for this ineffectiveness. Another Polish driver died in Berlin when an Islamic terrorist stole his vehicle to launch a cowardly attack on a Christmas market. Why has the Commission given so little attention to safety in its famous road initiatives? Can the Commissioner indicate where these safe car parks and hotels are located where, according to the Commission, drivers should take their daily rest? Maybe it is worth building such safe parking zones first, also thanks to European funding, and then changing the regulations? The legislative package presented here in May was called "Europe on the Move", but is it really a move towards the safety of drivers?

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let us not be mistaken. We are not here to discuss today who attacked which driver and where and for what reasons. Nor are we here to discuss whether this debate is legitimate and valid. That would be to side-line the two important issues: on one hand, the lack of secure parking places and, on the other, the inability of the Member States to implement the legislation which is in place. In this connection, it is worth mentioning that the driver is responsible for the truck and also for what the truck carries. As the Commissioner has already made clear, we have TEN-T guidelines, which say clearly that the Member States should be providing safe and secure parking facilities plus or minus every 100 kilometres. I would add that there is also an EU requirement for parking operators to provide information about the availability of these parking spaces, but Member States’ compliance with this requirement is, if I may say so, basically a joke. We can indeed ask how the Commission will safeguard security on European roads but we should not forget that Member States may be more to the forefront on this matter. They have to share information and make proper use of it, and they have to deliver for the TEN-T network. I have a final remark to make to the Commission.
