We are in the situation that we are to be implementing legislation which we are soon to agree on, but we have a lack of parking places. Is it realistic to expect that we will be in a position to implement this legislation in the foreseeable future, in the next few years, if the Member States do not comply today with the legislation already in place? This is something we should bear in mind when we are negotiating and approving the new mobility legislation.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: , on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I think my speech will be a little out of date. Safety on the roads of Europe, but especially towards Europe, is a real problem. For the past twenty years, Calais has been a focal point that illustrates the consequences of European and especially Franco-British policies. The number of migrants, I assure you, dear colleagues, has fallen sharply since the end of 2016. We have gone from around 7,000 to a few hundred, but this number is tending to increase again. I sympathize with the plight of the truck drivers, but in Calais at least 150 migrants have died since 2002. They want to deprive them of shelter and food. A priest had to oppose the police to allow a distribution of meals in the square of his church. It is outrageous and inhumane. Justice condemned the mayor of Calais and the French state to finally put an end to the inhuman and degrading treatment inflicted on these migrants. I think that it is by taking all of these situations into account that we will be able to secure the territory for those who cross it as well as for those who live there, and to avoid tragedies, whatever they may be.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I want to pick up on the part of the question as it was written and to say that, if we are looking at Calais, it is a very longstanding issue. My first visit to the safe parking area there was some 15 years ago. It was an area which had been set up by the Calais Chamber of Commerce, and we have seen considerable growth of the infrastructure up there since, with steel fences, more police activity, and yet the problems persist. All of us would agree that drivers should be able to operate safely, and we do need to tackle the criminal gangs who profit from desperate people here. We need to look at how we are doing in terms of cross-border police cooperation. But I also do not want to see any more dead unaccompanied minors falling from a truck when they should have been safe in the UK, had the Dublin system worked properly. So we do need a range of solutions to the problems we are looking at this evening, from asylum policy through to high technology.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the threat to the security of transit freight transport has several levels, between which we must distinguish. First of all, it must be said that road safety supervision and the handling of traffic offenses, as well as the prevention and prosecution of criminal offenses endangering property, health and life, are the exclusive competence of the Member States of the Union. However, the area of ​​transport and trans-European networks itself falls into the group of shared competences. We have common rules for the safe transport of passengers and goods. Road corridors are co-financed by the European budget. Transit transport simply has a European dimension and the Commission should address issues that jeopardize its fluidity and security. Taking effective measures to increase truck safety is also very important in the near future. Autonomous trucks, which should start driving on European roads in a few years, are already being tested in several Member States. But while artificial intelligence can significantly reduce accidents and increase traffic flow, it is much more vulnerable to unexpected attacks. Finally, another very sensitive dimension of European transit freight should be mentioned. It is a fact that most drivers are nationals of the new Member States. It would be very unfortunate if the Union hesitated to take measures to increase their security. That is why I am very grateful to the colleagues who have put this question to the Commission, and I join in their efforts to protect the drivers and the cargo they carry.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the safety of all road users is a matter of primary importance and which we discuss a lot, especially in the Committee on Transport and Tourism of which I am a member and as a member of it, I canto ensure that this issue will also be largely taken up in the new package of mobility rules that we are discussing.In particular, the drivers of heavy vehicles should have dedicated areas for rest and rest, provided with all the services but above all safe.They must be able to rest without worrying about either defending their cargo from theft, nor about their personal safety.Controls by the authorities are unfortunately insufficient in this area.Europe can do a lot at the regulatory level, but without the cooperation of the Member States too, it becomes difficult to implement the rules.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I understand and share the concerns about the safety of truck drivers and the cargo they transport. They are often the victims of raids by illegal immigrants, who in the most innocuous case use them for free transport to their desired destination. This is the reason why I am very skeptical and strongly against the desire of the lobbying interests of some Member States for drivers to take breaks outside trucks. It is a public secret that there are not enough hotels and guarded car parks on the roads of Europe to carry out such holidays. Examples are France and Belgium. There are no guarded hotels there, and drivers are forced to leave their cars in violation of the rules. Raids on cargoes lead to an increase in cargo insurance premiums and / or even a refusal of insurance companies to insure cargo on trucks passing certain routes. The insurance premium increased by 200% last year. I call on the Commission to abandon these wishes set out in the Mobility project, because there is nothing more important than the physical security of truck drivers.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I think it is a good idea to highlight this problem on the Commission's agenda, at a time when we began the debate on the road transport package and in full transition from the concept of transport itself, conceived as a sum of ways towards an integrated mobility model. Now that the modification of the Regulation on driving time and rest is underway, which directly affects the safety of drivers, road safety and the conditions and quality of employment in the sector, I would like to ask that, in the modification , or undetermined concepts are eliminated or specified, such as what is meant by "home", by "adequate rest" and many other concepts. This issue is directly linked to what I consider to be a necessary definition of 'safe parking areas' in terms of road safety, but also in terms of physical safety and in terms of services for drivers. In addition, it seems important to influence, from the perspective of professional transport, to promote greater coordination between the police forces that deal with traffic and those that carry out border security controls on both sides of the same, something that can avoid many congestion. Finally, this reflection should include the promotion of connected vehicles, driving aids, electronic tolls and intelligent road management, including automated information on safe parking areas with shared tools that work in the cross-border environment. This will make the road safer.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, there is a bigger problem behind the problem of truck drivers: immigration, the problem of closed borders. This is not directly said by the colleagues of the People's Party who asked the question. They refer to attacks, but imply desperate migrants trapped at borders and ports. How many migrants died from suffocation in truck caches? Of course, truck drivers have our support, not only for inhumane working hours, stress on time, poor road networks, attacks, but also because they are excluded from the Posting of Workers Directive. But just as drivers need safe roads, so refugees need legal and safe passageways, and here there is no rivalry between them.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: - President! Two years ago, the emergency situation around the port of Calais has raised the growing issue of driver safety. In response to a written question at the time, the Commission pointed out the importance of the EU Action Plan against Migrant Smuggling, adopted on 27 May 2015, in tackling the problem. Two years later, we see that trucks have become the means of perpetrating terrorist acts and that professional drivers have fallen victim in many cases. All this only proves that the Commission's plan to tackle the migrant crisis, like other EU initiatives, is not working in practice. We need to talk about the constant decline in the number of hauliers, the lack of resupply, the wages of hauliers and other social issues, but all this is worthless if the level of driver safety deteriorates so much that dangerous surcharges are slowly being paid to those transporting goods to Europe's major ports. Calais, for example. In the meantime, some Member States are taking protectionist measures to protect markets, which undermine the common market and the free movement of goods and services. Here we could mention the missing resting places, parking lots. Apart from the fact that there are few of them, they do not ensure the safety of either the driver or the shipment. It is a well-known fact that leaving a vehicle also raises practical, legal and insurance issues. Our aim is to alleviate the situation of carriers and create conditions for them that offer a practical solution, especially through the mobility package that will be negotiated soon. Drivers would probably appreciate this more than the Commission's and some Member States' efforts to force them into dubious roadside accommodation instead of a fully equipped cabin!

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman! I have a different opinion on the words that have been said here about what a backbreaking job it is to be a truck driver. Well, no, gentlemen, this is not such a backbreaking job. What we would expect, however, is a certain minimum of security, and that is what is needed. Minimum safety both in the investment part, therefore yes: road and along the road, including parking lots and additional service. I'd like to see police cars in every parking lot. Well, this is a rare sight. I would like to see, for example, a road transport inspection in the parking lot that exists in every country. Both institutions are most often there to think about how to punish drivers, but not necessarily to help them for their safety, also for the safety of cargo. It is a fact that drivers are not always trained, it is a fact that drivers are often from countries that offer a lower wage. But it is also a fact that they are operating under the pressure of this great cheap competition.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, road safety in Europe is a very important issue and, of course, we need to ensure the safe movement of lorries, which cause a lot of accidents. At the same time, however, the safety of truck drivers and their goods must be protected. However, Mrs Jourová, I would like to ask you a serious issue that is happening in Greece: there is currently a real piracy of trucks with Bulgarian license plates, which carry out internal transport work and stay in Greece for more than ten days, while this is prohibited. . They make domestic itineraries and in fact compete unfairly with Greek companies and create a lot of problems. This is a serious matter. I convey to you the cry of agony of the owners and drivers of Greek trucks who can no longer withstand this unfair competition from trucks with Bulgarian license plates which are literally pirate.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, when more than eleven million people in the European Union earn their living in activities related to the transport of goods by road, it becomes an obligation to have safer roads, rest areas and secure parking. But not all the problem is solved with an investment to improve the infrastructures: the driving times and the quality of the rest of the transporters are terrible. On many occasions, after exhausting days of driving, they have to stop anywhere, without the right to a decent rest, to continue the journey as soon as they wake up. Added to this are the high levels of stress that drivers are having from having to monitor the load they transport and, if not, take care of the payments and the repercussions of losing it. The potential danger posed by these situations is a problem for road safety, drivers and society. Controls must be increased, legislation improved and, above all, working conditions improve.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, although there has been great progress in road safety in the European Union in recent decades, the high number of fatalities and serious injuries continues to cause great human suffering and unacceptable economic costs, estimated at EUR 100 billion annually. In 2016, 25,000 people lost their lives on the roads of the European Union and another 135,000 were seriously injured. European Commission data on road safety show a 2% decrease in the number of fatalities in 2016. However, while these data are encouraging, they may nevertheless be insufficient for the European Union to achieve its goal of reducing halving road mortality between 2010 and 2020. In order to stop these silent killers, the Valletta Declaration was signed in Malta, which represents a common commitment by EU Member States to promote road safety and reduce accidents. One of the main objectives is to reduce by 50% the number of fatalities in road accidents in 2020, having the year 2010 as a reference, and to reduce by 50% the number of serious injuries in 2030 compared to 2020. The package called “Europe in Movement ”aims, in particular, to make traffic safer, recognizing that actions by all stakeholders are needed to reduce losses and deaths. Commissioner, the truth is that, since the adoption of this package on 31 May, little progress has been made in road prevention and other issues closely linked to road safety remain unanswered, issues which are linked - as the Commissioner has said here - to combating terrorism and the lack of coordination between the police in combating crime.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I want to appreciate the question asked by my colleagues and I think we need to understand it correctly. This is about safety and security and there is a complex of factors: the quality of roads, infrastructure, unguarded parking, non-compliance with regulations, because there are states that fine drivers who sleep in the cab to guard their goods and are attacked or find the next day, if they leave, the truck occupied by another person; violates the rules and fines these drivers. Here we have economic effects, obviously, insurance increases, some insurance companies no longer want to insure carriers and drivers. I met with associations of carriers, with drivers, all of them complain about the extraordinarily precarious situation of transport safety from the point of view of guarded parking lots, from the point of view of lack of control, after all, because, as I was saying here, we must also have border control. But we have a gang of criminals, we were talking earlier, Commissioner at the European Public Prosecutor's Office, who are simply stealing from trucks. So here we need the support of the European Commission, not just the national authorities.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, road accidents are one of the leading causes of death in Europe, with more than 120,000 fatalities per year. We must be realistic: we cannot think of making all the motorways of Europe safe with a stroke of the pen in a few months. We need a work culture that restores dignity and rights to hauliers, with intelligent rules that prohibit exhausting driving shifts, in particular those to which drivers are obliged to circumvent the rules on cabotage and those to protect the single market. But Europe must also aim to raise the average quality of its road network, without neglecting the secondary networks. State-of-the-art infrastructure and obsolete, poorly lit, too busy and dangerous roads often coexist in the same region. Just as it is necessary to secure the parking areas along the motorways, often the place of trivial and grotesque accidents. An action plan must be drawn up as soon as possible to make our roads safe: only homogeneous safety throughout the European road network can lower the impressive number of victims that we are forced to count every year.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: - Can I safely do my job today?That is what many truck drivers ask themselves when they drive their truck through Europe.I share those concerns of the truck drivers.That is why I, together with my colleague Dennis de Jong, wrote to the Ministers of Transport of the Netherlands, Belgium and France and called on them to take measures to ensure a safe route to Calais.My first question to the Commissioner is: has this topic actually been discussed in the Transport Council in September?My second question would be: if in 2015 we as the European Parliament called for more safe parking spaces, and the Commissioner says that nine have been built with European money in the past period, which Member States should do more to ensure the safety of our drivers?to ensure?Because I think we have a joint task here as the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Member States.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, it has been a very interesting debate. When I am confronted with transport experts in my country, everyone is talking about safe parking zones. I think this is an extremely important issue that the EU should address, because if these parking zones are to be logically distributed across Europe in some way, then this must be coordinated by the EU. Thank you, Commissioner, that you have paid relatively much attention to this issue in your speech, but I still think that in the future, Europe will need to play an even bigger role here. We will probably not solve the violence against truck drivers, it will probably always fall within the competence of individual nation states. But we can play our part in increasing the overall safety of truck transport across the European continent and in ensuring a certain status for individual, say, truck drivers. And those parking spaces are, in my opinion, extremely important.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Before I give the floor to Commissioner Jourová, I want to say that we have seen a very broad debate, from refugees to cabotage.I do not want to disregard any of these issues, but I would like to thank all the speakers who, in their contributions, have referred to the core of the question.(End of the catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank the House very much for this important and interesting discussion. As I said at the beginning of this debate, for the Commission it is of the utmost importance that the road transport sector can function well and that the safety and security of drivers is ensured. The road freight sector is facing a complex range of threats which continue to cause increased costs and delays, affecting the competitiveness and viability of the many small and medium—sized enterprises, which are the backbone of the sector. The Commission is working hard to find solutions to mitigate these security issues through a mix of interventions which include funding and the development of best practice guidance and tools to help the sector to improve its overall security.  This is in addition to actions that Member States and regional governments themselves must take to better secure their roads. There is no single magic solution that will solve all of these problems overnight, so the focus of the Commission will remain on working with our partners to collectively improve the security of Europe’s roads in the long term.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I thank all colleagues who have followed this debate to the end.I also thank the services.I wish you all a safe way home and a good night's sleep.(The sitting was closed at 9.48 p. M.)
